PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That the ancient and irreplaceable native forests in the South West of Western Australia are being destroyed by logging for woodchipping, that many species in these forests are in danger of extinction, and that Federal Government intervention is urgently needed to protect our natural heritage.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in parliament assembled, should call on the Federal Government to:
1.immediately use its powers to protect Hawke, Sharpe, Giblett and Rocky blocks and all other high conservation value and old growth forests in the South West of Western Australia,
2.refuse to renew woodchip export licences unless it is guaranteed that the wood comes from tree crops, agroforestry or plantations and,
3.take steps to ensure the rapid transfer of the wood products industry from all native forests and on to plantations, tree crops and agroforestry.

PETITION.TITLE: Landmines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned urges the Government to press for a total ban internationally on the production, stockpiling, trade and use of anti-personnel devices.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate urge the Government to provide financial aid for the demining of countries such as Cambodia.

PETITION.TITLE: Chemicals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned respectfully call upon the Federal Government to
(1)consider the grave concerns of residents of Pyengana in Northern Tasmania that their water catchments have been adversely affected by private forestry operation's use of simazine.
(2)accept full responsibility for control of use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals.
(3)investigate, as a matter of urgency, the need for amending the label, monitoring the application, or withdrawing the chemical from use.

Dear Senator Colston

Thank you for your letter of 10 November 1994 concerning a discretion contained in new regulation 2B(3)(a) of the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Regulations (Amendments), Statutory Rules 1994 No. 325. The Committee has asked whether there are any criteria in the Regulations for the exercise of this discretion and whether its exercise is subject to AAT review.

New regulation 2B prescribes the level of professional indemnity insurance required of registered brokers and foreign insurance agents. It amalgamates two separate former regulations (3A and 10B) which set identical standards for these two types of intermediary. In amalgamating old regulations 3A(3)(a) and 10B(3)(a), new regulation 2B(3)(a) did not change their content or the Commissioner's discretion in any way.

There is a concern that large excesses or deductibles in professional indemnity insurance policies can result in loss to members of the public dealing with insurance intermediaries. Old regulations 3A(3)(a) and 10B(3)(a) limited the deductible amount allowable for registered insurance intermediaries. However, they also allowed the Commissioner to administer the legislation with flexibility where this was justified by the circumstances.

The Insurance and Superannuation Commission publication—A Guide to the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act 1984—has been issued to all registered brokers and foreign insurance agents. This makes clear that higher deductible amounts may be approved where an intermediary has adequate supporting capital, or a guarantee from a bank or other secure entity.

The Commissioner's discretion to approve deductibles is subject to sections 41 and 42 of the Act. Section 41 prevents the Commissioner from making an adverse decision affecting a person under this Act without giving that person notice of his or her right to be heard. Section 42 allows an application to be made to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for general review of decisions of the Commissioner under this Act.

I am advised by the ISC that the provisions were reviewed as a result of the then Minister Assisting the Treasurer's letter of 7 February 1990 to the Committee. The conclusion was reached that the general review provisions of section 42 apply to both the Act and to the Regulations. The legislation is therefore considered to provide protection for all persons subject to the Commissioner's discretionary powers in this area.
Yours faithfully
Paul Elliott
7 December 1994
10 November 1994
The Hon Michael Lee MP

Parliament House

Dear Minister
I refer to the following instruments considered by the Committee at its meeting of 10 November 1994:
1.Citizen Band Radio Stations Class Licence made under s.132(1) of the Radiocommunications Act 1992
2.Handphone Stations (27 MHz) Class Licence made under s.132(1) of the Radiocommunications Act 1992.

Clause 8 of the former instrument and clause 7 of the latter provide for circumstances in which directions may be given relating to the operation of a station and set out the persons who may give such directions.

The circumstances are where there might be interference to radiocommunications which may endanger an aircraft or there are emergencies relating to the environment, risk of death or injury to persons or substantial damage to property. The persons who may give directions are police, Defence Force officers, officers of the Australian Coastal Surveillance Centre and certain prescribed officers.
These provisions appear appropriate and reasonable, but the Committee asks which provisions of the parent Act authorise the conferral of these powers to give directions.
Yours sincerely
Mal Colston
Chairman
31 January 1995
Senator Mal Colston
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Colston

Thank you for your letter of 10 November 1994 about the Citizen Band Radio Station (CBRS) and Handphone Stations (27 MHz) class licences that were made under s.132(1) of the Radiocommunications Act 1992 (the Act) and considered by the Committee at its meeting of 10 November 1994.

The Committee has sought information about what provisions of the Act authorise the conferral of powers to give directions under clause 8 of the CBRS and clause 7 of the Handphone Stations (27 MHz) class licences.

I can advise that the power to allow directions to be made under both clauses is conferred by s.133 of the Act. In particular, subsection 133(1) provides that "the SMA may include in a class licence such conditions as it thinks fit". Paragraph 6(b) of both licences makes it a condition that a person operating a CBRS or handphone station must comply with a direction given under the abovementioned clauses.
The condition is identical to a condition imposed in individual apparatus licences issued under s.100 of the Act.
I trust this information addresses the concerns of the Committee on this matter.
Yours sincerely
Michael Lee

—by leave—With great respect to Senator Spindler—I do not know whether he heard my discussion with Senator Woodley—what he said just now is not correct. Senator Woodley told me at the last minute that the Democrats would not support the motion today because it had not been considered by the party. That is what he told me.
