DEBATE.TITLE: LAW AND JUSTICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 1 February, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had reached the stage where I was suggesting that the government was wrong in rejecting our suggestion that there needs to be further avenues for review under this legislation. We are concerned that the lower chance of having a security assessment overturned is the reason for ASIO being asked to conduct fewer assessments in recent years. We would be interested to hear the minister's response to that.

PARA.TAB: Another matter raised by the parliamentary joint committee was that injustices could arise because `the decision to refuse access, whether on the basis of security or general suitability grounds such as a character, is not in fact capable of judicial review'. The committee concluded that `the review process should be an effective one covering all relevant aspects of the process, including the actual decision'. This is consistent with the concerns of the Administrative Review Council, which, in its report to the Commonwealth government entitled Review of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act: the ambit of the act made this comment:

SPEECH.PARA: In the Council's view, a distinction is properly drawn between the amenability to review security decisions as a class and the applicability of the grounds of review to a particular decision.

The ARC also recommended that certain provisions of schedule 1, including provisions relating to decisions under the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act 1979 of the AD(JR) Act 1977, should be repealed. Yet the very same schedule is to apply to the new division of the AAT.

PARA.TAB: In summary, the Australian Democrats support the abolition of the Security Appeals Tribunal and the transfer of its functions to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal because of not only the possible cost savings but also the advantages in having a single tribunal system with uniform standards. Nonetheless, we believe that there are a number of flaws in the bill as presently drafted and as I have indicated. We therefore seek the referral of this bill to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

I wish to make a couple of further points to some of the other amendments in this bill. We are also concerned about the proposed changes to the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. These amendments provide that if a provision of an act has an invalid application but also has at least one valid application, then, unless the contrary intention appears, `it is the parliament's intention that the provision is not to have the invalid application but is to have every valid application.'

While it may well be that the amendments are ultimately useful, we are always wary of the executive of the parliament attempting to fetter the powers of the judiciary. For this reason we believe it would be beneficial to have the Senate committee look at that provision as well. There are also some points to be made about the amendments proposed in this bill to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975. The impetus for the reforms is contained in the 1991 Report of the review of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. This report has already provided the basis for reforms previously dealt with in an earlier law and justice legislation amendment bill. But we would be keen to examine this aspect of the bill in the context of the whole of the review process when it is considered by the committee.

Finally, there are some amendments to the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976. Certain of the changes give an arbitrator to whom a matter has been referred the power to apply to the court for leave to refer a question of law to the court. However, it has been suggested that these changes may be unduly restrictive and that the litigant should be able to make such an application personally in the same way that such applications are contemplated by the provisions of section 39 of the Commercial Arbitration Act 1984 in Victoria which are mirrored in arbitration legislation throughout Australia.

Further, there is some concern that the proposed section 53AB of the act is different to and out of step with this uniform commercial arbitration legislation. The proposed legislation also gives an unfettered right of appeal from an arbitrator's award to a party to an award. The legislation elsewhere in Australia does not give such a ride but allows an appeal either with the consent of all parties or the leave of the court. This can be seen in sections 38(2) and (4) of the Victorian act. Furthermore, the court cannot give such leave unless it is satisfied that there is a manifest error of law on the face of the award or that there is strong evidence that the arbitrator made an error of law and the question of law may add to the certainty of the commercial law.

Uniformity of approach throughout Australia is considered to be desirable to prevent forum shopping, which can be a costly process. In addition, the curtailment of appeals from arbitrators is said to be desirable because it would reduce the overall legislation and cost of litigation. This factor will need to be considered in the deliberations of the committee. We welcome the bill and look forward to scrutinising the bill within the framework of the referral to the Senate committee on legal and constitutional affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not traverse the ground already covered by Senators Vanstone and Spindler, who have set out the purpose of the bill and its general application. There are, however, two matters that cause me concern. I am pleased to hear that this bill will be going before the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.The first matter that causes me some concern is the amendment to the Acts Interpretation Act. Section 15 AAA, in particular, is what I refer to. I note that the explanatory memorandum states that in some recent cases the High Court has found the invalid application of Commonwealth law and has struck down various provisions. I will refer briefly to those two cases. There was a migration case commonly known as the Lim case reported in (1992) 176 CLR 1. That related to a provision which dealt with the imprisonment of boat people.

PARA.TAB: The section in question prohibited a court from releasing a designated person from custody. The High Court held that, as the section could apply to a person who was not in lawful custody as well as a person who was in lawful custody, it derogated from the court's powers to order the release and it was therefore invalid. The section, it would seem, applied to people who were lawfully imprisoned and people who were unlawfully imprisoned; it had a dual application. Because one of those applications was invalid, the provision was struck down.

Similarly, in Nationwide News, a case reported in 1992 177 CLR 1, a provision of the Industrial Relations Act made it an offence to use words which were calculated to bring a member of the Industrial Relations Commission into disrepute. The section applied to someone calling an industrial relations commissioner names, if you like—abusing the person—and also defaming the person. There were two aspects to it. As I understand the case, the law as such cut across the laws of defamation, which were not within the Commonwealth's ambit of legislative power.

The section had two applications. Accordingly, the court ruled that where you have two applications, one being invalid, the provision is struck down.Simply put, the situation is that if you have a law which supposedly deals with apples and, in the process, it touches on pears, and the Commonwealth does not have the power to deal with pears, the High Court strikes down the provision because it says, `It could deal with apples or it could deal with pears. It is not supposed to deal with pears.'

The Acts Interpretation Act is an act which is there to assist us in looking at Commonwealth law, to assist us in understanding federal legislation. I noted with some amusement the heading under the Acts Interpretation Act. It states, `An Act for the Interpretation of Acts of Parliament and for Shortening their Language'. I think section 15AAA proposed by the government really does not hold true to that principle; in fact, nor does the very act itself. It is quite amusing that there is this purpose at the head of the Acts Interpretation Act. I have yet to see the intention of shortening the language of the legislation. I think I will be a very old man before I see that happen.

This proposal gives parliament a bit of a two-way bet. This is my understanding of it, and I am open to correction. This is why I think it is a very good idea to refer it to the Senate's committee on legal and constitutional affairs. The proposal seems to allow sloppier drafting to slip through the net. If the law has two applications—if it applies to apples and pears—it would seem that the provision is allowable in so far as it applies or has valid application.

If it applies validly to apples and also touches on pears, this new proposal seems to say, `Forget the fact that it touches on pears; that is not right. But it is still okay for the apples.' The previous situation seemed to be that, if it touched on pears and apples and pears were not allowed, it was struck down entirely. So it allows it to slip through the net, so to speak. I think it really does widen the application of Commonwealth legislation.

On the face of it, that is an undesirable thing to have in legislation. If you legislate for something, it should touch on only that. If it touches on anything else which is invalid, beyond the powers of the parliament, I believe it should be struck down. That is a view I hold at the moment. I am open to advice, which no doubt we will receive via the evidence given to the committee. I believe there should be some accountability, if I can put it that way, in the drafting of legislation.

We have a federal system. The Commonwealth is allowed to legislate on only certain matters. The states legislate on other matters. If the Commonwealth steps over that bound and touches on areas where it is not allowed to transgress, where it is not allowed to go, that legislation should be struck down. I think this could really open the floodgates. I am not so sure that current section 15A is insufficient. I think it is an adequate provision and there is not a case to be made out by the government for the introduction of this new proposal. The two cases I mentioned, Lim and Nationwide News, do not illustrate the point well enough for the government.

The other point which is not of such great moment is the amendment to the Federal Court of Australia Act which is found in clause 35 of schedule 2 of the bill. Proposed sections 53AA and 53AB allow for an arbitrator in a hearing to refer proceedings to the Federal Court with the consent of the parties. The Law Council of Australia had some concern about this. An individual should be able to make application direct to have a matter of law referred to the Federal Court. If a question arises in such proceedings, it should not be so hamstrung that the arbitrator refers the problem—if we can call it that—to the Federal Court only with the consent of the parties. It might not be in the interests of one party to agree. It might not want it referred. The other party who has the argument might want it referred. I think it should always be available in proceedings for either party, the plaintiff or the defendant, to be able to air their argument fully and not be stymied from going any further. I think in this particular case this provision does that.

Again, I am open to the advice that no doubt we will receive via the evidence given to us. I await with interest to see the evidence of the Attorney-General. But for the time being I think this proposal is not a good one. It does not enjoy my support. Perhaps I misunderstood the operation of this proposed amendment, but it seems fairly clear that an individual cannot refer a matter to the Federal Court in such proceedings, it has to go via the arbitrator and it has to be done by consent. That is not a desirable situation. The bill otherwise has some commendable aspects to it. Those aspects have been touched on more than adequately by Senator Vanstone and Senator Spindler.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank senators for their contribution to this second reading debate. I note that this bill is being referred to a committee. The government will be supporting that reference.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

Ordered that the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1994 stands referred to the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee for consideration and report on 6 February 1995 pursuant to the order of the Senate agreed to earlier today.
Consideration resumed from 25 August 1994.
Bill agreed to, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Consideration resumed from 25 August 1994.
The bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some general comments about the Criminal Code Bill and the Crimes Amendment Bill, which were also handled on a cognate basis in the committee inquiry. The two bills went through quite an extensive consultation process and are the result of the work of two committees outside parliament. The first committee was the Gibbs committee, chaired by Sir Harry Gibbs, which published a report in July 1990 dealing with principles of criminal responsibility. The second report was produced by the Model Criminal Code Officers Committee, which was established by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General in June 1990. A significant feature of these two bills is that they are intended to establish a criminal code which is uniform throughout Australia and that they are the product of consultation between the state Attorneys-General as well as with the Commonwealth.

PARA.TAB: One particular provision I would like to address is the so-called Majewski issue. In developing the provision in section 426 that evidence of self-induced intoxication cannot be considered in determining whether the conduct was voluntary, the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General decided to follow the UK decision in Majewski (1977) AC 480 that evidence of intoxication can be used to deny intention or recklessness in offences of specific intent, such as murder, but cannot be used as an excuse in relation to simple offences of basic intent, such as assault.

This section, which is now being passed in the bills before the Senate, would place the Commonwealth in line with the law in England, Canada, the United States, Queensland, WA, Tasmania and the Northern Territory. However, it alters the common law in New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and the ACT, where gross intoxication may be taken into account in relation to all offences as a result of the High Court's decision in O'Connor in 1980. This is one of the provisions of the bills which was very carefully examined by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. While we express some concern about the change in the law, the Australian Democrats have decided to support it.

There are a number of other issues which equally were discussed by the Senate standing committee. Some of them are in the area of conspiracy. That issue arose under both bills and each requires an agreement to commit an offence as well as an overt act taken pursuant to that agreement. The Director of Public Prosecutions objected to the inclusion of the overt act requirement and argued that in some instances—for example, a murder—all the planning may have been done and the only remaining act could be the offence itself. However, as the Queensland Council of Civil Liberties argued, the inclusion of the overt act requirement ensures that the law properly distinguishes between tentative talk which might be constituted into an illegal agreement and something that was in fact serious. The Australian Democrats once again support that provision.

One provision that caused us considerable concern during the committee's inquiry was the requirement that people can be held to have withdrawn from a conspiracy if they have taken all reasonable steps to prevent the offence which is the subject of the conspiracy to proceed. That may well be interpreted to mean that they should be obliged to inform the authorities of the planned operation and this could in fact act as a disincentive to withdrawal. We would have been happier if the bill had not used the word `all'. We would have preferred to have seen that struck out. Once again, bearing in mind that the bill is the result of thorough consultation between the states and the Commonwealth, the Democrats have decided not to seek an amendment to this bill.

Finally, I briefly state that the Democrats support strongly the provisions on corporate criminal responsibility. While some concerns were expressed about those sections before the committee, we believe that these provisions are an advance in Australian criminal law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Spindler pointed out, the Criminal Code Bill and the Crimes Amendment Bill are intended to bring about a federal criminal code. Common law operates in New South Wales and Victoria and a criminal code operates in Western Australia, Queensland and Tasmania. These bills have sought to merge the two so that there is uniform criminal law throughout the Commonwealth. In the first instance this code will apply only to federal offences, but it is anticipated that the states will follow and introduce similar legislation so that there is uniform criminal law throughout the country.

PARA.TAB: For example, the age of criminal responsibility varies throughout Australia. In Tasmania it is the age of seven, in the ACT it is the age of eight, and elsewhere it is the age of 10. The example given to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee was that of a seven-year-old child from New South Wales being able to be convicted of a federal offence committed while on holiday in Tasmania when the same act committed at home would result in no charge. It is this sort of inconsistency that the code seeks to remedy.

There seems to be a good deal of support for a national criminal code. It is anticipated that this will not come about for another five years. I think that is the time frame the government is looking at. I urge the government to introduce this law carefully and err on the side of caution rather than of haste because we are dealing with perhaps the most important legislation which could come through this and the other place.

Criminal law goes directly to sanctioning the behaviour of the citizens of the country. It involves serious penalties and the deprivation of liberty. Apart from the death penalty, there is nothing greater than that. So we have to be very careful when we look at how we judge people to be guilty of an offence and what sorts of acts will constitute an offence at law.

Traditionally, criminal offences are looked at in Latin terms of actus reus and mens rea; that is, the act that is done and the intention that goes with it. For instance, I could throw a piece of wood into a crowd. I might not intend to hurt anybody but, nonetheless, that act is a dangerous one. The law looks at that and says that if I intended to hurt someone I am guilty of perhaps a more serious offence. In fact, if I killed someone I would be guilty of wilful murder. If, however, I just threw it recklessly that could be a lesser charge. I would still be guilty of an offence but guilty of manslaughter or murder. The criminal law looks at the act that is done and the intention that follows the act.

In this particular legislation, the terms `physical elements' and `fault elements' are used. I think there is going to be some trouble in getting this across to both the legal profession and the public at large. It was Her Honour Judge Yeats from the District Court of Western Australia who really drew the committee's attention to the drafting of the bill. She said that physical element and fault element were perhaps unfortunate choices and were not to be preferred to the current terminology—words like `fact', `act' or `omission'.

I would suggest that the government have a look at the drafting of the criminal codes. The Griffiths code is an exceptional piece of legislation. Although it was drafted at the time of Federation, the words are still capable of simple understanding. As Her Honour Judge Yeats said, the use of a word such as `fact' or `act' are words that anyone can understand. But once you say to people, `In judging whether you are guilty we have to look at the physical element and the fault element,' it gets a bit nebulous.

Her Honour Judge Yeats said, `I have to face juries and explain to juries what the law means.' She concluded that a criminal code should be usable by juries as well as by lawyers and that drafting in any way that can result in a misunderstanding is very serious. She said in her evidence:

SPEECH.PARA: I could probably, after some study, grasp this legislation, but my job is not to simply grasp the law but to explain it to a jury, and that is the point where the simpler the language and the simpler the concepts, the more usable the code will be . . . The language that is used has taken it out of the realm of being usable with juries, and that is a serious, serious problem.

What Her Honour was saying was that the wording would make it difficult for judges to put this legislation to juries, which consist of men and women chosen at random. I believe that is a concern. I would ask the government to be ever mindful of that.

PARA.TAB: I applaud the move for such a national code. In the committee's report—I refer to page 34—there were some drafting aspects of the bill which the committee put to the government. I ask the government what it thought of those proposals in relation to the specific drafting issues at page 34 and 35 of the committee report.

It is such a complex area that in the remaining eight minutes of my speaking time I could not attempt to cover adequately the issues concerned. Senator Spindler raised some issues which I share. But my main concern is that if you are going to have legislation of this importance you keep the language as simple as possible, and the Griffiths code is a very good example of such simple language. At the end of the day, this legislation is going to have to be understood by a jury.

It will be a jury that the judge explains this legislation to and says, `A person is guilty of conspiracy or intoxication if these circumstances apply.' Intoxication, for instance, as Senator Spindler touched on, can affect culpability in this way. The judge then perhaps reads the section from the legislation to the jury, and if that section is too complex, if that section is not capable of being simply understood, then juries are going to have a difficult time getting their minds around the law.

I think that is my main concern with the proposed legislation. It is introducing new terminology. Hitherto we have dealt with very simple words, very simple concepts. `Beyond a reasonable doubt' is a concept which I believe most men and women understand. They have heard it enough and they know it applies to the law.

Similarly, when you say to someone, `If you commit an act which results in death, then in certain circumstances you can be guilty,' that is very simple; anyone can understand that. When you bring in notions of fault elements and physical elements, it then gets quite unclear. That is my difficulty with the proposed legislation. But, as I say, this is commendable legislation, and I hope that the government takes on board the committee's recommendations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Clause 6, page 3, lines 3 to 39 and page 4, lines 1 to 15, omit the clause.
(2)Clause 9, page 4, lines 22 and 23, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Repeal of sections 86 and 86A and substitution of new section

PARA.TAB: "9. Sections 86 and 86A of the Principal Act are repealed and the following section is substituted:

`86.(1) A person who conspires with another person to commit an offence against a law of the Commonwealth punishable by imprisonment for more than 12 months, or by a fine of 200 penalty units or more, is guilty of the offence of conspiracy to commit that offence and is punishable as if the offence to which the conspiracy relates had been committed.

`(2) Despite subsection (1), if the person conspires with another person to commit an offence against section 29D of this Act, the conspiracy is punishable by a fine not exceeding 2,000 penalty units, or imprisonment for a period not exceeding 20 years, or both.

SPEECH.PARA: Note: Penalty units are defined in section 4AA.

PARA.TAB: `(3) For the person to be guilty:
(a)the person must have entered into an agreement with one or more other persons; and

TAB.TAB: (b)the person and at least one other party to the agreement must have intended that an offence would be committed pursuant to the agreement; and
(c)the person or at least one other party to the agreement must have committed an overt act pursuant to the agreement.
`(4)A person may be found guilty of conspiracy to commit an offence even if:
(a)committing the offence is impossible; or

PARA.TAB: (b)the only other party to the agreement is a body corporate; or

TAB.TAB: (c)each other party to the agreement is at least one of the following:
(i)a person who is not criminally responsible;
(ii)a person for whose benefit or protection the offence exists; or
(d)subject to paragraph (5)(a), all other parties to the agreement have been acquitted of the conspiracy.

PARA.TAB: `(5)A person cannot be found guilty of conspiracy to commit an offence if:

TAB.TAB: (a)all other parties to the agreement have been acquitted of the conspiracy and a finding of guilt would be inconsistent with their acquittal; or
(b)he or she is a person for whose benefit or protection the offence exists.
`(6)A person cannot be found guilty of conspiracy to commit an offence if, before the commission of an overt act pursuant to the agreement, the person:
(a)withdrew from the agreement; and
(b)took all reasonable steps to prevent the commission of the offence.
`(7)A court may dismiss a charge of conspiracy if it thinks that the interests of justice require it to do so.
`(8)Any defences, procedures, limitations or qualifying provisions that apply to an offence apply also to the offence of conspiracy to commit that offence.

`(9)Proceedings for an offence of conspiracy must not be commenced without the consent of the Director of Public Prosecutions. However, a person may be arrested for, charged with, or remanded in custody or on bail in connection with, an offence of conspiracy before the necessary consent has been given.
`(10) In any law of the Commonwealth:
(a)a reference to paragraph 86(1)(a) of this Act is taken to be a reference to subsection (1) of this section; and
(b)a reference to the application of subsection (1) of this section because of or by virtue of paragraph 86(1)(a) of this Act is taken to be a reference to subsection (1) of this section; and

PARA.TAB: (c)a reference to section 86A of this Act is taken to be a reference to subsection (2) of this section.'.".

SPEECH.PARA: I would say just quickly to Senator Ellison—and I thank other senators for contributing to this debate—that a number of specific drafting issues, as have been mentioned, have been identified by the Senate committee. Of course, the responses to those particular issues, I believe, were provided to the Senate committee when it was deliberating on this particular bill.

PARA.TAB: I do commend the Senate committee for its work on this bill. As has been mentioned, I believe that it is the beginning of a very interesting and new era in the development of the criminal law. It makes sense, I think, to seek uniformity in this area. It is pleasing to see that there is bipartisan support for such an initiative. It is also pleasing to see that that support comes from the highest level of government. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating), each premier and chief minister all are committed to the on-going development of a model criminal code. I think this is necessary, given the fact that the project is a long-term one aiming for completion in the year 2001. I think also it can be said that it is fitting that this parliament should provide a lead by being the first to commence this legislative process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to make a point in relation to this matter. Perhaps it is worth drawing the Senate's attention to 1.120 of the Senate committee's report. I think it encapsulates basically what Senator Ellison said but not completely what Senator Spindler said—because he has amendments. But the report says that in each area and most if not all other areas where concerns are raised there is a decision to be made involving a compromise. As Mr Andrew Menzies, whose work with the Gibbs committee began the process which culminated in the bill, observed about the achievement of a national uniform code—

SPEECH.PARA: and we hear the word `compromises' often, don't we—
`compromises have to be made by the various jurisdictions involved'. The committee report goes on to say:

The committee is satisfied that the Criminal Code Bill 1994 (and its cognate Crimes Amendment Bill 1994) provide a thorough, workable, logical and balanced compromise between competing legal policy views, and, perhaps more importantly, between the competing interests of the State and of the people, which lies at the heart of the criminal law.
It is on that basis that the committee came to the conclusion that the bill and the Crimes Amendment Bill should be supported. I just wanted to reinforce that.

PARA.TAB: But I want to make the point though that Senator Ellison was at the hearings in relation to this bill and he had a number of matters that he wanted to raise. We do not have in here—and this is a common practice—the minister who usually represents the attorney who, with the greatest respect to other ministers as hard as they try, has probably got a better chance of being able to keep the flow going. We have had another minister who probably has not been listening. He did not appear to be listening to what Senator Ellison was saying; no-one has offered an answer to any of the points he has raised.

It is not as though there is any bad will here. People are just trying to have a genuine debate, not get up and babble to the other wall and let it all fall on deaf ears—which does happen if the minister is only in here as the person rostered to sit in that seat and say nothing; if they know that we are going to agree, and just let people get up and say things. That is not an excuse for a debate. Although we are not going to agree with Senator Spindler's amendments—if he is going to move them—those matters have been canvassed.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not moving any amendments.

—I thought earlier there was a suggestion that you were moving some amendments in relation to what you were talking about, but you now say you are not. Nonetheless, Senator Spindler is still entitled to have some response to the point that he has made. Otherwise, one wonders why we have a debate on the bill at the committee stage. One can understand why ministers and relevant shadow ministers are not here for all the speeches during the second reading stage, but one wonders why we bother rostering a minister in here at all during the committee stage. If they are not going to listen and respond in any detailed way, the committee stage becomes a farce. This is not a criticism of you, Senator Cook, but it is a general practice that has begun to develop.

PARA.TAB: One could say that everyone has had their chance in the committee hearing. This bill did go to a Friday committee. No-one is looking to drag out this matter for a long and extended time—not at all. Just because a bill goes to a Friday hearing, it does not mean that there should not be a minister here who has some passing interest, however small—I a nano interest—in what senators have to say.

TALK.START.PARA: —One millionth of an interest.

—Yes, one millionth of an interest to respond to what Senator Spindler and Senator Ellison have said. They were at the hearings and obviously think there is something worth saying on this matter. I would appreciate the government making some response to those remarks.

PARA.TAB: We have to roster ourselves to be here. The opposition manages to get the relevant shadow minister here when the bill is on. Why can't the government manage to get the relevant minister or the representing minister here? What is the great difficulty in that? Surely it would enhance proper debate of these matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support what Senator Vanstone has said. I think that applies particularly to bills which have gone to a committee, have had detailed consideration and have had points arise which sometimes are of a technical but nevertheless extremely important nature. I would also like to put on the record that while the Democrats have considered amendments and while, as I have stated, we would have liked to have moved an amendment in one area, we have decided not to do so in the interests of achieving a criminal code that is uniform throughout Australia. Nevertheless, these concerns remain. We will be monitoring very carefully how these provisions turn out in practice.

PARA.TAB: Certainly it is important the point should be made that the minister at the table should be the minister who has been involved in detailed discussions and who has detailed knowledge of the issues. I join Senator Vanstone in requesting that the government might consider following that procedure on certain pieces of legislation in the future.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Cook) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: EVIDENCE BILL 1994EVIDENCE (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 7 November 1994, on motion by Senator Crowley:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Evidence Bill 1993 has been through a longer embryonic stage than, I think, even the criminal code has been through. Commentators all around Australia have been putting forward their views. The Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs some time ago—I cannot remember which month; Senator Cooney may be able to help me, but it was probably in August of last year—had hearings on the bill.

PARA.TAB: There is general agreement—not unanimous agreement—that we should try to codify the laws in relation to evidence. Some people disagree quite strongly with that, but far and away the majority say there should be this uniformity. I have no intention of repeating the speech I made during the second reading debate. We got to the stage where there was general, but not unanimous, agreement that we ought to codify the law of evidence.

There were some sticking points between New South Wales and the Commonwealth because New South Wales has its own bill. It seemed appropriate basically to let New South Wales go away and sort it out. There were a number of points of difference. It has taken a number of months to do that. Some of the comments made in relation to the criminal code can just as easily be made about this bill. While people might say that uniformity is a good idea and we should codify this bit of law or that bit of law, in the end it requires some sort of compromise.

By and large I think we have done very well. But there is one remaining area where the government is not prepared to move and where we think it should move, so we are prepared to move an amendment accordingly. I foreshadow that at the committee stage I will move the following amendments:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 118, page 50, line 39, omit "sole", substitute "dominant".
2.Clause 119, page 51, line 9, omit "sole", substitute "dominant".
3.Clause 120, page 51, line 22, omit "sole", substitute "dominant".

PARA.TAB: There was one aspect of the bill on which agreement between the Commonwealth and New South Wales was not able to be reached. The coalition view is that the New South Wales government has taken the right approach on the issue and the Commonwealth bill should be brought into line. Accordingly, these amendments will be moved at the committee stage.

New South Wales and the Commonwealth were unable to agree in relation to the test applicable to determine whether legal professional privilege attaches to a communication or document made or prepared for the purpose of obtaining legal advice or for the provision of legal advice. The issue is whether that purpose—that is, the obtaining or provision of legal advice—is the sole purpose or the dominant purpose of the communication or document.

The bill provides for the sole purpose test. The New South Wales bill provides for the dominant purpose test, which is more generous to the party seeking to claim the privilege. The common law sole purpose test was laid down by the High Court in the case of Grant v. Downs. In a subsequent consideration by the High Court in Waterford v. the Commonwealth, the impact of the test was diluted.

It is a question of interpretation whether the High Court in that case actually resiled from the sole purpose test. As I understand it, the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) is of the view that the sole purpose test represents the current common law position and should be incorporated in this bill. After significant consideration of the issue the Australian Law Reform Commission concluded that the sole purpose test was not workable and endorsed a dominant purpose test.

It is disappointing that agreement was unable to be reached in relation to this matter for the purpose of determining legal professional privilege. It appears that the sticking point was with the minister, who apparently has a very close interest in this particular aspect of the bill. He has stuck to his view that the sole purpose test is appropriate, at the expense, I might say, of consistency, and despite the recommendations of Australian Law Reform Commission. The result is that the High Court will be required to adjudicate on two different standards. The states, when contemplating the adoption of the model law, will be able to choose which standard to apply.

The failure of the minister to accede to the more widely accepted view shows a stubbornness that belies his claims for consistency elsewhere. The dominant purpose test is to be preferred, particularly given that the Law Reform Commission has endorsed the dominant purpose test and that the adoption of that test would result in consistency with the New South Wales bill. Accordingly, I foreshadow that we will be moving amendments to the Evidence Bill at the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Evidence Bill 1993 and the Evidence (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1994 are most important bills. That is a statement that most people would think was hyperbole, but it is not. I want to pay tribute to the people who have got the Evidence Bill to where it is now. As Senator Vanstone said, this bill has gone through a long, embryonic stage. I do not want to name too many people who have been involved in the preparation of this legislation because, in doing so, I will leave out those who should have been thanked, particularly those who worked on this bill early in its development.

PARA.TAB: But I think it is proper that I acknowledge certain people. One of those people, who has already spoken, is Senator Vanstone. She did a lot of work on this bill through the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, as did Senator Ellison and Senator Spindler, who is now the deputy chair of the committee. The ministers involved—the Attorney-General, Michael Lavarch, and the Minister for Justice, Duncan Kerr—have worked hard, as did Michael Duffy and Lionel Bowen before them.

As I look around the chamber, I notice Mr Geoff Bellamy, who perhaps more than most has borne the burden of getting the legislation to the stage where it is about to be passed. That ought to be acknowledged. I see with him Peter Meibusch who has been of great assistance to Mr Bellamy, as has Simon Lake, who was in the office of the Minister for Justice.

I would like to pick out someone who worked at the Law Reform Commission for years and years on the preparation of this bill. I am referring to Tim Smith, as he then was. He is now Mr Justice Smith. He is a very distinguished judge and the son of a very distinguished judge. He saw the importance of this legislation and worked long and hard to see it get to the point it is at now. I know it is of great joy to him that this bill is about to be passed. It is proper that someone in this chamber, in this parliament and in this country acknowledges the work that he has put into this legislation.

Evidence is very important. It sounds a very dry subject, but it is about fairness to all—no matter what their age, their health, their intellect, their personality, their education, their ability to speak English, their familiarity with court proceedings or their treatment prior to the commencement of those proceedings. It is particularly relevant in criminal trials.

A look through this bill shows that all those issues were addressed. A look at the law of evidence, which took many centuries to develop, shows that it is about that. Evidence is there to curb the exercise of arbitrary power and to see that a proper balance is maintained between the parties to a trial. Those great qualities of liberal democracy of which we speak are protected by the law of evidence.

It has been said that this bill will do much for micro-economic reform. I know that when people speak of micro-economic reform in this matter they are putting it as a secondary consideration to the main consideration, which is to do with fairness between people who come before the courts of this land.

As a digression, I will use as an illustration of how important evidence is the present debate, if it can be called that, around the House about people who gather timber for a living and those who want to protect the forests for posterity—the environmentalists. A major part of the dispute depends upon the state of the forests and what damage is or is not being done. That is very much an evidentiary issue. If the rules of evidence could be applied to the situation that prevails and the facts about what is going on in the forests could be established, a lot of heat would go out of the argument. That is an illustration of how the establishment of truth is very important.

Another point I want to raise before I sit down is this: the rules of evidence at times prevent the truth coming out in court. Facts that may be able to be established by a particular means are not established because of the rules of evidence. People say, `Isn't this ridiculous. The truth is frustrated by these rules of evidence.' That is a wrong analysis. Truth should not be gained at the sacrifice of fairness and justice.

I will quote something that I have quoted in here before; it needs quoting again and again. It is a quote from a decision by the Vice-Chancellor Sir Knight Bruce in 1846, which is almost 150 years ago, in a case called Pearse v Pearse. It was a civil case, not a criminal case. He had this to say:

The discovery and vindication and establishment of truth are main purposes certainly of the existence of Courts of Justice; still, for the obtaining of these objects, which, however valuable and important, cannot be usefully pursued without moderation, cannot be either usefully or creditably pursued unfairly or gained by unfair means, not every channel is or ought to be open to them. The practical inefficacy of torture is not, I suppose, the most weighty objection to that mode of examination, nor probably would the purpose of the mere disclosure of truth have been otherwise than advanced by a refusal on the part of the Lord Chancellor in 1815 to act against the solicitor, who, in the cause between Lord Cholmondeley and Lord Clinton, had acted or proposed to act in the manner which Lord Eldon thought it right to prohibit. Truth, like all other good things, may be loved unwisely—may be pursued too keenly—may cost too much. And surely the meanness and the mischief of prying into a man's confidential consultations with his legal adviser, the general evil of infusing reserve and dissimulation, uneasiness, and suspicion and fear, into those communications which must take place, and which, unless in a condition of perfect security, must take place uselessly or worse, are too great a price to pay for truth itself.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a great statement to remember in a period when the forces of law and order seem intent on overriding those great and traditional principles that have been inherent in the law for so long. Unfortunately I find myself more and more a conservative in this area, but I do think there are protections to be maintained and that the coming of the age of micro-economic reform and of economic rationalism should not be allowed to take away those great traditional rights that protect our liberty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats welcome the Evidence Bill 1994. Before I outline our position on it I would like to pay tribute to the speech just made by Senator Cooney. I pay tribute to his role as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs which he has chaired with great emphasis on the principles he has just outlined. It is important, as Senator Cooney said, in this age where economic rationalism is pushing us into adopting financial judgments and applying the financial slide rule to many decisions, that we protect the civil liberties and the freedoms of Australian citizens. I commend him for those statements and associate myself with them.

PARA.TAB: This bill is an important tool not just for lawyers but for the people of Australia. The aims of the bill are threefold: firstly, to provide a consistent system of evidence law for use in the Federal Court; secondly, to modernise and simplify what are in many ways excessively complex and outdated rules; and, thirdly, to establish the basis for what may eventually become a uniform code of evidence that will apply throughout all Australian jurisdictions.

The process of reform in this area began in November 1977 when the Senate's legal and constitutional committee recommended that `a review of the whole of evidence law should be undertaken by the Law Reform Commission with a view to producing a wholly comprehensive code of evidence based on concepts appropriate to the present day.' In 1987 the Law Reform Commission duly reported and four years later the governments of both New South Wales and the Commonwealth introduced evidence bills into their respective parliaments based largely on the Law Reform Commission's proposals. Eventually it was agreed that the New South Wales and Commonwealth bills would form the basis of a uniform law. This bill represents the Commonwealth contribution to the process.

I also pay tribute to Justice Smith and his role in bringing this process to fruition and to the present bill. He has been, as Senator Cooney said, extremely diligent and extremely forceful over the years to move the process ahead. I am sure he would be delighted that we have reached this stage. The case for an overhaul of the law of evidence was summed up in one submission to the Senate legal and constitutional affairs committee when Professor Mark Aronson observed:

SPEECH.PARA: In recent times the High Court had had to deliver judgment in three cases on the meaning of the hearsay rule, 10 cases on the meaning of and application of the similar facts rule, 12 cases on the complexities of corroboration law, and 17 cases on police evidence of an accused's confession.

Presently there is also the unsatisfactory situation whereby Commonwealth laws are interpreted subject to the different laws of evidence in different state jurisdictions. Although one would hope that it is extremely unlikely, it is therefore conceivable that a person could be convicted of a Commonwealth offence in one state but would not have been convicted had they been tried in another.

PARA.TAB: I now turn to some of the substantive features of the bill. Firstly, I wish to address the dominant purpose test as against the sole purpose test in the area of legal professional privilege, which is one of the main issues in contention and which was dealt with in some detail in the committee's deliberations. Currently the draft bill provides in clauses 118, 119 and 120 that, if a client of a lawyer or an unrepresented party objects, evidence cannot be given that would disclose confidential information that was brought into existence for the sole purpose of providing legal advice or for use in litigation. The rationale for the rule is that it encourages freedom of consultation between clients of lawyers and their legal advisers, or unrepresented parties and their advisers, and does not act as a disincentive for persons contemplating litigation to produce documents for use in that litigation.

The competing policy objective is that the court should not be restricted in terms of the documents it may call before it. This is obviously the position that the government has adopted. However, there is a serious weakness, I would submit, in the sole purpose test in so far as it is difficult to apply literally without destroying the client's privilege. As Mr Justice Smith explained to the Senate committee, a solicitor's file comes into existence not only for the purpose of giving legal advice; it is also used by the solicitor as a record of work done in part for the purpose of charging the client. The Australian Law Reform Commission also concluded after extensive consultation:

SPEECH.PARA: The sole purpose test was not workable. There was a universal acceptance of the dominant purpose test as a test that struck the appropriate balance.

The Democrats will therefore be supporting the use of the dominant purpose test rather than the sole purpose test with respect to clauses 118, 119 and 120. In other words, we will be supporting the coalition's amendments.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats will also be proposing a number of amendments during the committee stage. I will briefly outline those now. They were in fact tabled in the committee's interim report in June 1994, where we gave notice of these amendments after considerable consultation with the minister's office. The first of the Democrat amendments is to ensure that police officers would be able to give evidence in chief on behalf of the prosecution by reading into evidence a prior written statement only where the defence consents to this approach. This amendment adopted a proposal put before the committee by the Australian Council for Civil Liberties and one that was adopted by Mr justice Smith. The minister responded by noting that the defence would generally refuse to consent to the police reading into evidence the prior written statement and that the prosecution would see no benefit in serving the statement on the defence if the police officer could not then use it.

However, the main benefit of this amendment is to facilitate the provision of routine evidence by police officers. Where that evidence is not routine—for example, identification evidence—the defence should have the right to require that the evidence be given in full. Further, the minister's reasoning ignores the fact that the police will still be able to use the statement to refresh their memory.

The second and third amendments would provide that a witness cannot be required by a court to give evidence that incriminates that witness where, as a result, harm might be caused or there was a likelihood that the evidence would be unreliable. The minister's response to that is that these amendments appear to impose conflicting obligations on the court and place those who might give self-incriminating testimony in a more privileged position than other witnesses. However, the bill at present simply refers to the test of the interests of justice. This test was felt, even by judges, to be vague and arbitrary in its application. The Democrat amendments simply provide the court with better guidance and with some criteria for the application of the test.

The fourth amendment would ensure that both gay and heterosexual couples are covered by the definition of `de facto spouse'. The minister seems to suggest that this would create a legal status similar to marriage. However, what the amendment seeks to produce is equality between homosexual and heterosexual de facto couples. I believe this is a principle that should be included in all legislation that comes before the Senate.

The fifth amendment we are proposing relates to the definition of `parent' and includes in the definition `the person with whom the child is living as if the child were a member of the person's family'. We understand that this amendment may gain the support of the government.

Finally, I wish to advert to a number of criticisms of the bill made by outside bodies which have so far not been addressed by the government. For instance, the Law Society of New South Wales argued before the committee, firstly, that improperly obtained evidence should be automatically inadmissible rather than the court having a discretion to exclude evidence and, secondly, that the bill should include a provision making it mandatory that an interpreter be provided for an accused person who is not sufficiently conversant in English.

In particular, I lend strong support to the second of these recommendations, while leaving the first one open as to its value and urgency. I have written to the Attorney-General asking for his response to both of those points but, as of this morning, I had not received a response from the Attorney-General's office. I rather regret that because, as I said, in particular the provision which I think would be one of simple justice—that is, that an interpreter be provided on a mandatory basis where a person is not sufficiently conversant in English to follow proceedings—I would have thought the government should have considered favourably and urgently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation before the Senate has been some 16 years in the making. It has really been around for some time, as the government points out. I think it was also examined thoroughly by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I compliment the work done by the secretariat and my colleagues on that committee and the chairmanship of Senator Cooney.

PARA.TAB: The committee produced an interim report on the Evidence Bill. It raised in that interim report some 38 concerns touching on a variety of matters. By way of example, one issue which concerned me was whether clause 20, which permits comment on failure to give evidence on behalf of the defence, really destroyed the right to silence and whether it effectively cast a reverse onus of proof on the accused by causing the accused to have to call or give evidence. That was just one of the concerns. The others were perhaps of a lesser nature. I single out that one as an example of some of the issues that were raised by the committee.

As a result of that interim report, the Federal Government liaised with the New South Wales government, which is introducing a similar bill. The committee also recommended, in addition to this liaison between the two governments, that there be a period of at least six months between the passing of the bill and its coming into operation to enable the legal community to familiarise itself with the bill's operation. I am pleased to note that originally this was to come into operation on 1 January this year and that the government has replaced that with 18 April this year.

I note that the government agrees in principle with the recommendation made by the committee that there be a panel to monitor this legislation and that the panel comprise representatives of the relevant courts, legal practitioners and the Attorney-General's Department. I cannot stress enough the importance of such monitoring of this proposed legislation and that, furthermore, such monitoring should be the subject of examination in the future by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

This is a most important piece of legislation. I know I said that about the Criminal Code Bill that we dealt with earlier this morning, but when you combine the Evidence Bill with the Criminal Code Bill you really cover the ambit of criminal law and law enforcement where the state says to an individual, `You are guilty and you will be punished. The full force of the law will be visited upon you.' So how you deal with evidence in a criminal matter, where the individual is innocent until proven guilty by the state, is extremely important.

Similarly, this bill applies to civil actions. When citizens take each other to court, they should be able to rely on the judicial process as being fair, an orderly and proper process whereby they can seek a remedy. The rules of evidence are precisely the machinery of the courts. How the courts deal with evidence is absolutely crucial. Frequent concern is being expressed at present about the way in which evidence is treated. You do not have to look any further than the O. J. Simpson trial in the United States, where there has been much argument over what the prosecution has done with evidence. After all, evidence is what is used or relied upon in making a determination when the court comes to try an issue.

This bill is extremely important. The regulation of how we treat facts and articles, which can give rise to a verdict of guilt, is extremely important. There was a feeling that there should be a codification of the laws of evidence for the Commonwealth and that in due course the states would follow suit. With the passage of this bill and the New South Wales legislation, there will be great uniformity between the state of New South Wales and the Commonwealth in the federal jurisdiction. I think that is no bad thing and is desirable. Nonetheless, a subject like this must be approached with caution and care, and should be monitored. I know the government agrees in principle with the committee's suggestion, but I cannot stress enough how important that is because this legislation is innovative and is breaking new ground. Over the years we have

SPEECH.PARA: relied on common law to build up rules as to how the courts try issues.

PARA.TAB: One such rule that has been built up over the years is hearsay. It is a simple thing. Somebody who goes to court cannot give evidence of what another person has said because, quite obviously, that could give rise to grave injustice. If I went into the witness box and said, `I know that to be a fact because someone told me it was a fact,' that would be a very shaky foundation on which to base any conclusion about my day-to-day dealings with my fellow citizens. So over the years the common law built up the rule against hearsay.

The rules of evidence have been built up and distilled through the affairs of human beings over hundreds of years. This bill attempts to codify the law of evidence for the Commonwealth. I know that it has been denied in some circumstances that this is a code, but I must say that it does purport to cover greatly the area of evidence.

I want to address in particular the amendment proposed by Senator Vanstone, and I applaud it. It deals with the sole purpose test for legal privilege. I must say that it has been another principle which has developed over the years. If someone goes to see their lawyer, they can do so without fear or favour. They can do so in full confidence, knowing that what they say to their lawyer is privileged. What they say to their lawyer is between themselves and their lawyer. That is an essential principle in the administration of justice in this country.

We have a system of natural justice where someone is allowed to be represented. It is a right. Accompanying that right is the right to have your communications with your lawyer privileged. You do not have to incriminate yourself in a prosecution. You do not have to put yourself over the barrel, so to speak; you can simply say nothing, and that is your right to silence. But if you do say anything, it will be used in evidence against you.

In conducting your defence, you should have the ability to seek legal advice in a privileged and confidential environment so that you can then make your decision whether you wish to say anything or whether you wish to maintain your right to silence, or how you conduct your defence generally. It would be a grave injustice if the state were able to trample upon that right to privilege. Quite frankly, the sole purpose test is insufficient to protect this great principle that is so basic to our legal system. The committee's report stated that the traditional rationale for privilege is said to be that it promotes the better administration of justice. I believe it does.

The problem with the sole purpose test is that it is too restrictive. It says that something is privileged if the communication is given for the sole purpose of legal advice or for communication between a client and lawyer. That means that the communication must be just for that purpose and nothing else. That is too restrictive because, in some instances, you might be consulting with your lawyer and, in the course of that communication, something else is involved—some extraneous matter—but it is still tied up with your communication, which is privileged. The sole purpose test could result in that communication then being open to inspection because it could be said that that was not really the sole purpose of the communication. The sole purpose was not just for legal advice; there was this other extraneous matter.

That is why the dominant purpose test is the best one. That test asks: was the dominant purpose of your communication with your lawyer for legal advice on the matter? If the dominant purpose was, then it should be protected. So if there is some extraneous matter involved, then so be it; but as long as the dominant aspect of your communication is for the purpose of legal advice, then it should be protected.

His Honour Mr Justice Smith, who worked so hard on this legislation, I might add—I commend him for his work—said that the dominant purpose test would be a better one to be applied. That view was supported by the Law Society of New South Wales and the Australian Law Reform Commission. I think that really does sum it up. With those bodies supporting it, you really do not go much further than that. I think Senator Vanstone's amendment is a laudable one and I will be supporting it at the committee stage.

Finally, it is essential that the legal community comes to terms with the evidence bills as soon as possible. It will be a great change for the practice of law in this country and I urge the government to do everything possible to alert the legal community as to this impending change and to alert the community at large also. Right now there are millions of Australians going about their daily business and none of them would realise that the laws of evidence are about to be encapsulated in these bills—nor would they really care, I suppose, until they have cause to go to court or unless they are prosecuted by the state. Nonetheless, I do believe that the dissemination of knowledge on this aspect is indeed very important. It strikes at the basic rights of citizenship; that is, how a citizen is tried in a court of law. You cannot get anything more important than that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Evidence Bill 1993 and the Evidence (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1994. It is the resumption of the second reading debate and Senators Vanstone, Cooney, Spindler and Ellison, representing three of the parties in this chamber, have addressed themselves in the second reading debate to the bills. It is for me on behalf of the government to reply and comment on the debate that has been put forward.

PARA.TAB: The government acknowledges the commitment of all those involved in bringing these bills before the parliament, of the participants in the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee and of those that have worked through these issues, as Senator Ellison has observed, over the long time that it has taken for the gestation of these bills. I say on behalf of the government that we appreciate their effort and acknowledge it as significant. In particular, the government recognises and appreciates, while not necessarily always agreeing with, the constructive tone of debate on the Senate committee. It recognises in particular the role of Senator Vanstone in that and the role of Senator Cooney as committee chairman.

It is fair to say that we are all constructively wrestling with what is the best outcome for an important piece of legislation in the law. The Evidence Act is fundamental to justice and any approach other than the constructive one would have been self-defeating. There has been a constructive approach. It ought to be acknowledged and the government does so.

There is in essence a large degree of common view between us about these bills. Indeed, I think it was Mr Reith in the House of Representatives who indicated that the coalition will not oppose the bills and went on then to point out a difference that nonetheless exists. That difference has again appeared in this chamber through the advocacy of Senator Vanstone. We have had foreshadowed from the opposition an amendment on the basis of that.

When Senator Spindler addressed the chamber he indicated that, speaking for his party, the Australian Democrats would support the coalition amendment foreshadowed by Senator Vanstone. I observe pithily, on behalf of the government, that that does not necessarily mean that the numbers are here to carry it but, in all probability, they are. Nonetheless, the government will oppose those views for the purpose of expressing its views on the amendment even though the amendment may be carried.

Additionally, the government itself has some minor technical amendments which have now been circulated in the chamber. I understand there is an acceptance that these are technical amendments. There are two sets of amendments. My understanding is that there is no opposition to those in the chamber. They clean up and improve the consequential implications of the bill.

That leaves me with a range of amendments to be moved by the Australian Democrats. The news on this range of Democrat amendments from the government's point of view is not so good as it may have been on some of the others I have commented on. As far as the Democrat amendments are concerned, there are five amendments to be moved. The government does not accept four of them. We will oppose amendments Nos 1 to 4. We also do not accept amendment No. 5 in the form as circulated which is, as I understand it, the form in which it is intended to be moved.

Although this matter is probably more appropriate for the committee stage, I indicate now to give maximum notice that if the word `the' before the word `child' in that sentence were replaced with the word `a' then the government would accept it. In other words, if the sentence read `the person with whom a child is living' rather than `the person with whom the child is living', the government would accept it. I observe that now so Senator Spindler may have maximum notice of what my position might be when the time comes. He might wish then to comment in introducing his amendment.

One of the other things I should comment on is that I caught in the remarks of Senator Spindler a reference to the need for the provision of interpreters. I understood the position he was putting to be a quite reasonable one, that if a person in a court has a need for interpretation then interpretation should be supplied. Section 30 of the Evidence Bill is headed `Interpreters' and reads:

SPEECH.PARA: A witness may give evidence about a fact through an interpreter unless the witness can understand and speak the English language sufficiently to enable the witness to understand, and to make an adequate reply to, questions that may be put about the fact.

Our understanding of that clause is that it meets the concern that Senator Spindler has raised, that in the event of a witness requiring an interpreter, an interpreter would be available. I make that observation since Senator Spindler raised this issue.

PARA.TAB: While it is probably best that anything I might say about the coalition's foreshadowed amendment to be moved by Senator Vanstone be confined to the committee stage, it would be wrong of me to not acknowledge the considered observations of Senator Ellison on this. The dispute here is not one of galactic magnitude—

TALK.START.PARA: —Politics.

—or politics. It is a difference of opinion. I think it ought to be acknowledged that the opinion on one side can be given considerable respect, as can the opinion on the other side, and whichever of the sides you come down on is understandable and reasonable.

PARA.TAB: Nonetheless, the government is required to take a point of view. Our point of view is that here the sole test rather than the dominant test for legal and professional privilege is the appropriate one. When we come to the amendment that I am certain Senator Vanstone will be moving, I will explain the government's reasons for that.

We recognise and acknowledge the cogency of the arguments that have been put forward by Senator Ellison and we thank him for them. It is good to have them on the record in that way. I am sure that they will be added to by Senator Vanstone shortly.

However, we do not agree on this point. We will be commending to the Senate the sole test rather than the dominant test. Therefore, I reiterate my thanks to all who have participated in this debate, and I commend the bills to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I owe the minister's office an apology. I mentioned in my comments that we had not received an answer from the minister. In fact, apparently a letter, dated 31 January, reached my office but it did not reach my desk. That might explain my comments on that issue, and I put on record my apology for that oversight.

PARA.TAB: On the substantive question about interpreters in section 30 in the bill, the clause does not satisfy our concern because, as I understand the wording of the clause, it does not make it mandatory to provide interpreters. It states:
A witness may give evidence about a fact through an interpreter unless the witness can understand and speak the English language . . .

SPEECH.PARA: But who decides? Does it necessarily follow that, say, court proceedings will be held up until an interpreter is available? We would favour a much stronger wording making it clearly mandatory that an interpreter must be available at the time.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: EVIDENCE BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: The bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

I also draw to the attention of honourable senators the amendment that has just recently been circularised, the object of which would be to negate, in effect, those provisions of this bill which would allow a court to abrogate the right of a spouse not to be compelled to give evidence against his or her partner.

PARA.TAB: I rise at this point because I was not aware that the Evidence Bill was going to be discussed this week. The Evidence Bill was not on the forward program that I received. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

At a whips' meeting yesterday, it was agreed that we should keep the government business flowing in the Senate. I apologise to you for the short notice. So you are not Robinson Crusoe. I seek leave to move the government's amendments together.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

".evidence relevant for a non-hearsay purpose (section 60);".

TALK.START.PARA: —For the reasons previously stated, the Australian Democrats will be supporting the amendments. We believe that legal professional privilege is an important area of the law and the protection must be preserved.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 33, page 14, line 6, subclause (1) after "may", insert ", with the consent of the defence,".
The amendment seeks to ensure that police officers may read into evidence a prior written statement only where the defence consents to this approach.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes the Australian Democrats' amendment No. 1.

—To save repeating myself, I indicate that the remarks I will make now in debating Senator Spindler's amendments apply equally to Senator Harradine's amendment. This legislation has had a very extensive gestation period. Every man and his dog has had the opportunity to express a view at one stage or another. There is definitely a benefit, in a cost of justice sense, in trying to get uniformity between the states and the Commonwealth. Concessions have to be made on both sides.

PARA.TAB: We have made it clear for some time and well in advance that we thought that the dominant purpose test was worth holding out for. We believe that would put the Commonwealth in uniformity with New South Wales. I make no criticism of what Senator Harradine has had to say in this respect—and that also applies to Senator Spindler. We have come this far and we have got to the point where we have some uniformity with New South Wales. For that reason, it is not considered appropriate at the last minute to make other changes that will take us out of kilter with New South Wales; otherwise everything we did last year was a waste of time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take mild exception to what has just been said. Senator Vanstone should know that this is not a last minute thing, unless she has not read the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I raised this matter with Minister Lavarch. I raised the matter with the committee. I even wrote a qualifying comment in the report, as did Senator Spindler. It is not a last minute thing at all. I explained, just a moment ago, why the actual wording of the amendment was somewhat of a last minute effort. As I understood it, the Evidence Bill was not going to be discussed this week.
—Me too; I agree.

—Senator Vanstone is acknowledging that she also thought that it would not be discussed this week. I apologise that you have not actually seen the amendment. The amendment simply gives effect to the qualifying comment that I made. Before you rule me out of order, Madam Chair, I felt that I should rise on this particular occasion to clarify the point made by Senator Vanstone. At a later date I hope I will advance eminently acceptable reasons why my amendment should be adopted.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Clause 128, page 55, line 11, subclause (5), omit "If the court", substitute "Subject to subsection (5A), if the court".
3.Clause 128, page 55, after subclause (5), insert the following subclause:
"(5A) A court must not require a witness to give evidence under this section if the court considers that it would not be desirable to do so having regard to:

TAB.TAB: (a)the harm that might be caused to the witness; and
(b)the likelihood that the evidence to be given would be unreliable.".

SPEECH.PARA: We believe a witness should not be required by a court to give evidence where, as a result, harm might be caused or there is a likelihood that the evidence could be unreliable. We believe that the court should be required to address its collective mind to those factors rather than simply to a fairly general interest of justice test which is somewhat vague.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes these amendments.

—I take the opportunity to put Senator Harradine's mind at rest. I was at pains to say that I was not being critical of Senator Harradine. These issues, including the ones he has raised, have been around for a long time. I make the point that, from our point of view, we have done the work. We have come to our position on what we will agree to and what we will not. We are not going to change our mind at the last minute on other issues. I was not being critical of you in the sense of coming in here at the last minute. We are all in here at the last minute, Senator Harradine. It is a scheduling problem. I just want to affirm that, when I said that I was not wanting to be critical of you, that is exactly what I meant. I was simply wanting to make the point that we have come the distance that we are going to come and we are not going to change that position at the last minute.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 4.Dictionary, page 93, Part 1—Definitions, omit definition of "de facto spouse", substitute the following definition:

PARA.TAB: "de facto spouse:

TAB.TAB: (a)of a man, means a person who is living with the man as his partner on a genuine domestic basis although not married to him; and
(b)of a woman, means a person who is living with the woman as her partner on a genuine domestic basis although not married to her;".

SPEECH.PARA: That amendment seeks to ensure that the law is applied equally to homosexual de facto couples as it is to heterosexual de facto couples. I believe that principle should be incorporated progressively in all pieces of legislation. I commend the amendment to the chamber.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes the amendment moved by Senator Spindler. We believe that this bill is not the appropriate place to, for the first time, create a legal status similar to marriage for partners in a homosexual relationship. The question of the legal status of a homosexual relationship is important and complex. It should not be approached on an ad hoc basis.
