If the status of such relationships is to be generally recognised, issues which will need to be addressed are the extent to which it is reasonable to confer the benefits of such recognition in particular areas without also addressing disadvantages which would result in other areas. Pension entitlements is one of these areas.

PARA.TAB: The Evidence Bill is intended to service a model for uniform evidence laws for possible adoption by the states and territories. It would be unfortunate if the issues of evidence law reform with which this bill is concerned were to be sidetracked by introducing a social issue. I emphasise that the government's view about equal rights, sexual discrimination and the rights of homosexuals in the community is very well known and has been debated at some length in this place in recent times. We believe that this bill is not the place where those issues should be dealt with on an ad hoc basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his comments and, in particular, the statements which indicate that the government would support such amendments in pieces of legislation which specifically deal with such issues. I still believe that the government is letting slip by an opportunity which should have been taken. But I am pleased that we have an assurance that the government will support such amendments when they are placed before the Senate as amendments to legislation, where the government would see that the subject matter is in consonance with the amendment moved.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 5.Dictionary, page 100, Part 2—Other Expressions, clause 10, at the end of subclause (2), add the following word and paragraph:

PARA.TAB: "or (c)The person with whom a child is living as if the child were a member of the person's family.".

SPEECH.PARA: I have previously averted to the reasons for the amendment. I understand that the government is prepared to support it in its amended form. I commend the amendment to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that, with that minor adjustment to Senator Spindler's amendment, we will now support it.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1Clause 18, page 9, subclause (6), line 18, omit "A person", substitute "Subject to section 18A, a person".
2After clause 18, page 10, insert the following clause:

TAB.EMPHASIS: Spouse may object to giving evidence

PARA.TAB: "18A. If the spouse of a defendant in a proceeding objects to giving evidence or giving evidence of a marital communication the spouse must not be required to give the evidence.".

SPEECH.PARA: These are very important amendments. I do not think we should doubt their importance. There are two aspects of the bill which these amendments attempt to address: compelling spouses to testify against each other in all civil or criminal matters where the court thinks fit; and the abolition of the right not to be forced to incriminate oneself with regard to bodies corporate.

PARA.TAB: The particular matter that I am addressing is the provision in this bill which compels spouses to testify against each other in all criminal or civil matters where the court thinks fit. I would find it extraordinary if the government did not realise the implications of pressing on with this matter, because it is common for lawyers to talk of marital privilege. I suspect that most people would regard it as a basic right that a person's spouse should not be compelled to become a state informer, because that is precisely what is happening in this legislation. People who are interested in human rights should listen, because in this legislation they are compelling a spouse to divulge confidences in the nature of a state informer.
We all know what has occurred in various totalitarian countries where spouses and other family members have been encouraged to dob in their family members, to dob in their spouses and then forced—

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't compare Australia to those countries, Senator. Goodness me!

—You can now, because in this legislation you are departing from a very important principle. You are departing from the principle that marriage should have the favour of the law, that communications between husband and wife are sacrosanct and that they should not be compelled by the state to give evidence against each other in respect of all civil or criminal matters.

PARA.TAB: `If the court thinks fit.' What if the spouse does not think fit? What if the spouse has a very real concern about being forced to dob in and testify against her husband or where the husband is being forced to testify against his wife? That is what you are doing here. Get up and deny that. Senator Schacht is shaking his head because he does not know that is in there. He has come in here, as I have, not prepared to debate this matter this week. But that is in there. Do not shake your head, Minister, it is in there.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you can't compare us to an authoritarian country which has no established process on human rights and the rights of the individual, Senator. That is what I was shaking my head at.

—So you do admit that this bill compels a husband to give evidence against his wife, to divulge confidence in the marital state to the court. That is what it does. I am not alone in my objection to this. I refer to a letter that was received by me from the Law Society of New South Wales. I will read the relevant part to the committee:

SPEECH.PARA: Part 2: Compellability of spouses and others in criminal proceedings. Clause 18, New South Wales clause 17, permits the court to override the objection of a spouse, a de facto spouse, a parent or child of a defendant and compel that person to give evidence against the accused unless there is a likelihood of harm being caused to the person or the relationship between the person and the defendant and the nature of the harm outweighs the desirability of having the evidence given.

The Law Society submits that the special relationship which exists between spouses and de facto spouses is such that except for the exceptions contained in clause 19, which is New South Wales clause 18, no spouse or de facto spouse of a defendant should ever be compelled to give evidence against the defendant. The confidentiality and trust that exists between spouses and de facto spouses should only be eroded in exceptional circumstances such as in domestic violence or child abuse, as is contained in clause 19 and New South Wales clause 18. So the Law Society is also very concerned about this obviously because of its importance in the administration of justice and fairness in Australia.

PARA.TAB: I am very uneasy about this matter. I believe the Senate has the responsibility and, indeed, the obligation to uphold the rights of individuals within the community. Here is our opportunity to uphold the rights of the individual. Here is our opportunity to reinforce the principle that marriage should enjoy the favour of the law. If the Senate goes ahead with this, in my view it will be doing so in contradiction of those two major principles.
I commend the amendment to the Senate. The amendment states:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Spouse may object to giving evidence

SPEECH.PARA: "18A. If the spouse of a defendant in a proceeding objects to giving evidence or giving evidence of a marital communication the spouse must not be required to give the evidence.".

That is the situation. Apart from the exceptions that are contained in clause 17 of the New South Wales legislation—incest, violence and so forth—this is providing the protection that spouses have always had.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine has raised an extremely important issue. He did raise it, as he said, before the committee so the government and everyone concerned had plenty of notice of the issue that he would raise. We have given it long and hard consideration. The distinction here is not about spouses having absolutely no protection in court proceedings for their communications but whether it is absolute protection, absolute privilege or qualified privilege.

PARA.TAB: In deciding by a whisker not to support Senator Harradine's amendments, we have given careful consideration to clause 18 and to the various factors that the court must take into consideration when it decides whether or not spousal communication should have protection. It may be useful to read some of those into the record. First of all, the person must have been aware of the communication and the court must hear and determine any objection to that communication being heard in court in the absence of a jury. So there is some protection in the process.

The court must take into account in making its decision whether there is a likelihood that harm would or might be caused, whether directly or indirectly, to the person or—and I feel that is an important qualification—to the relationship between the person and the defendant. I believe that gives some protection to the marriage relationship if the person is to give that particular evidence.

Further, the court must take into account the following: the nature and gravity of the offence; the substance and importance of any evidence that the person might give and the weight that is likely to be attached to it; whether any other evidence concerning the matters is reasonably available to the prosecutor—the implication being if that evidence can be obtained in other ways then clearly it would not be thought fair for the court to compel it from a spouse; the nature of the relationship between the defendant and the person; and whether in giving the evidence the person would have to disclose matter that was received by the person in confidence from the defendant.

As far as is possible this section gives the court a range of criteria which it must consider when deciding in a particular case whether it should infringe the principle that communications between spouses should be confidential. On balance, and having given consideration to this matter in its entirety, I feel that the provisions in the bill strike a proper balance between, on the one hand, the interests of justice and fair court proceedings and, on the other hand, the importance to protect the relationship between spouses.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes the amendments moved by Senator Harradine. I very much agree with the remarks made by Senator Spindler. On behalf of the government I would like to respond to a couple of points put on the record relating to Senator Harradine's amendments, particularly amendments 2 and 3, which are the substance of the amendments.
—It is only 1 and 2.
—Senator Harradine will have to excuse me as, in anticipation, part of my response covers 3.
—I wasn't going to move it.
—You weren't going to move it?
—I am tossing up whether to move it.

—We will be very cooperative if you do not wish to move it. In Victoria and South Australia a spouse of the accused is compellable in a criminal trial but enjoys a discretionary privilege in terms very similar to those proposed by the bill. In both states a court has a discretion to exempt such a spouse from giving evidence for the prosecution where there is a likelihood of damage or harm to his or her relationship with the accused. A court is required in both states to balance that likelihood against the importance of obtaining the spouse's evidence in a particular trial. Where a spouse cannot be compelled to give evidence, he or she of course can refuse to give evidence regardless of the state of his or her relationship with the accused.

PARA.TAB: Senator Harradine, in his remarks, talked about `informers'. He used that term, which is an emotive one. I state very firmly on behalf of the government that this bill does not compel anyone to become an informer. It is only concerned with the giving of evidence in court proceedings. It is up to individuals themselves, including spouses of persons engaged in criminal activity, whether they provide information to investigative agencies. We very strongly refute any suggestion that this bill compels anybody to become an informer. Particularly in Australia there has always been some cultural aversion to the nature of the term `informer'.

We believe clause 18 in particular provides a balanced test for dealing with evidence by spouses. It was recommended by the Law Reform Commission, and it enables the court to take into account the actual state of the relationship between spouses. We believe the amendments moved by Senator Harradine are too inflexible.

Seeing Senator Harradine is still making up his mind about whether he will move amendment 3, I conclude by mentioning other remarks Senator Harradine made. He quite rightly talked about the interest in this chamber in human rights. Many senators on all sides of the chamber have had a long interest in human rights, which is only an appropriate course. Senator Harradine gave the impression that, if this bill is carried without his amendments, situations would then apply in Australia as would apply in other countries that have a long history of unfortunate human rights abuses. I refute that very strongly. I think the due processes this country has in favour of the individual in legal proceedings overwhelmingly would prevent that and diminish the concerns that he raised.

I point out that I, like you, Senator Harradine, have served on the human rights subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade of this parliament, have made reports and have shown a particular interest. I do not deny the fact that you have raised in this chamber issues involving human rights abuses in many facets in many other countries. But I also emphasise to you that it is drawing a very long bow to suggest that this bill would in any way align Australia with the situations that now apply unfortunately in those other countries. You know as well as I do those other countries which you mentioned do not have the established due processes of the law that we have in this country and, above all else, do not have the cultural history that this country has. The right of the individual in all aspects of human rights and legal rights is so well established that no one piece of legislation can take away the rights of people to have due process and be legally protected from unfair actions by the state or by agencies. So we reject your amendments and ask the chamber to reject them as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course Australia has a different judicial system and a history of protection of persons on the basis that they are innocent until proved guilty. I acknowledge that, minister. There is no problem about that. What I said was that we all know of those totalitarian countries which compel spouses to become state informants, whether that is before the courts or to the police or wherever. That is a matter of fact. What we have—and I would like to know why this has occurred—is legislation that will change the situation. For example, in my state of Tasmania, at the moment spouses are not compelled to give evidence against each other. You say that this will affect persons who engage in criminal activity. Who says that they are engaged in criminal activity?
—The court will determine that.

—Just a moment. They are innocent until they are proved guilty. The threshold matter that you have to deal with is the question: why are you extending this provision that is in only two states to the rest of Australia? Why are you extending it to New South Wales? Why are you extending it to Tasmania? Why are you extending it to Western Australia, for example? Why are you extending it to Queensland?

PARA.TAB: There are now only two states that have provisions such as these. The common law and most legislatures have traditionally provided that a spouse is either not a competent witness or not a compellable witness against a person. For example, under the imperial criminal Evidence Act 1898 the wife or husband of the accused could not be called as a witness except upon the accused's application. Statutory exceptions to this principle have arisen. We have the statutory exceptions to the principle and they are contained in clause 19 of this legislation.

I just remind the minister and the chamber that, in contrast, he talked about the recommendations of the Law Reform Commission. A lot of things are done for uniformity's sake without the implications being looked at. In contrast to the Law Reform Commission's recommendations, I prefer the view enunciated in the 1963 edition of Phipson on Evidence that spouses should not be compellable and marital communications protected `in order to ensure that unlimited confidence between husband and wife upon which happiness of human life and peace of families depend'. That is quaint language, but it is still relevant now. What I believe you are doing—and I will not say anything more on this because, obviously, I do not have the numbers; but I think I will be proved right, unfortunately—is undermining the very important principles that marriage should enjoy the favours of the law and that marital communications should not be made to be compellable evidence.
Amendments negatived.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: EVIDENCE (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: The bill.
Amendment (by Senator Schacht) proposed:
Clause 3, page 3, subclause (2), line 15, omit "1 January 1995", substitute "18 April 1995".

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the amendment means that the profession now has all of February, all of March and 18 days in April to adjust to these changes. Every speaker in this place has pointed out how long this bill has taken to come together. Most members of the profession who are engaged in litigious matters that will be affected by this legislation have taken some interest in it. As I recall, when the committee had its hearing on this—I might be wrong, but I think not—we were told that a draft had been distributed through CCH. That might be the case.
—I was just informed that it was distributed and published through Butterworths.

—Yes. People who are interested in this area and who rely on their knowledge of it to earn their income are fully aware of what is coming up. So they could be expected to be watching when this bill is passed and to acquaint themselves with the differences between what has been distributed by Butterworths and what we end up with. That should not be too hard for people to do, given a period of time.

PARA.TAB: Originally, the expectation was that the profession would have six months between the passage of the bill and its coming into effect. But the delays have meant that the original starting date, which was to be 1 January this year, has now passed; so we need a new starting date, and we have picked 18 April. The reason we have picked 18 April apparently is that it is Easter. That is not because we are into celebratory functions or whatever, but because that is a break in the court hearings. What about the Queen's Birthday long weekend? That is another break.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are republicans over here.

—You might be, but it has nothing to do with whether we are republicans or not; it is a question of giving the profession time to isolate those minor differences that we may have made. A minor difference to you and me might mean a very substantial difference in the presentation of a matter. I am not arguing for the legal profession but for their clients, so that the legal profession has time to get up to speed with this and represent their clients as efficiently as possible. I am not at all sure that a couple of months and 18 days is enough.
—Are you moving an amendment for that date?

—I want you to respond to why you think it is enough. From discussions held earlier this morning I am advised that the department is of the view that the profession likes to get a lot of its cases out of the way by the middle of the year and so the best guess for the best break is Easter rather than the Queen's birthday long weekend. That may be true, but I give an example of where things done too quickly without adequate advice to the profession can cost people.

PARA.TAB: The example, which I think is a good analogy, is that of the launch yesterday of a new divorce application kit. There is a new form to be used by unrepresented and represented clients. It is a sort of tick-a-box form. The suggestion is that the form is going to be much simpler. If it turns out to be that way, we obviously welcome it. The production of this kit, I think, is one of the first signs that the work of the family law committee, promoted by Senator Brownhill and worked on by Senator Reid, Senator Spindler and others in the other place, is starting to bear fruit. I approve of easier and simpler forms. I approve of forms for Family Court or any other court users that mean people can use them without having to go and pay solicitors.

I do not in any way want to criticise the introduction of the form itself. I go to the timing, however. The profession in my state got letters dated 15 or 16 January stating that on 1 February the family law court would be changing its divorce application form and they were provided with the new one. The letter was kind enough to say that forms produced by law stationers or ones that complied appropriately could be used.

But here is the trick. The family law court has had its wordprocessing or database system changed. You may have filled in an old form. You may be from the country; a lot of people live in regional Australia. Not many people go and get a divorce application, fill it out and file it. They go away and think about it. It is a big step; it is an end to the marriage they thought was going to be wonderful. You may have got the form two weeks ago and you go back today as an unrepresented client and find the court saying that it cannot take it. Why can it not take it? Because it has had its computer system changed and now it needs the tick-a-box form. The old form will not do.

So there is significant cost to any number of unrepresented clients who had taken the old form and did not know about the new form. They might not have been watching telly last night. This might go on for months before people realise that they are trying to lodge an outdated form.

People might say, `Who cares if the profession is disrupted?' I do not suppose anybody on the other side does, but their clients care if they are disrupted and the cost is increased. As I understand it, most of the forms in the Family Court are available on disk. But this has been rushed for convenience, like I suspect this bill is—let's pick Easter rather than the Queen's birthday weekend—so this new divorce kit is not available on disk. What does that mean if you go off to a small practice in the country or a big city firm with a big family law practice in it? It means they get out the typewriter—cross, tick, cross, tick. We are back to 1970s technology.

The Family Court had extensive negotiations about the new form to try to make it better. That is what we have done here. We have had extensive negotiations over the evidence bill to try to get it as good as we can. When it came to the implementation, the profession found out on 16 January—some of them might have found out a bit earlier, but not much earlier—that a new form would be coming in on 1 February and that the old form would not be acceptable and that they cannot get the new forms on disk.

I would not like to think we are making the same sort of mistake here. The mistake in the Family Court matter is able to be remedied only by upgraded costs to solicitors and clients. Any mistake here is not so easily remedied because you cannot identify when a member of the profession is not up to scratch because they have not had sufficient notice. I would like the government to point out why it thinks a couple of months and 18 days is really sufficient for the introduction of this bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the fact that you are not moving an amendment to change the date, but you are asking a number of questions—
—If you don't give me a good reason I'll think about it.
—I do not want to encourage you.
—Try and do a good job then.

—We always try. I am advised that the April date was selected in the House of Representatives in October last year when this bill was introduced and it was anticipated the bill would get through the parliament before Christmas. It did not; it came to the Senate. It was referred to the appropriate Senate committee—I presume the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs—and now it has come back. That date emerged in the House of Representatives when people anticipated a speedier passage of the bill than has now occurred.
—So why are we changing it?

—I have asked the same question of my advisers. It is an obvious question. Parliament has delayed it for whatever reason. I am informed that, as you have certainly conceded, there has been plenty of publicity about this bill. In one sense the consultation process has gone on for a long time. Every man and his dog and every suspect in the legal profession and every legal committee has been rounded up and so on to have discussion about it.

PARA.TAB: It is not as though this bill and its contents, even its application date, has suddenly been sprung on anybody. It has been around a long time, as you have more than adequately explained, even to me and I have not been through this bill at great length. So it is not as though this bill has been sprung on anybody. The bill and its contents have been through long negotiations and consultations which have got some agreement on all sides. It may have been a tortuous process but agreement has been achieved. It has not been sprung on people as far as the profession's knowing what is coming is concerned. Obviously there would be at least somebody, some professional person, in a law firm, aware of what is going on and that this bill was coming.

So we believe that 18 April is still a reasonable date. Obviously you can always say another month, two months, three months or a year of preparation is needed before something comes into operation and then presumably more people would know about it but, in view of the length of time already taken, I suspect many people in the profession want to get on with the job.

I have also been advised that in those cases that start before 18 April and continue past 18 April, past the Easter break, the old rules still apply until those cases are finished. So no-one, whether it be a court, lawyers and so on, will have to change their operation in mid-stride if they have a case—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is true whatever date you pick though.

—That is true. We believe that the 18th is sustainable. I am told by my advisers that the department will be making every effort to publicise the new provisions and to send out information to the profession. That is the only appropriate course. I do not know whether I have persuaded you not to put up an amendment, but we believe 18 April is okay.

—I have had an indication from Senator Spindler that were we to move an amendment we would not be successful, so we will save that little exercise. There is always the opportunity in the House of Representatives to move an amendment if we find further information that indicates that the choice you have made is not right. Could you indicate what you mean when you say the department is going to notify the profession? Does that mean you are going to write letters to the bar councils and the law societies and let them do the rest?

PARA.TAB: It is important to understand that it will not be just people who are members of bar associations who will be affected by this. There are states, like South Australia, that have a mixed profession where someone could easily find themselves defending someone and not having been notified by the bar association because they are not a member of it. So the problem of letting solicitors know is not just a case of getting to the relevant societies, as not everybody is a member of the relevant law society. I would not say that there are plenty of people. In some states I do not think—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Little in Victoria is not a member.

—I did not hear that interjection, I am sorry. I would respond to it if I did hear it and found that it related to something I had said. I am not ignoring you; I just did not hear what you said, Senator Schacht.
—In New South Wales you have to be a member of the Law Society to practise.

—Yes, that is true in a number of states. Nonetheless, there are sole practitioners—and I do not know if they are in Oodnadatta—out in far reaching country towns. There are sole practitioner who just do not liaise much with the rest of the profession; they are isolated and work on their own.
—I have the answer.
—Good. I want to know what you are going to do.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that three things are being planned: firstly, obviously we will be writing to all the appropriate legal bodies informing them of the starting date in the legislation; secondly, we will be preparing a commentary on the legislation and its content which will be available for sale through—
—When will it be available? Let me guess—18 April.

—No, even I would draw the line at that. We would be aiming to have the commentary available for distribution in early March; and, finally, the department will be organising seminars, inviting members of the profession who wish to attend to come and be briefed on the legislation. We also understand that, anyway, the profession itself in recent times has organised its own seminars to publicise the bill.

PARA.TAB: I have outlined three things to you, Senator. In view of the cooperation on this point, if you have any other suggestions to make as to what should be reasonably done to publicise and bring the starting date and the content of the bill to the attention of the profession and that sole operator or practitioner at Oodnadatta or elsewhere who may not have got information, we will be happy to receive those in the next couple of days.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his answer. I can see that I am on a lost cause here, but I can see some difficulties arising. With the greatest of respect to the department or anyone else who is aiming to do a commentary on this bill, for it to be said that it will be available in early March means to me late March. I think I would be almost prepared to take cash bets. But since I am not really being personal, I will not bother with that. It is a lost cause. We want to conclude this bill. If more points need to be made about it, they can be made in the other place.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just one last point. My advisers have said March. I think when we say March, we are meaning 1 March, and we will meet that deadline. Let us put a date on the record. We will make it 10 March. If 18 April is the starting date, I believe it is not unreasonable to have the commentary available at least a month before that starting date. So we will make it 10 March, and that will be our target.
—My concerns have been heightened by the minister's responses just over the last five or 10 minutes.
—You mean you would support an amendment?

—I am on the point of saying that, if there is to be an amendment, we may well support it. I wonder whether the minister could make a commitment to communicate with the legal profession directly. The three avenues that he has outlined are really sort of second stage matters. He is going to an association and relying on the association to do certain things.
—You mean write to every lawyer?

—That is one way; the alternative would be to take out advertisements in the daily media. Either one of those would assist. But I am a little uncomfortable about the government relying on communicating with associations and providing publications which are available at a bookshop to be purchased. I think people need to know that it is available. I would like to see a commitment to general publicity in the daily media or direct communication by letter to members of the profession.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not a lawyer, and people know my views about the legal profession. In the past, I have made remarks about what I think ought to be significant reforms in the legal profession. One of them is communication and making sure the public gets access to information. In this case, we are talking about the profession's access to information on a law that has been carried by the federal parliament. I emphasise that this is federal legislation for federal courts; it does not affect state jurisdiction. I have tried to get information about whether there is any way we can identify those practitioners who generally practise in the Federal Court.
—Oh, that's not good enough.

—Hang on, Senator Reid. I am trying to find out whether there is a databank of information. Are you suggesting that we should send a letter to every practising lawyer in every state? I think that would be approaching 30,000 to 50,000 people.

—You can send letters to every social security client and every other client who you want to massage any time you like. There is no difficulty in sending out 30,000 letters. If you are serious about them—

—I know that it is not difficult to mail the letter; that is not my point. My point relates to the databank of information and the appropriate list of which lawyers would genuinely be interested in this bill. I am sympathetic to the idea, because I think it is good communication, good government and good due process.

PARA.TAB: I will raise with the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) the point about whether there is a way that we can go direct to the practitioners with this information. I cannot make a commitment about it because I do not have enough information in front of me. It would be stupid and irresponsible of me to make a commitment that may not be able to be carried through for whatever practical reasons. I will raise with the Attorney-General what Senator Spindler said and what Senator Vanstone said in her follow-on. I will ask him to come back to Senator Vanstone, as the shadow minister, with information about the pros and cons of sending direct communication to the practitioners on this point.

Nevertheless, in relation to those other three points, we have a commitment that the commentary would be completed and available by 10 March. I think we are doing everything we can on these commitments that have been negotiated across the table. Maybe I am more than sympathetic to some of those requests because I am a non-lawyer. I ask you to support the government and this great effort by a non-lawyer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the minister comment on the additional suggestion of placing advertisements in daily media—not to reproduce the whole bill but simply to draw attention to the fact that this information should be obtained from the various legal associations?
—Perhaps I can ask the minister to at least take this into account: if the Attorney does not agree—
—Look—

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Colston)—Senator Vanstone has the call.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will sign a contract myself, but I think it ought to be A-G's which has some advice.
—True; I am just making a simple point. You have indicated that you will ask the Attorney about the efficacy of writing to the entire profession.
—Communicating direct, yes. That is what Senator Spindler asked me.
—I think we can accept that because, if he doesn't, no doubt the Democrats and the opposition will.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take Senator Spindler's suggestion about advertising on board and refer that to the Attorney. I do not know whether it has been done in the past. It seems to me that, within due reason about cost, it might be a reasonable idea.
—You spend millions in other departments advertising programs.
—And when we do we get abused by the opposition.
—Sending out Cleo magazines.

—I know that you are not interested in safe sex, Senator Alston, but a lot of the rest of the population is, and that is what that was about. I would raise with the Attorney-General the suggestion about some modest advertising in appropriate places, not full pages in the Australian. Appropriate advertisements could be looked at with only a modest outcome on cost.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bills reported with amendments; report adopted.
Bills (on motion by Senator Schacht) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 7 December 1994, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports the Archives Amendment Bill 1994, but I will make a few general comments. This bill seems to have come about because the government has been basically asleep on the job in terms of the consequences for archives of the privatisation of a number of government business enterprises. We have now apparently reached the point where the government realises that it is necessary to take legislative action to prevent any further erosion of the archives.

PARA.TAB: The initiative for this bill comes from the National Archives Council, of which Senator Margaret Reid has been a member for some 10 years. I think it alerted the government to the fact that a number of things were being done on an ad hoc basis and it was necessary to adopt an overall strategy. Although belated, I think this legislation is certainly welcomed.

It is worth noting that there are already a number of GBEs which have been translated into the private sector and, in respect of each of those, there are different rules that apply. For example, a specific clause was put into the Moomba pipeline legislation in order to protect its records. In the case of CSL however, archives had to reach an agreement with it about redepositing records which had simply gone with the organisation. The Commonwealth Bank seems to have always been above the law in this regard and has always held its own records. The Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation similarly took its records with it and some have been subsequently retrieved.

Aussat records were transferred to Optus when Optus acquired the Aussat satellite. Again, because of the very ad hoc and ill-thought out nature of the exercise, it decided that it did not make much commercial sense to hang on to presumably vast quantities of useless information and it handed them back to archives. Australian Airlines used to hold its own records but when it became part of Qantas, archives lost control of those records.

We have a whole series of patchwork solutions that have been arrived at by default. Until now the government has not been prepared to take action to coordinate its approach. But, finally, we now seem to have adopted a principle where, unless the legislation specifically states otherwise, the records will remain with the archives. That being the case, it is certainly an advance on the current system.

Archives are clearly the most appropriate place for the control of these documents. They are the ones in a position to make any judgments that need to be made about the selection of documents. I assume that they bend over backwards to retain almost everything. That is as it should be. An independent body should have responsibility for this rather than someone who is directly involved, perhaps having good commercial or other reasons for deciding that they prefer to see certain records no longer in existence. I simply say that we support that amendment. We similarly support the amendment in relation to the national witness protection program and those changes which allow the Australian Federal Police to retain certain sensitive documents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to contribute briefly to this debate because the Archives Amendment Bill is an important piece of legislation for the Australian Archives. The Archives Bill was passed through the parliament in 1983. It is interesting that the explanatory memorandum pointed out that the Archives had already been in existence some 40 years at that time. So we are talking about one of the older institutions of government.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Archives still does not have its proper home in the parliamentary triangle, and I hope that will be dealt with before too many more years pass. Although the Archives keeps a lot of papers and documents—the records of the tax office may well be boring, but those of a lot of other departments are really very interesting—it also has a great deal of material which is presently stored in repositories around Australia which is worth looking at and which should be on display as part of the history and heritage of this country. I hope this material will be on display.

I was somewhat dismayed at the abandonment of the Museum of Australia. It made me think that the Archives, as a building for display, might also slip away due to those who do not regard the displaying and making available of the history and heritage of the country as something of significance. For example, the Archives has all the original models and proposals for the provisional Parliament House. It has so many things that are worth looking at. It is a pity that people cannot see these things. If there is a building in the parliamentary triangle, it will become one of the important institutions and places for people to visit. A great deal of research is done through the records of the Archives.

We realise that it has become quite important that, if government institutions are to be sold, the government records of those enterprises should be retained and be made available as others are. Senator Alston has been through some of the recent examples of what has occurred with those records. It is necessary that this amendment to the Archives Act is passed to assist in seeing that there are fairly clearly defined arrangements for the future. There are a number of ways of dealing with this issue, and several have already been dealt with. A document that I have been given reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . the only existing remedies for this problem—
that is, of government business enterprise documents—

are to seek to have provisions for retention of the records included in the legislation authorising the sale of the enterprise, to bring the records back into the coverage of the Act by regulation or to induce the new owner to deposit the older records with Australian Archives . . .
As has been mentioned, this has occurred. But all of these are somewhat uncertain. There needs to be some proper arrangement for the records to be retained.

PARA.TAB: I am also concerned about some of the records of sections of departments which have been closed down in recent times that have not been given to the Archives. It is inevitable that there will be changes to the function of government. Some things become irrelevant after a period; new things come along. I have recently heard of instances where sections of departments have been closed down and the records have been left somewhere and not given to the Archives. It has even been suggested to me that millions of dollars of assets in drawings and technical information in certain areas of construction have not been properly deposited and recorded. If the Commonwealth wanted to go back over some of those matters of infrastructure, the records may not be able to be found as one would expect that they should.

There are other areas about which Australian Archives is very aware. We need to look closely at the original act to see whether it is adequate to cover them. Some of us have mastered quite well E-mail and some of the new means of communication. Others of us still marvel at what can occur even in our own offices. We need to look at how that material is to be recorded. Documents that are drafted on computers can be changed many times before one gets a final version.

Under the old system, whereby these documents were produced on paper, the original drafts would also be available. They also tell a story of how something emerged and evolved. Much of that is now lost because one can bring up a document on the machine and amend it. What went on and why it went on is lost. I cannot help thinking about the little yellow stickers that we put all over things these days. Once upon a time, cabinet notebooks and other documents had handwritten notes. Frequently, that is the most interesting part of a document. We will not find much of that any more, because the interesting bits are on the little yellow stickers that may be removed or which may fall off anyway. A lot of the history may well be lost and not available for historians in time to come.

I have been reading through the 1993 act. It does not specifically refer to only written documents. It refers to documents and records. Perhaps it was written without it being adequately expansive for the means of communication these days. Even in 1983 the most senior public servants had a secretary. They now do not. It is all done by machine and done quite differently.

It is important that the country retain its history. It is part of the heritage. I know that Australian Archives is looking at these technical changes. In any event, it also needs the resources to explore and examine them and to find out how to keep the tapes and records that are made of documents these days. We all know what has happened with the National Film and Sound Archives and what has occurred to the old films and the steps that have to be taken to preserve them and keep them in good condition. Australian Archives needs to be adequately resourced to see that it can do the things that it knows need to be done with the records of the country.

As Senator Alston has outlined, the opposition supports this bill. There are not many times when one gets a chance to talk about the Archives. The annual report always comes in on the night before the Senate adjourns for Christmas. The opportunity to stand up and talk then is very limited indeed. So this bill's coming in gives me an opportunity to raise some of the matters that I think are significant: the building; the new means of communication; and the records of government departments which are closed down and disposed of either by sale or by just coming to an end. They are significant. I hope that we will continue to record the history of the country and make it available for future generations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Archives Amendment Bill 1994. The coalition supports this bill for two very important purposes. It clarifies the current legislation relating to the records of the national witness protection program. The bill also ensures that records of the Commonwealth that are inadvertently removed from the operation of the Archives Act 1983 when public bodies change their structure to government business enterprises that are commercialised, incorporated or privatised are not lost to the nation.

PARA.TAB: The mechanism for the proper archiving of Commonwealth, state and private records in Australia is vital. At the national level, we must set an example with proper levels of funding and support for the latest methods to save archival material. As a member of the council of the Australian National Library, I pay tribute to the library's contribution to archiving our national history. A main corporative objective of the ANL is to collect and preserve Australian documentary material of national significance and ensure that this material is available to all Australians. The Australian National Library has addressed in its council, of which I am a member, a number of issues related to this. One of the great problems with the collection and preservation of this sort of material is that there are two key questions to answer: firstly, what will be collected; and, secondly, once it is collected, how is it stored in a form to guarantee that it will be there over a long time?

We had an interesting debate at the council one day when we went through all the different media in which material can be stored. Film has enormous problems, particularly the older films made with nitrate before the Second World War, which are now deteriorating very rapidly. What sort of processes and expenses will we go to to ensure that this material is properly preserved?

Then there are video tapes. I do not know whether any senators have seen colour video tapes from 1975 when colour television first started in this country. There has been a marked deterioration in quality over a 20-year period. Under current systems of recording material, given another 20 years all of this will be lost. We looked at computer disks. We all know what happens on a computer disk. If we press the wrong key at the wrong time we can make huge slabs of information totally disappear.

The interesting thing about the discussion at the Australian National Library was what we came back to in the end as the safest form of storage, and that is books. Back to the old technology of books where, if preserved properly in airconditioned premises, we can probably guarantee up to 600, 700 or 800 years for the preservation of material. The problem with that is the vast amount of written material and the storage space required. Storing material in this form creates all sorts of cost problems.

Some of the most interesting material that has been stored is early Australian film. I had the opportunity once to visit the national film office in Canberra and look at some of the material that had been kept for an exhibition for people interested in the Art Deco era of Australia back in the 1920s and 1930s. The film office put on a day for the Art Deco society and played radio recordings of the old shows in those days. It showed film from those days—all the old Dad and Dave films—and pictures of the original parliament with the beautiful Art Deco architecture that was created there before being extended in cheap ways. That material is vital to our national heritage, but because of the nitrate film used at that time we are in danger of losing it—it faces the possibility of destruction.

The great problem we have now on the second issue I raised—what we keep as opposed to the way in which we store it—is the vast volume of material that is created every day. Just think of how many newspapers have been created in Australia on this day, how many books and how many magazines; how much film is created for television every night and radio recordings from every station right around Australia. Of that material, what do we hold on to, store and archive? Some rather tragic examples from the past show how we can lose precious material.

The radio program Blue Hills that was recorded by the ABC and produced 1,700 episodes has only six part episodes left. By lack of diligence the rest just got lost or destroyed in the system. The Jack Davey show, which was very popular through the 1930s, 1940s and 1950s, was recorded on large acetate discs which were obviously taking up a lot of room at the radio studio. Those discs were used as fill in the Warringah expressway. All the original Jack Davey shows are now under the Warringah expressway. All that precious Australiana has been lost because of lack of care.

The government has to put some resources behind the archival system in Australia. It is not just a matter of building a building and storing the material in it. What the archives office has to have is more resources so that it can be pro-active in educating organisations on ways in which to store material in a preliminary form—not throwing it away—so that later on archivists can come searching for original material and sorting and selecting can be done. It is expensive but we only get once chance. Once we have lost this material it is gone forever.

We now have a new problem presented to us. With the information superhighway coming across Australia, in the new communications age, there is going to be an enormous amount of material that will not only come down the line from other countries but will also leave Australia for other countries. We will be selling a whole range of new products on the information superhighway. This will be a great new export industry: a whole range of new products will flourish. In the past, we had a problem: we lost bits of Dad and Dave, Blue Hills and the Jack Davey show. This will now become a major problem. We will have to make those vital decisions again of how to store the material, what to collect and what to archive. It is something that the parliament should address.

Senator Reid raised the valid issue that we do not normally have a chance to comment on the report that comes down. The government has introduced this bill and we have had an opportunity to talk about the precious nature of the records of Australia and the need for more resources to support this matter. I commend the bill to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the government, I appreciate the remarks of senators in support of this bill and the interest shown by senators who spoke on the bill. I do not want to delay the Senate. The government's views have been very adequately expressed in the second reading speech, and I commend the bill to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before calling on question time, I wish to raise a couple of matters. A matter has been raised with me concerning the safety of workers who leave the building late at night and must pass through the blockade to get to their cars. The Speaker and I are aware of one or two isolated incidents of abuse, although in general the protesters have been courteous and well behaved. We have drawn these incidents to the attention of the organisers of the blockade, who assured us that they will make every endeavour to forbid abusive behaviour, which they see as damaging to their own cause.

PARA.TAB: The security controller has advised that the police have been made aware of the incidents and will now be monitoring the main entry points to ensure, if possible, that such incidents of abuse do not recur. I advise all occupants of the building that if they have any concerns about passing through the blockade they should phone the Parliament House control room on extension 5999 and prompt arrangements will be made to have a parliamentary security attendant escort them to their car.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday a number of visitors in the galleries disrupted proceedings by clapping. I remind visitors to the galleries that disrupting the parliament in any way is considered disorderly and could lead to a decision to close the galleries. While I recognise that the issues about which some visitors are protesting generate considerable emotion, I ask you to refrain from any action which will disrupt the proceedings of the Senate. Your protest so far has been courteous and constructive. I ask you both in your own interests and in the interests of the Senate to continue this courtesy in the chamber.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before questions I wonder if I could ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) to clarify ministerial arrangements. We understand that Senator Collins has been asked to take over the management of the woodchip debacle. Does that mean that questions that we would otherwise have asked of the environment minister must now be asked of Senator Collins in his new capacity?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no change to ministerial arrangements of which I have been made aware.

—Mr President, if Senator Faulkner still has his job, my question is directed to him as the Minister for the Environment, Sport an Territories. I refer him to the deal with the Tasmanian Labor Party, revealed by its forest spokesman Paul Lennon on 27 January, which resulted in 50 coupes in Tasmania that were originally to be protected being deleted from the list and substituted by 50 coupes in Victoria so as to meet the government's target of 500-odd coupes to be preserved from woodchip logging. I ask the minister: what was his part in organising this arrangement?
—There is no truth to the suggestions that there were any such arrangements.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the minister if he would therefore explain the statement of the Tasmanian Labor spokesman Paul Lennon. What was he doing—trying to be a big man in Tasmania, where Tasmanians seats were under threat? Why did he say that 50 coupes were substituted from Victoria?
—Why don't you ask him?

—No, I am asking him. He should know. He deals with his colleagues in Tasmania. Why would he say 50 coupes were being substituted from Victoria to Tasmania? Is not the fact that was the case further confirmed by the evidence in Victoria that what was classified was 74 rather than the originally declared 124 coupes?

—I really cannot speak for members of parliament who are members of other houses, and I think most people would suggest that a question asking me to do so is quite unreasonable. I have given Senator Hill as much information as I can on the issue.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. I refer to reports yesterday that the United States based fibre optics company Methode Electronics has decided to shift its regional headquarters from Singapore to Sydney. In addition to manufacturing operations, the report claims that the company will operate its regional sales services and distribution facilities from this centre. Can the minister confirm these reports? Further, can the minister inform the Senate of the conditions in the Australian services sector that have encouraged Methode to relocate?

—I did not quite catch all of that question because of the interjections in this chamber, but I will answer that part of the question that I did hear. It is true that the US electronics company Methode Electronics has decided to relocate its operations in the Asia-Pacific from Singapore to Australia. The Methode Electronics fibre optic product group will control the manufacturing, sales and distribution of that company's products, the fibre-optic products, in the whole of the Asia-Pacific area from Australia.

PARA.TAB: Methode will invest $20 million in Australia over the next five years, create 50 new jobs and, because of this relocation, increase the high technology exports out of this country by having export earnings of $20 million a year. It will certainly strengthen Australia's reputation in this part of the world as a premier location for electronics information technology and high technology.

The other part of the question that I heard goes to the issue of the performance of the Australian services sector. The Australian services sector represents 70 per cent of all economic activity in Australia, employs 80 per cent of workers in this country and is noted as a sector of intelligent exports. Output in the services sector has shown rapid acceleration over recent years. Production is up by 12.2 per cent in the last 3 1/2 years.

In terms of exports, the services sector is a big export performer and our exports have been strengthening from that sector, the most recent example being IBM, which yesterday announced record earnings of $420 million from exports from Wangaratta in Australia. It is indeed a success story. Importantly, $134 million of its earnings from exports were from software services supplied from Australia to the Asia-Pacific area.

On the services sector, investment across the board has increased. New investment is expanding. It is up by 38 per cent from June 1993, and the ABS forecasts on investment for this sector show a growth of 42.1 per cent in investment in the current financial year. I can also add that the National Australia Bank quarterly business survey says that this sector looks forward to and is confident about its growth prospects in the future and looks forward to sustained economic growth.

The other important indicator for Australia is employment. The Bureau of Industry Economics industry briefs on the services sector show that the services sector has accounted for almost all of the employment growth in the Australian economy since 1991. A total of 420,800 Australians found jobs in the services sector in the 21 months to December 1994. A big chunk of the government's commitment at the last election to deliver half a million jobs, which will now be delivered one year ahead of time, is due to the buoyant performance in this sector and has caused the government to revise upwards job growth in the most recent indicators and to revise downwards the level of unemployment in this country. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's gallery of the mission of the Commission Bureau on Production and Trade of the French National Assembly. On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate and hope that your stay here will be productive and interesting.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I assume he will not get any questions from his own side on woodchipping, so I ask him this: is it true that 61 of the 249 New South Wales compartments on his list have recently passed a stringent state government process entailing external approval by the EPA, the National Parks and Wildlife Service and the Regulatory and Public Information Committee? Did a detailed New South Wales government environmental impact study recently rate the conservation value of 20 out of 26 of his compartments in the Eden area as being moderate to low even at the least sensitive end of the scale? Is it true that 12 of these contain no old-growth forest whatsoever? Was this critical information taken into account in the New South Wales Conservation Council's taxpayer funded assessments conducted by people such as `Natalie' and others? If so, how could these assessments reach the conclusions they did? If they were not taken into account, how can he say the process was rigorous? (Time expired)

—I am aware that a series of allegations have been made that coupes in the original list of 1,297 or in the current list of 509 should not have been included in that list for various reasons. Those reasons have included previous logging activities, the presence of plantations and so forth.

PARA.TAB: It is true that there are coupes which have been previously disturbed by logging or other activities or which contain plantations. Criticisms have been based on false assumptions such as, firstly, that any disturbance renders the whole coupe of no conservation value. By way of example I have used before, a quarry of a few hectares in a coupe out of an area of, say, 130 hectares does not mean that that coupe does not retain high conservation values. Nor does the fact that half a coupe has been clear-felled mean the remaining area is not of high conservation value.

Another false assumption is that the whole list is based on the classification of coupes as old growth or wilderness. As I have said in the chamber on a number of occasions, there are a number of other values which were assessed—a whole range of values—including national estate values, biodiversity, endangered species, and World Heritage as well as old growth and wilderness. That, of course, is consistent with the national forest policy statement.

It is also true that there may have been logging areas which we had under assessment and that that logging may be continuing. This would, of course, have a negative impact on the values that we have attributed to those areas. A process of verification has been announced which will determine whether that is the case. In assessing old growth, the portfolio applied the NFPS definition of `old-growth forest'. Consistent with—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order relating very much to relevance. Senator Faulkner has had three minutes or more to answer a very specific question asking whether 61 out of 249 compartments had recently passed a stringent state government process involving the EPA, the National Parks and Wildlife Service and the Regulatory and Public Information Committee. He was further asked whether a detailed New South Wales environmental impact study had recently rated 20 out of 26 as very low in terms of conservation value. I have simply asked the minister specifically to confirm that information—not to give me generalised answers. I understand that he is in the process of backing down quite comprehensively, but I want answers to specific questions. I would have thought you are now in a position to judge whether or not his answer is in any way touching on the matters that I have raised.
—I disagree with you. I am not in a position to judge that, but I would ask Senator Faulkner to address the question as closely as he can.

—One of the major problems that the Commonwealth has faced in this issue has been the lack of cooperation of state agencies. Where we have received cooperation from state agencies, on the few occasions that has occurred, those inputs have been utilised in the assessments that my department has made. I really believe it is very hypocritical for the states or Senator Alston to be critical of these outcomes, given the lack of cooperation that we have seen from state agencies in this process.

—I ask a supplementary question. I take it that you are simply not prepared to tell the Senate whether all those processes approved these areas on the grounds of conservation values. If you cannot answer that question, I ask you this: is it true that both coupes in compartment 2324 in the Glenbog State Forest were 100 per cent logged about 15 years ago? Is it also true that one of the two coupes was logged as recently as last year? You are the minister; you know the processes. Can you explain how this compartment meets your high conservation value criteria, whatever those criteria may be?
—Mr President, I have indicated, and I will say it again, that I do not intend to go into a debate today about the values of individual coupes. That is why we have established a verification process.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. It is totally irrelevant whether he intends to go into a debate today or not. He has been asked a specific question. If he cannot answer it, he should say, `I can't answer it,' otherwise he should have a go at answering it. He has been asked in relation to coupes in compartment 2324 on his list. Were they both 100 per cent logged about 15 years ago? In relation to one of those coupes, was it logged as recently as last year? It is a simple, straightforward question. What is the answer?

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—Mr President, I rise on a separate point of order. At the start of the day's proceedings you asked the gallery to behave themselves. They have behaved impeccably, but the example set by those opposite in shouting down ministers can hardly encourage them to continue to do so.

—I was going to make that point myself at some stage. But it is quite clear, and you know, Senator Hill, that I am not in a position to determine either how a minister will answer a question or, indeed, if a minister answers a question. I can rule on general relevance, but that is all.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Alston

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order and particularly your ruling. Standing order 194 states:

INTERJECT.PARA: A Senator shall not digress from the subject matter of any question under discussion . . .

That is a requirement that you are charged with policing. Therefore, you are in a position to make judgments about whether answers are in any way touching on the subject matter. If you are going to say to us that, irrespective of what might be said, even if he answers by talking about the price of bread, you cannot judge whether it is relevant, then what is the purpose of having a standing order of that nature? Why are you not able to say that an answer that says `I don't want to get into a debate about any particular item on the list' is not relevant when you are asked about those? After all, all those 511 presumably are there because each and every one of them has high conservation values. If the minister responsible for the list is not able to justify any one of those, I would have thought he has a very big problem. In any event, if he is asked about a specific one, why aren't you in a position, towards the end of his answer, to judge whether he has in any shape or form touched on that matter?

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course I am in a position to judge something to be irrelevant if somebody goes on to a different topic altogether. Senator Faulkner was not digressing from the topic in general terms.

—The process of verification has been outlined and it will substantiate whether a coupe has the values for which it has been placed on the list and therefore should remain on the list. It will be on the basis of substantiated evidence provided that that verification process and that assessment will be made. I hope, as I said previously, that we will receive better cooperation in the future from the states so that we can ensure that the verification process takes place quickly.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. The minister would be aware of recent press reports which allege that the government is supporting a $100 million sale of rifles to Indonesia. Can the minister advise the Senate and the wider community of the factual position with regard to this matter?

—Towards the end of January there were a variety of newspaper articles suggesting that Australia was interested in marketing a large number of Steyr rifles to Indonesia and nominated a figure of $109 million. There is no such proposal whatsoever and those newspaper reports were totally false. The Indonesian government has made it quite clear that it has never requested a substantial purchase of rifles from Australia, because it has invested heavily, as we have, in its own production facilities and it will source any rifles needed by the Indonesian army from its own country. I have been written to by the Managing Director of ADI, the only producer of military rifles in Australia, also saying that the company does not intend to market on a large scale Steyr rifles to Indonesia.
—What was Evans talking about?
—If you shut up, you will learn, you fathead.
—Order! That level of language really is not appropriate, Senator Evans. I ask you to withdraw it.
—I gracefully withdraw it.
—Order! That does not excuse the interjections, however.

—This answer was going to take 1 1/2 minutes. The complaints by members of the opposition suggest that they want to extend the answer, not me. ADI has had no intention of marketing Steyr rifles. This particular newspaper article was based on an application by ADI to export some Steyr rifles, and that was an exploration in principle. It was for the purposes in Indonesia of collection and evaluation, probably numbering 20 rifles. Because we have such strict export controls, in relation to even a small number of rifles—no matter how small—you need export in principle. I suppose the article has had one value—it has let a lot of journalists feed off one journalist's inaccurate report and have a great time in the press.
—You were very slow in responding.

—You are right in that, Senator Kemp; I happened to have been on leave. Even ministers are allowed to go on leave occasionally. I take this opportunity to say that there are no plans by Australia nor Indonesia for a large scale purchase of Steyr rifles to the value of $109 million or even $1 million.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. What is the total area covered by the 509 forest coupes now in contention and what proportion of Australia's forests do they represent? If, as logging protesters maintain, it is urgent that they have access to these coupes to be able to continue their activities, does this not indicate very clearly that these forestry activities are unsustainable?

—I think the estimated area of the coupes afforded interim protection in the Prime Minister's statement of 27 January is some 60,000 hectares. I think this amount represents around one-fifteenth of one per cent of Australia's native forest estate and around one half of one per cent of the total area of state forest.

PARA.TAB: I remind senators that, in addition to state forests, the forest industry can also gain access to private forest, as well as to other crown lands. That needs to be taken into account when looking at those sorts of percentages and proportions.

In response to the second part of Senator Coulter's question, I recognise that there are a number of constraints on the states in rescheduling coupes, but forest agency sustainable yield calculations indicate that there is a significant amount of unlogged forest available to the industry and a complex network of roading infrastructure is also already in place.

If it is true, as the industry is claiming at this point, that it cannot survive without the logging of these 509 coupes, then I do agree that it certainly raises significant questions about the sustainability of the current logging operations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In the light of his answer, will the minister give an unequivocal undertaking that he will use his best endeavour to obtain a very substantial expansion of federal support for plantation forestry in the forthcoming budget? I am not asking the minister whether this will be in the budget because I know the answer to that would be that we will have to wait for the budget, but will he, as the minister for environment, use his best endeavour to achieve this necessary expansion?

—The issue Senator Coulter raises obviously is a very important one. Plantation forestry is one of a number of priority issues that my portfolio will be considering in its budget preparations. I cannot give the sort of ironclad commitments that Senator Coulter has sought in this regard, but I can assure him that it is an important issue and it is one that the portfolio is giving due attention to in its preparations for this year's budget.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. What is the net impact of the woodchip industry on the balance of payments when such items as the cost of imported capital equipment, the use of inputs such as fuel, the repayment of interest on foreign loans and the repatriation of profits to other countries are taken into account? Can the minister confirm the findings of a recent La Trobe University study which found that, if the cost of subsidies to forestry operations is taken into account, a cutback of our woodchip export industry may in fact benefit our balance of payments?

—I do not have any figures that relate directly to woodchips per se. Woodchips are part of an integrated forest approach and are dependent on the performance of other sectors of the forest industry. These estimates vary, but about 60 per cent of a sawlog goes to sawn timber. The remaining 40 per cent waste material would classically then be feedstock for woodchipping. The industry is integrated and you cannot differentiate one part of the industry from another and apportion capital costs thereby. Certainly, we do not have any figures for that.

PARA.TAB: Woodchips themselves are the lowest value added form of forest product and they are feedstock, as I have said, for pulp and paper production. We do have statistics on exports of pulpwood, most of which I think is exports of woodchips. In 1993-94, exports of pulpwood from Australia were valued at $454 million. Total exports for the forest industry that year were valued at $860 million. Imports for the industry that year were valued at $2.6 billion—that is, other nations' forests. Therefore, the net deficit to the current account was $1.8 billion.

The implication of the question that somehow the existence of woodchipping exports is a net negative to the current account is, I think, a nonsensical proposition. The government is committed to a balance between environmental values—and protecting those—and protecting and providing a rational development plan for this industry.

The national forest policy, which we support and have been a key in getting together with the mainland states, involves a phasing out of woodchip exports by the year 2000. That does not mean to say that woodchipping per se would stop. We would hope that the woodchipping that is done then is consumed domestically in Australia and value is added to it for import replacement and/or export.

To the second part of the question about the La Trobe University study, I have not had an opportunity to examine, nor do I believe my colleague the Treasurer has had an opportunity to examine, this study in any detail, but I do note that it refers to a state government forestry policy issue, not a federal government forestry policy issue. The states do have control, under the constitution, of those forests, not us. Not having looked at it in detail, I do note as well, however, that the subsidies are presented as estimates and cover a wide range. I also note that the subsidies referred to do not appear to be directly related to wood exports. Therefore, the link with our balance of payments is not that clear-cut.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is direct to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I refer the minister to the joint study involving the Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management and the Australian Heritage Commission which led to the 1992 agreement for the southern forest region of Western Australia. Is the minister aware that that agreement was applauded as a model process by the Prime Minister, the then ministers for the environment and resources, the coalition and the Democrats—Senator Coulter was the leader then? I ask: in a letter dated 12 December 1994 to the Western Australian Minister for the Environment did you not recognise the agreement as meeting the requirements of the national forest policy statement? If so, why is the government threatening the jobs of timber workers by launching yet another study into coupes in the very same area?
