—I am aware of the history of the agreement between the Australian Heritage Commission and the Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management. There is a memorandum of understanding between CALM and the AHC and it provides an agreed basis for applying the results of the joint assessment of National Estate values with particular reference to section 30 of the Australian Heritage Act, section 30 referrals for timber production operations in the regions, and to CALM's ongoing management responsibilities.

PARA.TAB: As required under the memorandum of understanding, the AHC-CALM joint assessment of National Estate values has provided the basis of section 30 advice for the past two years. This certainly has given very significant information about the values affected by the timber operations and the level of protection that is afforded those values in the regional reserve system.

This year CALM from WA proposed logging in a larger number of areas containing old-growth forest than had occurred in previous years. In its advice the commission referred to the conservation gains initiated by CALM, particularly—and I think this is well acknowledged and has been acknowledged by members of other parties in the Senate—in relation to wilderness. But in its section 30 advice, the Australian Heritage Commission certainly commented that the conservation of old-growth forest was not adequate, pending decisions on the guidelines for the comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I have taken careful note of the answer from the minister, who will go down as the conservation and environment minister who absolutely destroyed the value assessment process in this country.

PARA.TAB: Minister, you said in your answer that there were large areas; that is correct. You also said that the process was not adequate in terms of what had occurred under that assessment. I therefore ask you, Minister: if that is the case, why did you write in a letter to Kevin Minson, the environmental minister in Western Australia, these words on 12 December:

QUESTION.PARA: In line with the National Forestry Policy Statement the Commonwealth will give `full faith and credit' to the national estate assessment undertaken jointly by the Australian Heritage Commission (AHC) and the WA Department of Conservation and Land Management . . . While not strictly constituting an assessment of old-growth forest as envisaged under the NFPS—
and these are the words you want to listen to—
the assessment of disturbance as adequate to meet the NFPS requirement to assess this value in the southern forests region.
Why did you do that, Minister? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, there is a difference between the nature of assessment and that proportion of areas assessed that ought to be contained within a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system. That was the point I was attempting to make to Senator Crane.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt, as I indicated, that the Australian Heritage Commission made very clear and also made public in its section 30 advice to Minister Beddall that the conservation of old-growth forest was not adequate, pending the decisions on the guidelines for comprehensive, adequate and representative reserves.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. The balance of payments in recent months has reflected a surge in capital investment. Could the minister indicate in what way he would expect this to be reflected in the economy, particularly in the manufacturing sector?

—There has been a lot of understandable comment and analysis on the implications of the deteriorating current account deficit, and it is unquestionably the case that that current account deficit has a significant element of bad news in it. But, as is so often the case, bad news tends to drive out good. While the government, as has been made very clear by the Treasurer, does have to respond to that current account deficit—and the Treasurer has made clear the way in which we will do that—any sober analysis, stripped of all the histrionics, the over-dramatisation and over-simplification, will reveal that a key element of that deterioration has been the rapid growth in capital goods imports at over 24 per cent in the last year. Of course, there are other factors, many of which Senator Gareth Evans referred to yesterday in his answer. But I do not want to give an analysis of it. I want to refer only to this point about the 24 per cent increase in capital goods imports.

PARA.TAB: The simple fact is that this surge in capital investment, reflected in the balance of payments, will serve to increase the productive capacity of the Australian economy to meet the demands of Australians as well as those of our trading partners. That, of course, is good news. It is very much the measure of the transformation of the Australian economy over the past decade from the closed, cosseted economy that we were left with to an internationally open and competitive economy.

To put it in succinct terms, the difference between the very serious situation that we confronted in 1985-86 and today is that in 1985-86 the balance of payments was being driven by paying for the mythical resources investment bust that was promoted by Fraser and Howard in the early 1980s. Today the current account deficit reflects, in large part, an investment surge directed at increasing the capacity of the economy to export and to create jobs.

To illustrate the point that I am making, there has been an analysis done by my department which we will be publishing shortly. It shows, amongst other things, that manufactured exports have increased to be more than 30 per cent of our exports in the last financial year, compared to less than 20 per cent in 1983-84. For elaborately transformed manufactures, the change has been even more dramatic. In the last financial year, 1993-94, ETMs increased by 16 per cent, and they have more than doubled since 1989. Reinforcing this picture of Australia as an exporter of sophisticated manufactures, our exports of office and ADP equipment increased by more than 50 per cent to $800 million last year, and exports of telecommunications equipment jumped to $500 million.

All recent surveys of the manufacturing sector indicate that this strong export performance will continue and is, in fact, underpinned by the capital investment now taking place. For example, the survey of manufacturing in New South Wales released on Monday indicates that a quarter of manufacturers plan to increase new capital investment over the next quarter, which is good news.

All I am trying to say is that the story is always more complex than the simplistic first headline would indicate. We have a substantial element of positive news flowing through in terms of the substantial capital investment going into our manufacturing industry, the capacity that it is creating and the jobs that it is creating.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Is it true that compartment 51 in Pappinbarra State Forest in the Wauchope district of New South Wales has been extensively logged on many occasions—as early as 1924, in the 1930s and, more recently, in the 1950s, 1960s, 1970s and 1980s? Can you explain how that forest equates to having a `high conservation value' under your definition?

—I have indicated to the Senate, in answer to a previous question, the processes in terms of verification of the values of individual coupes. That process will take place with, I hope, the cooperation of the state agencies, which is more than what has been received in the past from New South Wales, Senator Brownhill. That process ought to be able to be completed very quickly.

PARA.TAB: As well as that, we are asking state agencies to be involved in a rescheduling process. I am sure that you are aware of the nature of the assessments that are required under our comprehensive regional assessment process in the lead-up to striking a regional forest agreement. Senator, I can assure you that the conservation values of all 509 coupes on the nominated list will be able to be verified quickly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It absolutely astounds me that the minister could not answer any questions yesterday about all these compartments that he and the Prime Minister have been a signatory to and have knocked out of production. I will ask him a simpler question, and he might get this one a little bit right. Is it true that of the 249 New South Wales compartments on Mr Keating's list—you and Mr Keating have been working together on this—127 have been logged once, 69 have been logged at least twice, and only 53, or 25 per cent, have never been logged? How can you justify your claim that these compartments have a high conservation value? Have a go at that one.

—The 509 coupes and compartments that were identified represent those coupes considered to be of the highest priority for the protection of conservation values. That is the case. In the case of south-east New South Wales, the initial cut was after coupe 306, Yambulla. The coupes above this have a variety of values, including old-growth and wilderness. Coupes on the Register of the National Estate were examined to determine whether they would add significantly to the conservation values and the conservation integrity of areas. In the case of north-east New South Wales, a complete re-examination was undertaken by the department to try to protect the enormous levels of biodiversity. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. I refer to yesterday's disastrous current account figures and to one of the reasons for it: American subsidies to their produce exporters, including the new dairy subsidies announced recently. Why didn't our GATT negotiators arrange interim protection from such behaviour during the interval before the WTO agreement comes into force on 1 July 1995? Secondly, in light of the damage done to our citrus industry by laws passed in this very chamber in December, isn't the United States' behaviour yet another example of how Australia has been conned into unilateral trade liberalisation? Thirdly, what is the Americans' Bogor commitment to APEC really worth given this attack on Australian dairy markets which is contrary to the spirit of both WTO and APEC?

—I have to say, Senator Kernot, that you will never replace this rabble as the serious opposition while you keep him as trade spokesman. The simple fact is that this is a fundamentally misconceived question. Of course, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade is just that—an agreement. Nobody has the capacity to enforce any particular element of that agreement, and certainly not middle sized countries like Australia. What our very effective negotiators did was achieve an outstanding deal for our agricultural industries which the agricultural industries overwhelming support.

PARA.TAB: If the point of Senator Spindler's proposal is that the WTO agreement on agriculture should be better, he is absolutely right. Of course it should be better. It is the best that it has ever been. It is the first time we have made a breakthrough to get agriculture into the international trade arena, but it is not enough. It is a small, first step—a welcome first step, but small first step—along the road of agricultural trade reform.

Nobody is in a position to demand to impose their standards. From 1 July we have for the first time ever got in place a set of arrangements that will constrain the power of much larger economies, such as the United States and the European Union, to subsidise their agriculture in our markets. I wish it was more, but it is the best it has ever been.

In answer to the question about whether we have been conned into unilateral trade liberalisation, the exact opposite is the case. The World Trade Organisation agreement is about multilateral trade liberalisation. That is exactly what it is. You do not have to look very far to find the benefits. In the last few months we have seen Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand, with major changes in their tariff regimes, pressing down. We wish it went further and we would like more but they are substantial improvements. As a result of GATT we have had improved access since 1 January for Australian produce into, amongst other places, the United States market and more will flow over the next five years.

It is absolutely clear that primary industry, particularly the dairy industry, unequivocally supports the position that the government has taken with regard to the Uruguay Round and this most recent United States foray into our markets. We appreciate their cooperation. They are well organised industries that liaise closely with the government. We work well together, but they have made it clear that they also appreciate our support and the cooperation that we give.

It is the very question of the trade problems we have with people in our region—not just but including the United States—that makes the case for APEC so overwhelming, that makes the declaration achieved at Bogor so important and that makes the work that needs to be done this year and in subsequent years to implement that Bogor declaration so important, and we will be doing it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I wonder how long Senator McMullan can continue as the trade minister if he continues to produce record trade deficits like he did yesterday. I thank him for his set speech but he did not answer the question. Perhaps I can sharpen it up a little bit. If the United States continues to use these subsidises which cost our dairy industry dearly, will the government undertake to take the United States before the WTO disputes tribunal to make it toe the line?

—I thank Senator Spindler for the rhetorically very interesting question. I do not think anything that has taken place is a breach of the Uruguay Round agreements into which we entered. If it were to continue beyond 1 July, it would be. We have been, and we will be, persistent in the pursuit of our rights within the World Trade Organisation including, if necessary, through dispute settlement procedures. Australia has done that in the past. If necessary, we will do it again. It is that capacity which is one of the strengths of the multilateral trade rules. It is a capacity which Australia gets only by being a participant in the World Trade Organisation. It is one of the reasons why we welcome the Senate's support for the legislation that enabled us to do that last year.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Minister, you have spent over $100,000 of taxpayers' money on forest assessments that are biased and have no scientific basis. You have used these defective assessments to stop logging in hundreds of coupes that have been substantially logged for many years. You have blatantly misled the Senate by insisting that you have been rigorous in identifying forests of high conservation value—
—I raise a point of order, Mr President. This is question time; it is not speech making or statement time. I ask you to bring the senator to order.

—On the point of order: under standing order 73, certain rules apply to questions. One of them is that questions shall not contain statements of facts or names of persons unless they are strictly necessary to render the question intelligible. You are entitled—in fact obliged—to wait until the end of the question in order to judge whether what Senator Macdonald is putting is a necessary part of the final question.
—I do not think there is a point of order.

—Is it true that you have even stopped logging by falsely asserting that an abundant forest species, shining gum, is a nationally rare plant? Minister, you have demeaned all those Australians who are devoted to finding sensible solutions to sustainable development issues. But, worst of all, you have imperilled the jobs of thousands of workers who have given their lives to one of the most important export industries. Minister, why should the public have any confidence in you or your arrogant government?

—Something has really been lost sight of in this debate; that is, we do have a commitment under our national forest policy statement to put in place a comprehensive, adequate, representative and genuinely national system of forest reserves and establish it for the benefit of future generations. That is an important conservation element of the national forest policy statement.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the country also has a responsibility and, very importantly, an opportunity to set aside and protect areas that really are fundamentally important for these purposes. That is what a system of forest reserves will achieve. It includes a full range of values. That is again something about which there seems to be total ignorance by the questioners from the opposition.

We are not just talking about old-growth and wilderness values; we are talking about an assessment of a whole range of values that are also important. It is possible that significant biodiversity exists in areas that have been previously logged. It is also true of endangered species. World Heritage values are also important, as are National Estate values and Aboriginal heritage values.

We have an opportunity at this time, while there still are significant stands of native forest in this country, to really make a difference. As the government has said, the way forward is under the national forest policy statement, which is a document that has been agreed to not only by the Commonwealth government but also by the mainland states in Australia. In signing that document, governments agreed that there ought to be a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system. It also says—it is pretty obvious, really, when you think about it—that, until that reserve system is set in place, we avoid those logging activities in areas that are likely to have high conservation value. It really seems to me that that sort of policy makes a lot of sense.

In relation to the issue that has turned the minds of the opposition today, we have excluded 509 areas from woodchip export licences. This gives them interim protection so that there is an opportunity to see that assessment take place. I have outlined the sorts of processes that the government is pursuing. I really believe that there will be positive conservation outcomes from what the government is attempting to do. You as an opposition have to answer why you do not stand for the protection of high conservation value native forests. Why do you not answer a few of the questions about the future of those areas? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If the minister's policy is so good, what is wrong with his communication skills, because nobody else in Australia can understand it? Why can he not answer the questions that we have been putting to him in the last week? Why can he not tell us what these rigorous assessments are and who these high conservation value assessments are supposed to be done by? Minister, give us some answers. Give the people of Australia some answers, because nobody understands it. Minister, you might start by telling us just who Natalie is.

—As I have indicated, the forest policy of the Commonwealth government and the forest policy of the mainland state governments is the same. It is the national forest policy statement. This government is serious about its implementation. As we look at its implementation, we do not forget the fact that there are significant conservation elements of that policy. We are committed to progressing those elements as well as the other aspects of the policy in order to ensure that we have a balance in the forest debate and a balanced forest policy in Australia.

—I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs to the continuing human tragedy in Rwanda and fears that the slaughter which decimated Rwanda can occur in neighbouring Burundi. Is the minister aware that the Tutsi dominated party for national progress in Burundi has called for the overthrow of the coalition government? Could the minister report to the Senate on the situation in Burundi and the possible moves by the United Nations Security Council to send a mission to Burundi?

—I suppose with all the emotion being generated by the woodchips issue it is a bit difficult for anyone to find any emotion to spare for the prospect of great violence and suffering in a small country far away. The response of the opposition demonstrates exactly that. The situation in Burundi is very worrying. We have all seen from the deeply tragic and appalling history of Rwanda what can happen when situations in exactly parallel social and political circumstances get out of hand. I think the failure of the international community to respond expeditiously and effectively to the situation in Rwanda should be one of the most appalling blots on the international conscience in recent decades. We ought to learn from that experience.

PARA.TAB: The situation in Burundi is very worrying indeed at the moment. The Australian government is aware of and deplores reports that the President of the Tutsi based Union for National Progress, or Uprona, has called for the resignation of Burundi's Prime Minister and for the overthrow of the coalition government of that country using `all necessary means'. That is a very alarming prospect. It is part of an ongoing pattern of instability which has been developing in the country. In December Uprona threatened to withdraw from a coalition with Burundi's other major political party, Frodebu, the Front for Democracy in Burundi. The government's collapse was only very narrowly averted at that time by the replacement of a controversial Hutu Speaker in parliament.

The UN Secretary-General's representative in Burundi, in Bujumbura, has described the situation at the moment as controllable but bad and deteriorating rapidly. It is possible that the parties could divide into separate factions. If this does occur, there is a very real prospect of widespread violence erupting, large population movements being generated and another massive humanitarian crisis occurring all over again.

What is happening internationally in response to this is occurring at three levels—and it is important to appreciate it—at the level of preventive diplomacy, preventive deployment and peace building. Preventive diplomacy efforts involve the UN Security Council issuing a presidential statement just a couple of days ago, on 31 January, denouncing attempts to overthrow the coalition government, condemning the extremist groups which continue to undermine it and calling on all parties to refrain from violence and give support to the government institutions which were established in line with the previous effort in preventive diplomacy under the convention of government of September last year. The Security Council also discussed a proposal to send a mission to Burundi as a follow-up to the mission in August last year but that is on hold at the moment.

In terms of preventive deployment, that is, the sending of military personnel for preventive purposes, the Secretary-General has proposed that there be UN guards installed in a humanitarian base at Bujumbura airport and a ready reaction force located in Zaire to intervene in Burundi if the situation deteriorates. That is still on the table of the UN in New York. In the view of the special representative the prospect of it is keeping some pressure on extremist elements. It is important to appreciate that that has not yet been the subject of actual decision.

The preventive diplomacy efforts involving diplomatic or political efforts or preventive deployment efforts of the kind I have just described are only part of the picture. It is very crucial if you are approaching the issue of prevention seriously in these sorts of internal situations to place effort on building effective governmental institutions and meeting the development, the social and economic needs of the country. To that extent Australia is doing its small bit—and I hasten to add it is only small at the moment—through earmarking a proportion, some $30,000, of our UN voluntary fund for human rights contribution for technical assistance to Burundi. Many more efforts of this kind by us as well as other countries need to be set in train if we are to make a difference at this stage.

We will certainly continue to monitor the situation closely and I hope that disaster there can be avoided. Finally, all of this does add weight to the Australian initiative before the UN General Assembly at the moment to introduce a major resolution on the subject of peace building and preventive diplomacy.
Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Further to a question from Senator Harradine yesterday about population programs in China, I have a long supplementary reply. I seek leave to incorporate that in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

ANSWER.PARA: 1. AIDAB regularly raises the issue of coercive family planning practices in its annual high-level discussions with the Chinese government, clearly setting out guidelines that all family-planning related programs Australia funds must comply with Australian government principles on population.
The most recent high-level consultations with China took place in Melbourne in September 1994.
These guidelines specify that family planning is to be voluntary and emphasise the need for quality of care in family planning service delivery.
AIDAB makes the same representations throughout the negotiation of individual projects.
With respect to Australia's two major family planning projects, we have concluded written agreements with the Chinese authorities guaranteeing that no coercive practices will be em ployed.

2. China's human rights performance is closely monitored by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade including the Human Rights Section. The human rights situation overall in China remains of concern to Australia and this Government has expressed its concern about human rights in China on numerous occasions. In addition to multilateral efforts to foster observance of internationally accepted standards of human rights in China I have raised the Australian Government's concerns about continuing human rights violations at the highest levels, including during discussions with Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen in Jakarta in November 1994.

Australia's obligation under the 1951 Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees is to provide protection to those with a well-founded fear of persecution due to their nationality, race, religion, political opinion or membership of a particular social group. Under the Convention, there is no obligation to provide refuge to those who are subject to generalised policies applicable to all citizens without discrimination. The only obligation is to protect people who fear persecution because they belong to particular groups.

My Department, including the Human Rights Section, has been regularly consulted by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in the development of the amendments to the Migration Act before the Senate. The Department's assessment is that there is no evidence to suggest that returned asylum seekers will suffer any discrimination or persecution on their return to China.

In relation to Senator Harradine's concern about the possibility of a pregnant woman asylum seeker being returned to China, it is longstanding government policy that the return of people with no right to remain in Australia is only carried out where the returnee's safety and dignity is assured. This will apply to pregnant women.

I would point out that the application of China's one-child policy does not generally provide for forced abortions however in particular provinces or villages there may be an application of the policy which differs from central Government directives and a risk of forced abortion may exist.

The Migration Act amendment legislation provides only that fertility control policies shall not be taken into account in refugee applications where they are argued as the basis for establishing the applicant's membership of a particular social group.

However, where a Chinese refugee applicant is a member of a pre-existing social group, such as an inhabitant of a particular village or province or a member of a particular factory or work unit in which fertility control policies are carried out in a persecutory manner—such as by the practice of forced abortion—they are not excluded from the protection of the legislation. This is because they fear persecution on the basis of their membership of a social group other than the unacceptably broad group of "Chinese subject to fertility control policies."

I further understand the Act allows for a non-compellable Ministerial discretion in particular circumstances to allow individuals to make applications for refugee status despite their initial exclusion by other provisions.
The Act also contains health provisions which would preclude travel by any women in an advanced stage of pregnancy.
3. Australia supplied 105 ultrasound machines to China in 1991/92—and stands by that decision.
The fact that ultrasound technology can be misused should not be allowed to overshadow the legitimate and highly beneficial role it can play
in improving the health and welfare of pregnant women and their children.

Many family planning facilities in China have access to ultrasound equipment—an article in The Economist, September 18, 1993, reported that medical equipment factories in China manufacture 10,000 ultrasound machines a year.
Consequently most family planning facilities in China have access to ultrasound equipment very little of it sourced in Australia.
China's family planning regulations prohibit the use of ultrasound for the purposes of gender selection.

It is clearly not possible for the Chinese government to police the use of every machine, particularly those which are in the hands of medical practitioners and/or health workers who are outside the public health system.

Enquiries confirmed that Australian machines provided under DIFF funding were distributed to major health and research institutions where their usage is most likely to be monitored to ensure compliance with family planning regulations.
Discussions were held with the Australian supplier and Chinese end-user prior to approval of DIFF funding and since regarding the uses to which the Australian manufactured machines would be put.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Coulter asked me what the government was doing to ensure that there is an expansion of plantation forestry in Australia. I have a reply given to me by Senator Collins, representing the Minister for Resources. I seek leave to incorporate that in Hansard as well.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

ANSWER.PARA: A key goal of the national forest policy statement is to expand Australia's commercial plantations so as to provide an additional, economically viable, reliable and high quality wood resource for industry.

One of the government's objectives under this policy is to promote an increase in commercial plantation development on cleared agricultural land and, where possible, to integrate plantation enterprises with other agricultural land uses.

The government is encouraging plantation development through funding allocated to the farm forestry program ($3.7 million) and the north Queensland community rainforest reforestation program ($4.2 million) over the period 1992-93 to 1995-96.
Under these programs support is being provided for the development of demonstration plantings, dissemination of information, training and extension activities, and industry and community development.

Under the north Queensland program additional support has been provided through the government's landcare and environment action program to provide training and work experience for about 250 young unemployed.

Support has also been provided for a number of more strategic projects relating to training, genetic improvement of the hardwood resource base, improving commercial links between landholders, investors and the wood processing industry, and developing economic models to enable landholders to evaluate the potential returns from plantation development.
The government, through the Australian Taxation Office, is also seeking to clarify the taxation treatment of private forestry.
A comprehensive public ruling is expected to be released within the next few months.
Once the final ruling has been released, the government will consider the need for any policy changes.

The government has also been providing funds for research and development into plantations and agroforestry through the Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation and the Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation.
Funding for a plantations study has also been provided to Environment Victoria through the Environment, Sport and Territories portfolio.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the Senate yesterday Senator Gibson asked me several questions about a species of eucalypt in East Gippsland known as eucalyptus denticulata. I now have an answer to the senator's questions.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the senator's first question, I can confirm that I did write to the Hon. Geoff Coleman, MLA, the Victorian Minister for Natural Resources, on 17 October 1994. The subject of the letter was the logging of the Hensleigh Creek catchment in East Gippsland and the preliminary results of an evaluation of conservation value of this area undertaken by my department. In the letter the Hensleigh Creek catchment is identified as having a number of values, including the presence of eucalyptus denticulata.

In regard to the supplementary question asked by Senator Gibson, I can provide the following information from the National Herbarium on the eucalypt. The Errinundra shining gum eucalyptus denticulata was identified and described as a separate species in 1991 and is accepted by the botanical community as being quite discrete from the more widespread shining gum eucalyptus nitens. The Errinundra shining gum can be readily distinguished by the peculiarities of the structure of the leaves and flower buds as well as having a shorter, juvenile phase of growth.

TALK.START.PARA: —What's the difference?

—I have just explained that. The distribution of eucalyptus denticulata is not certainly known but appears to be restricted to relatively high altitude forests near the Victorian-New South Wales border. Until more study can be carried out to clarify the actual range and conservation status of the species, it is clearly important to safeguard known populations. This includes stands occurring in coupes identified for rescheduling in East Gippsland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner), to a question without notice asked by Senator Ian Macdonald this day, relating to logging and woodchipping.

SPEECH.PARA: For the past two or three days the opposition has had a concerted effort in relation to asking questions relating to this very important issue. Indeed, yesterday we led off our questions by asking about the problems with the trade deficit. Of course, the industry that is represented outside this place provides a lot of assistance to lowering our economic problems. But what government members have done is refused to answer the questions put to them by the opposition. Indeed, yesterday when we sought to extend question time so more questions could be asked they ran away because they did not want to have any more questions asked.

PARA.TAB: The simple fact is that the minister for the environment has not told—and, indeed, refuses to tell—the people of Australia why over $100,000 of taxpayers' funds was given to a mickey mouse organisation to provide a report on which he relied and which is now shown to be absolutely and utterly flawed. He keeps pontificating in this place about high conservation values, how the process was so absolutely and utterly rigorous, that it could be absolutely relied upon, and that he relied upon such credible sources as Natalie, but he has refused to answer who or what Natalie is or may be for the past two days.

Why doesn't the minister give an answer to the very important question relating to why the list of 1,300 coupes that he said had been through this rigorous process has now been cut right down to 511. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating), in trying to come in and fix it, told us the figure was 509. But when we count them we realise there are 511. So the government, in its haste, cannot even count the coupes that it is talking about. When we look at those 511 coupes we see that some of them had been clear-felled as little as three months ago in places including my home state of Tasmania. Today Senator Crane and Senator Brownhill gave examples of places in their states of Western Australia and New South Wales. This is an absolute farce. It has occurred in absolutely every state of Australia. It is appropriate that this house, the states house, should seek to defend the rights of states to manage their forest industries properly.

What the government has now done is ensure that all this chippable wood will not be exported and will not provide jobs. But the trees will be felled anyway. As the Tasmanian Premier and the ACTU, the alleged senior partner of this government, have said, the trees will be felled anyway. What will happen to all this wood? The good economic sense will dictate that it rots on the forest floor instead of providing jobs and export dollars for this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —More fuel for fires.

—As Senator Calvert so correctly assists me, it will add more fuel for fires, which undoubtedly will do even greater damage to the environment, in such areas as the quarries, the airfields and the clear-felled areas that Senator Faulkner has told us are of such great importance.

PARA.TAB: The important thing any industry requires is certainty so that people can invest, employ and provide a future for themselves, their families and their communities. It was so very interesting to hear today Senator Faulkner talk about all sorts of things other than the human element, the human dynamic, in this debate. The Labor government has absolutely lost touch with the human element in this debate. Senator Faulkner ought to get out of Canberra, see the Picton, see the examples used by Senator Crane and Senator Brownhill and see what his department has done to this great industry.

The people of Australia will no longer accept the obfuscation and refusal to answer by this minister. He has to be made responsible, as should the Prime Minister, who so ineptly stepped into this mess and is now up to his chin in it. I am sure they will try to clear it up but, every day it lingers, more jobs will be lost, more people will go bankrupt, more regional towns will close and Australia will hurt even more as a result of the disastrous policies of this Labor government. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was going to move to take note of the answer given by Senator Faulkner to a question by me, but I consider the answer to Senator Ian Macdonald's question broad enough for me to cover the aspect I want to raise, and that is the incredible lack of knowledge of a minister who has made decisions that have effectively destroyed processes in this country that are near and dear to most of our hearts. I particularly refer to the fact that he has destroyed the conservation and environment value processes with regard to assessment in this country.

PARA.TAB: In taking note of this answer I particularly want to refer to my state, Western Australia. I wish to reiterate the facts about the AHC-CALM agreement in 1992—namely, that Western Australia signed with the states the 1992 agreement on national forest policy, that a proper assessment was carried out between AHC and CALM with regard to it, and that it covered not only forest values and what have you. The one area it did not cover—I am not arguing the case about whether or not there was a need to cover this in that assessment—is Aboriginal values. Can anybody tell me why you would give money to the conservation council in Western Australia if that is the only area that is not covered? These coupes must have been picked out by throwing a dart or something at the wall.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is unfair.

—That is how it was done. It was done no other way. You are going to find out more about this. You will also find out as a result of the study carried out in Western Australia, and it is here for you to read, that 49 per cent of the forest is now locked up in conservation or special reserves. I support that. I support it wholeheartedly. Fifty-one per cent is available for timber uses of a variety of types, but only one to two per cent is harvested on a year by year basis.

PARA.TAB: Where is the minister who walked out here a little while ago? Why doesn't he stay in this place and learn a little bit about the forest of this country—for which he has responsibility? Why doesn't he stay here and learn a little bit about it? We have to ask questions with regard to this whole matter. He said that, because there was a large area in terms of the proposals this year, they were not adequate; yet they were approved in the process in 1992. What if the situation last year were a bit smaller? What would he do in that particular circumstance? He does not know what he is doing in terms of his portfolio responsibilities. He is destroying absolutely and totally a process that has been worked out between Western Australia and the Commonwealth to deal with these particular aspects, a process which required enormous restructuring on the part of the industry in Western Australia in 1992.

Following that agreement, Whittakers of Western Australia invested almost $100 million under the new arrangements in those industries. That company has had it swept out from underneath it—just like that—to the point where it sought to have its shares suspended in trading on the stock exchange just two days ago. That is an incredible indictment of those opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the minister is not even here!

—No, he is not here. He walked out. We saw him go out. We invited him to stay and learn a little bit. If you cannot have faith in agreements which are signed between the various departments and parts of the state and the Commonwealth and they just unilaterally sweep them away, can we have faith in anything from this government? We can have absolutely no faith. The state can have no faith. It is not worth the paper that it is written on.

PARA.TAB: It is all because this man has not got control. He does not understand. The man who usually sits in that empty seat over there, which is occupied by Senator Faulkner occasionally, does not know what he is doing. Those opposite, many of them past union officials who would have supported jobs for the workers and those people out there, have walked away from them by their silence and lack of action. This is a real challenge to this government—whether or not it is going to become decent, get back and do things in a proper manner and take into consideration its agreements. It has just broken every principle in the book in dealing with this matter. It has made this country a laughing stock in terms of proper environmental and forest management.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —One picture is worth a thousand words. I have a picture taken from what is known as the Picton coupe 24C. You will see, on close examination of this picture, that it actually shows regrowth from a devastating bushfire. You can see the dead trees in the adjoining forest. I remind the Senate that 95 per cent of this coupe has actually been logged, yet the contractors, under direction from the government, are being prevented from returning to this area. I also remind you that sitting on this coupe are 30 tonnes of logs ready for transport. They are on the woodchipped area.

PARA.TAB: If you further look at this picture, you will notice that the high surrounding hills are not being logged and never will be logged above a certain altitude. Tasmania has some of the best forest practices in the world and we can see that from this picture. The tragedy is that forest workers are being locked out of this area by government decree. Today the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) would not even agree to contractors returning to work so that they can at least finish the remaining five per cent and clean up.

Tasmania is in the height of the bushfire season. You can see the problem in the picture. Arsonists are likely to get in that coupe, and not only could that area be fired but also the adjoining area with fires possibly sweeping into the top vegetated hills. This government decree is an irresponsible action that could result from the minister's decision. There is a need for an immediate return to work to clear up these areas where there is absolutely no high conservation value, as this picture shows. Urgent action must be taken.

I declare to the Senate that I am a small shareholder in North Ltd, a subsidiary of North Forest Products, which is one of the companies involved in forestry. The parent company is very concerned and has sent letters to its shareholders about some factually incorrect and misleading statements which are jeopardising workers' jobs at sawmills and the like. I want to quote a couple of extracts to put the correct position. The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: Effective forest practices in Tasmania have been development progressively over many years. Since 1971 there have been 17 formal government inquiries into forestry in Tasmania in which the industry has been subject to the most rigorous—
not the Natalie-type assessments—

environmental assessment. Tasmania retains more than 80 per cent of its original forest cover as estimated prior to European settlement. The land that no longer contains forest has in the main been converted into farm pasture and urban development. Of the forests in Tasmania more than 30 per cent are currently protected from commercial forestry and 30 per cent is managed for multiple use including wood production and recreation with the remaining forest being on private land. Of the multiple use forests available for the forest industry, less than one per cent is harvested in any one year and those areas that are harvested are regenerated under the supervision of the forestry commission.

Let us get back to this picture that I am showing to honourable senators. Normally this logged area would be controlled and supervised by the contractors. In late autumn there would be a burn and the area would be regenerated. So in a few years we would have a young, vibrant forest replacing something that has been burnt. We could see this as an essential ingredient to proper management practices in Tasmania.

PARA.TAB: But the truth is that Australian forests are not disappearing, and that is the issue I want to leave with you today. These forests are being managed responsibly and will continue to be managed responsibly. I ask all honourable senators to dismiss all these lies about the sustainability of Australian forests, particularly in Tasmania. I seek leave to table that photograph and a publication by North Forest Products entitled, How much do you know about woodchips?
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am rather surprised at the double standards of the opposition with respect to this question. We heard today the figures for the extent to which the public purse has actually underwritten and subsidised forestry throughout Australia. Taking the example of Tasmania, only a couple of years ago the Tasmanian government wrote off $450 million worth of accumulated debt by the Tasmanian Forestry Commission. Here we have in the opposition a group of people dedicated to the idea of unfettered, unsupported free enterprise. Yet we have in forestry an industry which has soaked up an enormous amount of public financial support through the provision of infrastructure and through the inadequate payment by forestry commissions and forestry companies of the—
—What's massive?

—Over $1,000 for every man, woman and child in Tasmania. You evidently support that. That is very inconsistent with your normal stand. Secondly, the opposition seems to be arguing that if an area is damaged in any way whatsoever then it is okay to go in and damage it further. This is to argue that if a person is raped it is okay to rape them again. If I break Senator Ian Macdonald's right arm, I could go in and break his left arm. That is a non sequitur. It is a stupid argument that the opposition is using.

PARA.TAB: There are areas which have been damaged which, perhaps because they are contiguous with an area of high conservation value, are themselves important to be protected. One looks forward to the day when there will be a proper, conserved area of forests in Australia. This may indeed involve areas which currently have been damaged in some way. The fact that those values have in any way been impeached in the past, even in the recent past, is not an argument that these areas should not be protected.

We heard from Senator Abetz a short time ago a lot of absolute nonsense about the way in which only the waste is used and about the way forestry workers clean up the forest floor, preventing bushfire. I have been in forests which have been clear-felled and cut down from North Queensland down to Tasmania, from Victoria and New South Wales through to Western Australia. In every case, massive amounts of timber have been left on the forest floor.

I remember going in Tasmania to the edge of the World Heritage area on the Great Western Tiers—a steep slope which had been clear-felled only a few weeks beforehand and then burnt by the forestry people. It contained logs well over 60 centimetres in diameter and 15 or 20 feet long. This was some months ago. That is exactly the situation that obtains, as I indicated yesterday, because the structure of the industry ties the poor devils who have the logging rigs to taking the maximum weight of logs out of the forest. It is not economic for them to pick up all the smaller branches and other material which could be chipped. So the claim that all this material is going into chips is a nonsense. It is simply untrue.

Finally, I pick up the answer of the minister today. He said to me that these 509 coupes contain one-fifteenth of one per cent of Australia's forested area, or half of one per cent of the area available for forestry. I stress: if the forestry industry needs to go into this minuscule proportion so urgently, then it follows very logically that this industry is basically unsustainable.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) to Senator Ian Macdonald's question. I would like to take note of the minister's answer to my question but the only problem is I got a non-answer and it is pretty hard to take note of a non-answer.

PARA.TAB: Senator Macdonald's question said that we have been blatantly misled by the minister's insisting that he has been rigorous in identifying the forests of high conservation values. The minister has been absolutely blatantly misleading the Senate as he does not really know anything about the coupes; he does not know anything about the compartments. It is interesting that in one of his answers to me he was talking about coupes. A coupe is a part of a compartment; a compartment is not a part of a coupe. Basically I think he needs to get his phraseology right to start with.

In answering my question and a lot of previous questions he tried to outline a number of factors in respect of what is deemed as high conservation, including old-growth areas, endangered species, world heritage, areas of high biodiversity, significant Aboriginal sites et cetera. But how then, I ask the minister, can the government assess an area that was logged in the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s as having those characteristics?

He also mentioned in answering my question—or not answering, I should say—that he was waiting on the cooperation of the New South Wales government. The fact is that the New South Wales Premier, John Fahey, has written to the minister six times to establish a definition of the methodology to be used to determine high conservation.

So the fault lies back here with the Commonwealth government. The fact is that it has been sitting on its hands. While it has been sitting on its hands, we have people around this building today, and it is costing them a fortune to be here. One person told me that it was costing him $1,000 a day for his lorries to be here to protest. He should not even have to be here. But he is concerned because it is hurting his village, the long-term jobs and the livelihood of people in that village. The towns are having problems; it has all been said before.

Basically this minister has to do something to fix things up. He was not quite the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories today; he was the minister for the environment minus woodchips today because woodchips have now been given to Senator Collins. So I wonder what will happen next week. Maybe another bit of his portfolio might be chopped off. It is a rehash of the environmental portfolio when I think Mrs Kelly was minister? Yes, I think she was the minister for environment or something, and she seemed to fall by the wayside. Now this minister is making the same mistakes that Mrs Kelly made; he is not getting the facts right before a decision is made.

The thrust of my question, which I failed to get an answer to, was to establish the characteristics of the Pappinbarra State Forest, which the minister considers important enough to declare as a high conservation area. You only have to call the office of the chief forester in the area to get the whole forest history of Pappinbarra and to find out that timber has been continually extracted from the area since 1924. How could that area have high conservation value if that is happening? It really astounds me that the minister has not looked into it. How can a forest that has been extensively logged for so many years now have a high conservation value?

I would like to see the minister walk outside the front of this building and speak with some of the timber workers who work up in that particular area. I wonder whether he could look those people in the eye and say, `No, you may no longer extract timber from Pappinbarra forest where you have been extracting timber since 1924; I've decided it is of high conservation value.' Basically, that is what it is all about.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—do not let the Prime Minister get off the hook—was in concert with this minister, who did not get his facts right from people like Natalie and others who gave the advice. Surely he should have done it a bit better. I think he stands condemned for that. I do not think he answered the questions on forestry that have been asked over the last few days. None of the questions have been answered properly. I think he stands condemned by the whole community, especially the community in those country areas.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Jones this day, relating to Rwanda and Burundi.

SPEECH.PARA: In so moving, I would draw the notice of Senator Evans to a letter I received last week from a Care Australia worker. When I returned from Rwanda, I went to see Senator Evans and spoke to him about the security position in the Katale area of Zaire where I had been. I said to him that I had seen a deteriorating position, and I thanked him for his interest at the time. The letter states:
We were targeted by the Zairean military. They shot around 500 rounds from machine-guns and kalashnikovs into the health and information team out-patient and Care clinical areas—
that was where I was working—

at 10 a.m. one morning. Eighteen people were shot and two killed, including an orphan. The only reason we weren't in those tents was that we couldn't get through the roadblocks. The majority of those shot were our national staff. We huddled on the floor of house two—
that was where we lived in the Rutshuru village about seven kilometres north of the area—
that day as the drunken soldiers fired machine-guns in the lanes around us. The house was later completely destroyed.
I bring that to the notice of Senator Evans because, in so far as I saw somewhere there had been a security incident, I am not aware of any report of that in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Recently we spent, I understand, over $1 million of taxpayers' money rescuing one French woman sailor whose ship got into trouble. I wonder whether any action has been taken or any procedure is available whereby Australian workers can be evacuated from that area. It is about 20 minutes by helicopter from Kigali, the capital. This is the first time that I have become aware that the security incident there was of such a major nature.

The Care Australia worker goes on in this letter to tell me that they formed a convoy that night with other aid organisations. In particular, he said that apparently Care Australia has become a target now for not only Zairean military but Hutu soldiers; they believe that the continuation of support there is not in their interests as there is an attempt at rearming. For them to go back, as Senator Evans quite rightly knows, there may be a further armed conflict—not only from Burundi but Zaire itself.

I bring this matter to the attention of the Senate and Senator Evans to ask whether he is aware of this situation and whether any progress has been made on any possible evacuation of my colleagues who may well be there and in much more major incidents than have occurred in the past.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to Senator Herron for his continuing intense interest in the humanitarian situation in Rwanda in the border area, in Zaire and also, of course, in Burundi, which was the subject of my answer today. In particular, I acknowledge again the particular personal effort he has made in going there to work among the refugees in situations of extreme distress and for the continuing interest that he has taken.

PARA.TAB: I am only partially aware of the particular incident to which he refers because I have been on leave and overseas for the last few weeks. But I will certainly follow that up and give him such further information as I can, not only about that incident but also the general issue of policy he raises about the capacity that presently exists or might be put in train to evacuate NGO workers caught in these sorts of situations.

I think, once again, the point about the really still quite desperate situations in the refugee camps in the Zaire boarder area demonstrates acutely the need for intense preventive action in the situation in Burundi, in order to avoid some situation like this again exploding out of control and producing all the havoc in its wake that we are so unhappily familiar with in the context of Rwanda. But I thank Senator Herron again for raising the issue. I will do my best to reply as soon as I can.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the report of the Anglo-Australian Telescope Board was presented I was in the unfortunate position of having less than the usual five minutes in which to address the report. I will take this opportunity to make some concluding remarks about the report. It is one of the great shames of this place that one has so little time sometimes to deal with very important and very complex reports.

PARA.TAB: The work that is being done by the Anglo-Australian Telescope Board is complex, is of great scientific significance and will pay dividends over many years. The work done in photographing the Shoemaker-Levy comet as it approached Jupiter and the consequences of the collision between the fragments of that comet and the planet will probably provide research work for years to come by the people at the Anglo-Australian Telescope Board.

I think it is one of our great achievements that we have a telescope of this quality in the southern hemisphere. One should not underestimate the importance of the geographical positioning of the telescope. It means that certain areas of the sky that are not available for scrutiny from the northern hemisphere are available for scrutiny by our telescope, which we operate jointly with the British. That means that we have a unique opportunity, in some circumstances, to obtain scientific information in relation to what is happening not only in the solar system in our nearby region of the universe but also further out.

The work that was done by the Anglo-Australian Telescope Board in looking at the structure of the universe, the composition of galaxies and their arrangement in the universe is important for understanding theories about the origin of our universe. If the big bang theory is correct, you would expect the structure to be of a certain nature. By looking at the filamentary structure which is evident in the disposition of galaxies throughout the universe, we are given some idea of the forces which were involved in the creation of the universe. We are also given some clues as to how the universe is expected to continue to expand and maybe ultimately contract.

That work which has been done by the Anglo-Australian Telescope Board is of great significance. I believe that we should all be very proud of the scientists who work at the Anglo-Australian Telescope Board. Their work is of internationally high quality and, as Australians, we ought to thank them for the contribution which they are making to science around the world.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: The ANL annual report indicates that the company has made a loss of $129.6 million. The accounts show that $106 million of that loss was due to abnormal items. The outstanding thing under note 16 of the balance sheet of the company is a provision of $100 million this year compared with a provision of $16 million the previous year. There has also been a substantial writing down in the value of total non-current assets, which includes property, plant, equipment, et cetera.

PARA.TAB: The important thing for the Senate to note is that the net value of the assets of the company—the net shareholding value of the company on the balance sheet—is $26 million. As the auditor says in his report, the financial statements have been prepared on a going concern basis and that, therefore, on that basis this company did have a positive value. I contrast that with the comment of the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) on 22 August last year that ANL could not be given away. The report that he quoted then indicated that it had a negative value of between $70 and $118 million.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are getting stuck into Captain Bolitho lately.

—That is quite right. I also note in the annual report that the company had a write-off, a tax loss, of $14.7 million from the sale of 25 per cent of Australian Stevedores. That was a shareholding held by ANL. The government sold that shareholding against the recommendation of two boards of ANL—the first board under Chairman Bolitho, which was sacked on 22 August last year, and the new board under Neville Wran. Both recommended against the sale. They said that it was a very valuable asset, yet I note in the accounts that there was a $14.7 million write-off from that sale. So that needs to be investigated further.

PARA.TAB: Finally, we look forward to actually finding out what is behind these provisions of up to $100 million, particularly $78 million, mentioned in the accounts. The auditor, in signing off the accounts, qualifies it to the extent of saying that it is subject to the continuing financial support of the government and the effect of such adjustments or reclassifications which might result from any decisions taken by the board. In view of the fact that the Senate has referred the matter of the sale of ANL to a Senate inquiry, we can look forward to investigating those questions in the near future. We must get answers to them. In the end, I am sure that we will be condemning Minister Brereton for his handling of this matter, particularly when one considers that this is a public asset and he deliberately went out and devalued it by saying that it could not be given away.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)it is now 2 years since the Government drafted the National Forest Policy Statement,
(ii)this statement was, and continues to be, endorsed and supported by a wide cross-section of the forest industry, and

(iii)the chaos caused by the `three-ringed circus' of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in concert with the Minister for Resources (Mr Beddall) and the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner), is a direct result of the Federal Government's refusal to enact the National Forest Policy Statement and highlights the incompetence of those involved; and

PARA.TAB: (b)calls on the Government to implement immediately a consistent and sustainable policy for the resource sector.

SPEECH.PARA: Today we are debating a motion of which I gave notice in the Senate on Tuesday.

PARA.TAB: This week has exposed a motley bunch of divided, confused snake oil salesmen. This week Fagin has been caught out in a monstrous con. He has dumped on his ministers and left them to take the blame and the flak. And so they should. But the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is where the buck stops. He has to also take the blame. The truth, as the opposition has shown again and again, is that this government has no forest policy. It has ministers in charge of departments over which they have no control. It is interesting that today in question time Senator Faulkner lost the woodchip part of the debate from his portfolio and it has been taken up by Senator Collins. I could say it is a chip off the block. It is a real kick in the teeth for the Minister for the Environment that he has not been able to answer any of the questions.

These people have been making statements on policy that they know they cannot implement and have no conscience in seeing a valuable resource industry grind to a halt. The industry has had nowhere where to go. It has no security. This government has no concern for the real issues: jobs, people, towns, villages and livelihoods and the very existence of human beings in those areas. At a time when we have the biggest monthly current account deficit on record our export industries are being hijacked by ill-informed greenies bankrolled by a foppish environment minister who has used money provided by taxpayers. Some of those taxpayers are outside this building today and in the building—the forest workers.

We have a third rate three-ring circus in control in Canberra today. It used to be called the federal Labor government. It is Labor's loopy lightweights this week. In one ring the Prime Minister slinks around bullying his bodyguards to keep forest workers out of sight—`out of sight, out of mind', he says, making only one appearance in parliament to face the music. And what music it was. We have an environment minister who is not only incompetent but gullible and, who, having replaced a minister who let her department give her the mushroom treatment, knows no more about this portfolio than she did. He does not even have the whiteboards to blame. Why has he brought the timber industry to its knees? Why has he, in concert with the Prime Minister, allowed this to happen? We have a resources minister who is the salami in the sandwich but who is also so lacking in conscience that he sees nothing wrong in issuing licences one week and asking for them back the next.

There are a number of key elements to this debate. We have, on the one hand, the coalition asking again and again how the Minister for the Environment and/or the Prime Minister arrived at their first and second mythical list of sacrosanct areas and, on the other, the Minister for the Environment saying over and over again that they are all areas of high conservation value. We have a coalition exposing the list compartment after compartment, coupe after coupe, day after day and the only response from the government is that the list is based on the best advice. I would like to suggest that Natalie and others might not have given the best advice. I think they were in error with most of the advice they gave.

We have an industry worth something like $859 million, involving some 85,000 employees. They are just the direct ones; a heck of a lot more are tied up with the timber industry outside that. We have a timber import bill of $1.8 billion, a national balance of payments blowout of $28 billion, and hundreds of trucks worth millions of dollars lying idle around this building because their owners have no job security and all the federal Labor government can say is that it is not its fault.

Repeatedly this week the Minister for the Environment has tried to claim that this chaos is the fault of the state governments. Let me remind the Minister for the Environment if he does not already know—and on his track record anything is possible—that the New South Wales Premier on no less than six occasions and as recently as 24 January 1995 wrote to the Prime Minister seeking a definition of the methodology to be used to determine areas of high conservation value. With the debacle of the list as exposed this week it is obvious that a clear definition is urgently needed. The New South Wales state government is still awaiting what it requested nearly two years ago.

Had the Prime Minister provided those guidelines it would not have been necessary for the timber industry to grind to a halt and to come to Canberra. The security of the jobs ensuring that rural communities remain viable and the provision of valuable export dollars must surely be more important than attempting to shore up the greenie vote in the cities. We are talking about real lives. We are talking about real jobs. My colleague Senator Gibson summed it up well the other day when he said:

This whole thing was a sham, and the minister and the government know it. It was a deliberate move by the government to try to con suburban Melbourne and Sydney that it was supportive of Green sentiments. The government thought it could play one side of the coin as well as the other by renewing the licences. It thought it could get away with doing that. The demonstration outside this parliament by the people who are directly affected and the demonstrations that have been in Tasmania, Perth and in forest areas all around the nation show that it will not work.

SPEECH.PARA: Look at some of the people who have come here at great expense. One whole town—which I am sure Senator Troeth will talk about—in Victoria has completely closed up for people to come here. From my state of New South Wales people have come from the north, from the south east, from all the way up the coast. You would have to be a pretty heartless government—a pretty heartless person, Senator Ray—to sit there and not have a concern for those people who have no job security. We have enough people out of work in Australia as it is without putting another heap of people out of work.

PARA.TAB: What does the Prime Minister do? He believes that politics is just a game and that postulating in question time every once in a while is all that is required to lead this country. But this is no game.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—That is right. Senator Abetz has said it numerous times during debate in this place. This is no game. This is playing with people's lives. Look at those trucks out there, those prime movers. They cost $250,000 or $300,000 each. I would suggest that while those outside and inside this building today appear hale and hearty, there are a lot of very worried people among them. These trucks attract large repayments. These people do not have $300,000 to put into a truck thinking it will pay for itself sitting in a protest out here. They have come here in a very serious way to bring their point to the government, a government that I believe has been callous, especially the Prime Minister in the way he has approached this issue. The Minister for the Environment just does not know. People in the other place can make comments about Mr Beddall.

PARA.TAB: This is about people and lives. These lorries out here are expensive to maintain. Those people have to put food on the table for their families. I know what it is like. Everyone in this place has heard stories about the drought. It is another type of drought these people are experiencing at the moment. The owners of timber companies have wages to meet. They have bank managers to satisfy. They have to have business plans and cash flow projections to secure loans to keep their doors open. I mentioned earlier today that one truck owner told me that it is costing him over $1,000 a day just to have his five trucks here and to look after his men who drove the trucks up here. Spare a thought for them, minister. I hope that Senator Faulkner and the Prime Minister spare a thought for the callous way they have gone about taking the jobs away from these people.

With the system of yo-yo licensing this government is engaging in at the moment how can it possibly know what the income will be for these people? How will these people know what their income is going to be next week, or the week after, or next year? The situation is serious. It is not a game. It is time this government stopped playing with people's lives, with the financial security of the timber industry and with Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also refer to the national forest policy statement which was first drafted two years ago. This policy statement makes laudable environmental statements but it also canvasses basic economic objectives that should be and can be achieved by sustainable forest industry. The statement talks about efficient and effective management of the nation's resources and the contribution that forest based activities make to the national economy and regional and local employment.

PARA.TAB: The government vision—that is the word that is used—is supposed to encompass `a range of sustainable forest-based industries, founded on excellence and innovation'. I can tell you, and I can tell the Senate, that the number of forest based industries in my own state of Victoria do indeed possess those qualities of excellence and innovation but at the moment they are not being given any opportunity to use those qualities. These industries should be expanding to contribute further to regional and national economic employment growth.

According to the statement, forest management should be effective and responsive to the community. Perhaps Senator Faulkner could explain this part of the vision to the community of something like 3,000 timber workers and their families who are outside Parliament House at the moment and who have made the long trip to Canberra. It also states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian community will have a sound understanding of the values of forests and sustainable forest management, and will participate in decision-making processes relating to forest use and management.

Unfortunately, the 3,000 people outside Parliament House at the moment have no participation in the decision making process. They have found it necessary to leave their homes and their businesses to come to Canberra and make their opinions known because there is no way, except at the ballot box, they will be allowed to express an opinion otherwise. They would have gained no comfort from the Prime Minister's flippant remark `send me a letter' in response to the questions that they asked him yesterday morning. The policy statement continues:
The goal is for Australia to develop internationally competitive and ecologically sustainable wood production and wood products industries.
There is a worldwide shortage of hardwood products and no lack of markets overseas. Yet with the present uncertainty for the industry, how can we guarantee the continuity of exports?

PARA.TAB: Today in the other place, according to a statement that I have been given by Mr Anderson and Mr McLachlan, the government voted against allowing a motion moved by the coalition calling for the immediate implementation of the national forest policy. Today the coalition moved in the other place:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House, recognising the damage to regional economies and jobs, reaffirms its commitment to the national forest policy statement and requests the government to bring about its immediate implementation.

None of the five members who have been allegedly going to resign—they are government members—have the courage to stand up against the government's strongmen to bring about the implementation of the national forest policy statement.

PARA.TAB: This is just not good enough. Not only today's effort but also this shameful backdown has been preceded by at least two months of policy backflips by the government. In December 1994 Senator Faulkner advised Mr Beddall of 1,309 coupes and compartments of high conservation value. At the end of December Mr Beddall made his decision, in the week before Christmas—something like 22 December—Mr Keating announced the reschedule of the study of existing operations, and on 27 January 1995 Mr Keating identified 511, not 509 as is widely publicised, coupes and compartments for logging.

Another goal announced in the national forest policy statement is to `expand employment opportunities and the skills base of people working in forest management and forest-based industries'. What incentive is there for private enterprise to spend hard-earned capital on value adding equipment when the industry is in such a state of uncertainty? If management plans were implemented, as is advocated in the policy, it is anticipated that they would provide a set of operational requirements for wood harvesting and other commercial and non-commercial uses of forest areas. This would give the industry the certainty it deserves and needs. If the government thinks it is so important, why did it vote against implementing the national forest policy today?

The Labor members of the Senate and the House of Representatives who constitute the government have always taken pride in their supposed representation of the working man.
