Of the senators in this chamber, I would like to detail those senators from the other side of the chamber who were previously trade union members. Senator Burns was a member of the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union; you, Mr Acting Deputy President, were a member of the Printers Union; Minister Cook was a member of the WATLC, the BWIU and the ACTU; and Senator Chris Evans was a member of the Federated Miscellaneous Workers Union and the Fire Brigade Union.

Senator Foreman was a member of the South Australian branch of the Vehicle Builders Federation of Australia; Senator Forshaw was a member of the Australian Workers Union; Minister McMullan was a union official; Senator Neal was a member of the Federated Ironworkers Association; Senator Murphy was a member of the CFMEU, formerly the Australian Timber Workers Union; and Senator Sherry was a member of the Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Union. Senator Devereux, who was the National President of the Electrical Trades Union, is now sitting on the crossbenches because of his refusal to accept the government's decision.

I ask all of those senators: where do you stand on this question? Why aren't you showing your support for the timber workers? The ACTU has declared its support for the timber industry. Why can't you? The timber industry in this country is alive and well but there must be no loss of jobs while the industry and the government work out a consistent and sustainable policy. For the sake of the timber industry, I hope it is sooner rather than later.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have here for everyone to see, and we see them often enough, a $20 note. It is the last one left in my wallet for the week. At the bottom it is signed by the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia, Bernie Fraser, and reads, `This Australian note is legal tender throughout Australia and its territories'. That is what you are given in your pay, and that is the sort of tender overseas visitors are given when they change their foreign money into Australian money. They know that they can use that note to purchase whatever they want in Australia and it will be recognised. The Governor of the Reserve Bank signed that note, which is a contract that you can use against goods.

PARA.TAB: In my hand I have another contract, and it is called National Forest Policy Statement: A New Focus for Australia's Forests. Inside there is not the signature of the Governor of the Reserve Bank. No lowly person like him signed this one. There for you to see—and for Senator Murphy, who is smirking, to see—is the signature of none other than the Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Keating). The highest elected office holder in Australia has signed this contract, this agreement, alongside all the premiers of Australia, including the former Premier of Western Australia, Carmen Lawrence, leader of the disgraced government of Western Australia, fortunately replaced by Mr Court.

There are all the signatures of the highest elected people in the land, and this statement is not worth the paper it is written on. It seemed to be worth the paper it was written on until Mr Keating, seeing a few greenie lunatic votes going out the door, reversed the whole lot and revoked some licences. That is what the Australian Prime Minister's signature is worth; it is worth nothing. He is the highest elected person in the land.

Let us talk about the woodchipping companies. I should say `milling companies' because I believe it is a misnomer to call them `woodchipping companies' when you are talking about the public forests. I could not blame millers and woodchippers for carrying on, as I am sure they will when they eventually go away if they get something out of this government—although, the way things are going, that might take a while—milling and gathering wood under the basis of the old licences. The only licences which have been taken away are those for exporting woodchips. The rest of the arrangements must stay and the industry can carry on.

I cannot blame those people for continuing to woodchip, whether the government is prepared to renew the export licences or not. The only thing they can do if they want to continue chipping the waste material—I wish we could get through to the Greens that woodchipping comes from waste material and waste material alone—is continue to do so and make a stockpile. We can watch the mountains of woodchips grow as they chip the part of the logs that can be chipped. I doubt that the mountains of woodchips would ever grow as fast as the mountain of foreign debt that stands at about $150 billion to $160 billion at present. As our pile of woodchips grows, so too will the foreign debt grow. The only time that that mountain of foreign debt and that pile of woodchips will be removed is when this disgraced Labor government is defeated at the next election.

Letting a stockpile grow would immediately help to diminish all of the logs currently being wasted and get things going again. There would be universal support throughout Australia for that because, when Mr Keating ripped those export licences away, he did it right across Australia. He was fearful of a few greenie lunatic votes going out the door.

The Green movement claimed, and the government believed it, that all the forests in Australia are being mismanaged. I do not know whether any of them in other states are being mismanaged, but I do know one thing: the forests of Western Australia are not being mismanaged. If a state government is not managing its forests properly, the federal government should seek out that government, do something to it until it again starts abiding by the agreement that has now been disgraced and then let it have back its licences. But, no, what did Mr Keating do? He took the licences off everyone right around Australia. I do not know whether Tasmania, Victoria, New South Wales, Queensland or the Northern Territory are mismanaging their forests, but I do know that Western Australia is not. Let the Prime Minister find out which states are not managing their forests and give back the licences to the ones that are managing their forests properly. I believe all the states are managing them properly, but this is what happens when there is pressure from the lunatic Greens.

Let us now deal with the economics of this issue. I am not ashamed to admit that I am a dollar man. There has to be a way to make a dollar in any project that I look at, otherwise I will not be in it. The Greens claim, and the government believes them, that beautiful, straight jarrah and karri logs—I use Western Australian timber as an example—are being used for woodchipping. I have heard the Greens say that in this place.

With my rural and primary industry background, I know a bit about abattoirs. Our family grows some pretty good prime beef, but I have never known an abattoir to put prime beef into sausages. Has anyone else here known that to happen? If operators of an abattoir did that, they would be foolish. We can compare woodchips to sausages. Woodchips are only by-products from mills, just as sausages are from abattoirs. That is all they are. The lowest quality cuts go into sausages; they same is the case for woodchips.

What fool in the timber industry would use logs that are worth about $450 a tonne, which is what jarrah and karri logs are worth when they are delivered to the mill door, for woodchipping, making them worth about $45 a tonne? You would have to be an economic fool. I know that the Australian government at present cannot manage its economy, but even it would not manage the economy in that way. You would not use a log that is worth $450 a tonne or prime steak at $15 a kilo to make a by-product. It is as simple as that. That is the simplest economic lesson I could give anyone in this place. It is as simple as that. So why does the Green movement and the Australian government need to protect those logs?

TALK.START.PARA: —It doesn't take too many logs to make an opposition front bench.

—I would have thought Senator Murphy, being a representative for Tasmania and a union official, would support the forestry workers a bit more than that. The southern forests of Western Australia alone provide about 1,400 jobs and the industry is worth $50 million. The industry is about 40 per cent karri and 60 per cent jarrah. I know the Western Australian government, the Court government, looks after its forests. I know that forests are managed by people who have a four-year degree in forestry. I also know that it takes four years from the time you first look at a forest for logging to get it ready. I know that there is a ban on logging within 200 metres of either side of a creek, river or whatever. I know that you cannot log where there is more than a 15-degree slope.

PARA.TAB: Also, before any contractors are let in, so many trees with good seed are selected to be left standing to provide natural seed. I also know that CALM, the Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management, which controls our forests, appoints the contractors to fell the trees. They are dedicated contractors. They work for CALM only; CALM controls them. It is the same case with the dedicated contractors who serve the mills. So private enterprise is not admitted on its own into the public forests of Western Australia.

The logs are delivered to the landing and a price is charged. People may think that that is the end to where Western Australia controls its logs, but it is not. There is control beyond that landing. Seventy per cent of first-grade logs in Western Australia must go into value adding. There is a plan for the way to properly cut up logs using electronic controls. Then there is value adding and away it goes.

In the time that I have been given to speak on this issue, I hope I have shown this chamber that at least in Western Australia the forests are managed properly to ensure that it has a sustainable industry into the next century. Western Australia is logging areas that were logged between 1908 and 1920. These forests have been logged before, so you cannot say that my state is logging virgin forests. I could talk for a lot longer, but in the spirit of cooperation with my colleagues I will leave it at that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot let this debate go by without refuting some of the comments that Senator Panizza just made. Certainly a number of statements have been made in recent times. One of the most important ones is that there has been a lot of concern about the national forest policy. It was never an agreement that the conservation movement in Australia was happy with. It is interesting to note that the opposition is now so vehemently defending the national forest strategy when, in fact, part of that national forest strategy includes a moratorium clause—something which I have not heard anybody from the opposition benches mention.

PARA.TAB: There has also been a great deal of talk about what does get chipped and what does not get chipped. We heard comments yesterday and the day before about the fact that it is only the excess, the rubbish, that gets chipped. The information that is coming out is really amazing.

I have spoken to the unions involved and the people who are working in the forests in the south-west of Western Australia. They say they do cut down trees that are hundreds of years old, despite the comments from Senator Abetz that they never cut down 400-year-old trees. That is a nonsense statement. It is happening in Western Australia. They actually do not like cutting them down. They call them a name that relates to human excrement because they are not very good for their saw equipment. The loggers do not like cutting them down. They do not use them very much for sawlogs because they have all these dreadfully inconvenient knots and areas in the tree and because they are so old and so valuable as a habitat.

In the past couple of days those opposite have also told me that this is ridiculous. They have asked how I can stand up and say that 400-year-old trees, and those in excess of that age, are being used for woodchipping because trees hardly ever get to be 400 years old. All I can say is that it just shows how precious these environmental resources are—the ones that have survived to an age of 400 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you know that they are 400 years old?

—The opposition senators are appearing to act from a position of total ignorance, because there is any amount of evidence. I challenge them to talk to the people who have the photographs and can show them the exact age of the tree. I guess they do not know that it is quite easy to age a tree once it has been cut down because of the tree rings. Of course, there is ample photographic evidence that people who are cutting down trees for woodchipping are cutting down trees that are extremely old and that existed long before European settlement in Australia.

PARA.TAB: When you think about it, even people from the opposition benches, probably in their local community, would see that there is huge public outrage, and sometimes up to $200,000 or so spent, when a Moreton Bay fig is in the line of a building development. They will build walls around a Moreton Bay fig. They will build roads that curve around a Moreton Bay fig. Whilst I have nothing against Moreton Bay figs, I believe there are people in the opposition who have probably helped to save Moreton Bay figs in their own area. But what is the difference between a 100-year-old Moreton Bay fig that was grown by a European settler and a tree which may be in excess of 400 years old and which, in fact, is a very valuable habitat and was around hundreds of years before European settlement? The heritage value, the sheer value of life, of something that has managed to survive, and is still living for hundreds of years after it was originally a seedling, is not replaced by a blue gum plantation or something that is planted in a monoculture or something that is planted simply to provide the basis for sawlogs.

How can we talk about an industry being sustainable? The word in this motion is `sustainable'. If it is absolutely essential to gain access to old-growth forests more than a hundred years after the first access to old-growth forests in Australia, if it is absolutely essential for the industry to survive by continued access to old-growth forest, how on earth can anyone on that bench say that this industry is sustainable? How sustainable is it? How long does it take to grow a tree? Why do you still need access to old-growth forests over a hundred years after the forest industry has commenced operation? How can you call that sustainable? How can you regrow a 400-year-old tree? How can you do that and talk about ecological sustainability? How can you recreate an ecosystem by planting a plantation? If you use land that is being used for farmland currently, if you look at the prospects for agroforestry, if you look at how you can create win-win situations for jobs in the rural and regional areas, then you have the possibility for actually sounding credible in this argument.

Today, Senator Cook made a very pathetic attempt at responding to a question in relation to the balance of payments. I would like the members of the opposition bench and also the members of the right wing of the Labor Party—who, we know, are fighting behind closed doors as strongly as those members of the opposition who are sitting here today—to actually look closely at the figures that are available, to have the courage to look and see what the actual benefits of this industry to the Australian economy are. I do not mean the actual export figures. I am talking about the actual benefits to Australia's balance of payments. If, as many people are beginning to do, you calculate the industry's high and increasing capital intensity—and we heard today how we are importing more capital into Australia—its increasing reliance on imported fuels and other inputs, and its very high level of ownership from overseas sources, you will find that, with the subsidies that are available to this industry, we probably have a negative balance of payments.

The rationale for this is that, if there is a cut-back in our exports of woodchips, then, ironically, we may benefit our balance of payments and perhaps have the commonsense to shake ourselves and realise that, if we are going to benefit our balance of payments, we have to look at value-added industry. This does not mean, as Senator Abetz is suggesting, that we put the most environmentally atrocious whacking great pulp mill at Wesley Vale. It does not mean, as some people would suggest, the biggest possible pulp mill in the middle of the south-west. It means using your heads. It means talking to the communities. It means talking to those people in the various communities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where do you put it?

—Senator Sherry said, `Where do you do you put it?' The answer is that you put it in a number of places. You do not just look for the biggest possible pulp mill for which there is no immediate market. What you do is look at the particular region. You look at the markets that are available for particular products. You look at the boutique markets for those kinds of products of pulp, if that is what you are producing. You also look at the number of people whose jobs are threatened.

PARA.TAB: We have heard talk about the number of people who are associated with the industry, but we also know that the number of people actually working at cutting down and chipping trees is small in comparison to the number of people who are totally involved in the kinds of industries that rely on the forest as a living entity. Old-growth forest as a living entity means an environmental and ecological resource, a tourist resource, a small industry, a business resource, a service industry resource and accommodation and so on. Every time you destroy an old-growth forest which is the resource for those industries, because of the spread effects which are much higher in those industries which rely on the continuing existence of old-growth forests, then the number of jobs which may be impacted now and in the future is much greater than were ever in chipping and logging for woodchip exports. There is no doubt about this. Anybody who is honest enough to look at the figures will know that this is true.

The green movement is not after the jobs of the people in the forest industry. Everybody who is willing to look at commonsense will know that these jobs cannot continue in woodchipping for exports because of the fact that Japan will not continue to buy Australian woodchips after markets come on line from other countries. I know that it has been pointed out that a portion of the woodchips from Australia do not go overseas, and that means those jobs, obviously, will continue. If we continue to put our heads in the sand and assume that the only way this industry can survive is to continue to try to sell export woodchips to Japan and other countries like that, we are being ridiculously naive.

We have to sit down and talk. Instead of this crash-or-crash-through approach, we have to sit down and talk about the various values. It is not just a resource for a resource sector. It is a forestry resource which has values in a number of different ways. They include ecological values which cannot be replaced simply by replanting a plantation. They include the values of those people who work in those industries which require the continued existence of those old-growth forests. Go down any time you like and talk to those people in Pemberton who rely on those old-growth forests for their continued existence.

TALK.START.PARA: —What for?

—Talk to those people who find that the forest residue is being burnt because the woodchippers and those people who are logging the forest will not let them get to it and use it. There are jobs in the south-west of Western Australia which could be producing jobs for hundreds of more people and the access to those jobs is being taken away by those people who assume that the state forests belong to the companies which have a licence to log them.
—That's a lie, and you know it.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, what I have said has been called a lie. I wonder whether you think that is unparliamentary?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—Senator Panizza, Senator Margetts has objected to your inference that she is a liar.

TALK.START.PARA: —By way of explanation, Mr Deputy President, I did not say that she was a liar. I said that what she said was a lie and that she knows it. I do not believe that is calling her a liar.

—I have ignored some of the interjections that were made on my left earlier, which I could have interpreted rigorously as reflections on honourable senators. You would assist the chair if you withdrew your remark. Senator Margetts has objected because she has taken the words you have used to imply that she has told a lie.
—I withdraw.

—Thank you. The situation is that the forests in Australia that are being logged, apart from privately owned forests, belong to all of the people of Australia. The people of Australia are concerned about jobs; but they are also concerned that any industry which is using a resource that belongs to them uses it in such a way as to have care for the future as well as the present. In the last two days I have been asked, `What's the use of a 400-year-old tree that happens to be in a paddock? Why not cut it down?' There are many uses. I am very disturbed that there are people who would say that there is no use for a tree that has existed for 400 years.

PARA.TAB: I invite anybody who does not actually believe that knotted trees or gnarled karri trees are being woodchipped to go and find out. If it is true that you do not care or that you actually believe there is no value in something that has been in existence during times we can only read about in history books and which has survived for hundreds of years, then be honest enough to say publicly that there is no intrinsic, special heritage value in some living organism that continues to be in existence after several hundred years.

If that is what opposition senators are saying, then that is what they have to admit to the Australian public. Do not try to say, `Yes, this industry is sustainable,' and, `No, it's not going to have an impact on the forest' at the same time as saying, `There is no value to something that has managed to exist in a living form for over 400 years.' I know that not every log that has been woodchipped is 400-years-old, but I know that there is sufficient evidence that sufficient high value old-growth forest is being included in the current woodchipping.

It has been clearly demonstrated in question after question by the Greens in the estimates process that the reality is that, despite whatever rhetoric there is in the forest policy statement, there is no body that has been making sure that the conditions of licences are kept to. The states say that it is a federal role and the federal government says that it is the states' role. Therefore, the many values—not just the values to the woodchipper—have not been able to be maintained because no body has been supervising the licence conditions. Whatever you say about management to the highest level, it has not been supervised in Australia.

If you are going to talk about a sustainable industry, resources and resource security, then talk about the full values. Even the economic values do not add up. It is time for everybody to be honest. If the opposition does not care about living forests that have been around, sometimes for hundreds of years, if it does not care that the last vestiges of life in those forms are being wiped out for a very temporary profit, say it. The opposition should say, `This is what we care about: we care about the short-term profits; we care about making the industry happy for now; we don't care about the future of even their jobs; we don't care about the future of anybody's job that actually depends on the forests remaining where they are, which is our biggest export job grower.' Our biggest export job grower is actually tourism in Australia.

If the opposition does not care about those jobs, it should be honest enough to say, `We don't care about those jobs; we only care about the short-term solution for one industry which is largely owned by overseas interests and whose profits are going overseas.' If that is what you want—a big export of profits—that is what you are going to get. That is what you will continue to get if you close your eyes and think, `All we want is to gain continued access to unique ecological resources in this country.' This is what the debate is about. All other values have been forgotten. The only value that has been coming up again and again is a misplaced and miscalculated value for the dollar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Looking at Senator Brownhill's motion, I readily agree with part 1 of his statement of fact that it is now two years since the government drafted the national forest policy statement. Part 2 states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . this statement was, and continues to be, endorsed and supported by a wide cross-section of the forest industry—
I will not disagree with that. Part 3 states:
. . . the chaos caused by the `three-ringed' circus—
that is a bit of parliamentary nonsense that I will allow him to get away with—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not nonsense; just a fact.
—Senator Brownhill, I will not dispute you on that description. Part 3 continues:

SPEECH.PARA: of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in concert with the Minister for Resources (Mr Beddall) and the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner), is a direct result of the Federal Government's refusal to enact the National Forest Policy Statement and highlights the incompetence of those involved—
I will dispute what it is a direct result of.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you are not worried about their competence.

—I would really appreciate it if you would listen; then you may understand what I am trying to help you with. I will seek to amend the motion to suggest that the three-ringed circus, as described, is a direct result of the federal government's failure to follow the proper licensing process. The Minister for Resources (Mr Beddall) made a mistake. He displayed his incompetence.

PARA.TAB: The Federal Court has confirmed that and has found him guilty of not following the process required by the law of this land. That is a fact—not an opinion—and has caused what we see today. It has caused this debate to occur and it has caused the trauma—there is no other word; it is the accurate description—of the situation where this place is ringed by people who are concerned about their jobs and people who are concerned about the process which delivered this chaos. I will be seeking to amend the motion to make that point clear because I think it more accurately describes the situation we have.

If we were to follow Senator Brownhill's lead and look at the national forest policy itself, we should easily understand that part of the implementation of it is to explain it and accurately describe it to the nation. That, most apparently, has not occurred. That has not been done. The government has failed in that responsibility.

It is not surprising, because we have seen time and time again instances where this government thinks it is sufficient to chuck out a few words, to give the people a dose of rhetoric. There is a list of them, starting with that one about no child living in poverty and going down to some of the terminology we see in this national forest policy statement.

Having chucked out that sort of rhetoric, the government has a track record of sitting back and blaming everybody else when nothing happens. I think it is most apparent that this government has the capacity to enforce its own policy. It could get on and actually do it instead of just saying that it exists and then blaming everybody else for it not occurring.

The government has the capacity to enforce its own policy and it cannot use the same old excuse all the time and get away with it—it has not got away with it this time—that it is the states' fault, that they are supposed to come along and sign something, agree to something or have a discussion, a summit or a COAG meeting. That is a tired excuse.

This government has been advised that it has the corporations power, the export regulations power, the world heritage properties protection act, the Endangered Species Act and the Australian Nature Conservation Agency establishment legislation. The power is there, but where is the will? Where is the will to enforce what it has in its own policy? Those powers could be used to enforce the relevant sections of the national forest policy, yet we see procrastination and deliberate obfuscation. We see the shuffling of responsibility and the finger pointing in any direction but where it belongs—back to the federal government itself. The government really cannot any longer hide behind the deception that there are others to blame. It has a responsibility to use all of the authorities and opportunities at its disposal. If this policy is so good, let us see it in action.

The other responsibility the government has is to explain its policies and to define the terms and assumptions upon which its policies are based. I agree with Senator Troeth, who earlier in this debate made a contribution which I thought was quite enlightening. Part of the national forest policy statement says something along the lines, according to her quote, that the Australian community will have a sound understanding and will participate in the decision making. That has demonstrably not occurred. The national forest policy also states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . until the assessments are completed, forest management agencies will avoid activities that may significantly affect those areas of old-growth forest or wilderness that are likely to have high conservation value.

That was signed by all states. What do we see happening? We see Senator Faulkner recommending, rightly or wrongly—that is not the dispute at the moment—approximately 1,300 areas that had old growth forest or wilderness value and we see him being ignored. The Prime Minister, on another occasion and for other reasons, set aside 509 or 511 coupes—it does not really matter—as having high conservation wilderness value and the state governments of Victoria, Tasmania and New South Wales are ignoring that.

PARA.TAB: We have the federal government blaming the states for not coming to the party with this policy. We have the states signing something and then we have them walking away from their own signatures. In fact, it seems that the unions and the Tasmanian and Victorian governments are saying that they will target some of those areas as a matter of priority. They are saying that they will target old growth and wilderness forests. What sort of government is that? It is not responsible government; it is feral government. There is no other way of describing it.

That is the sort of determination that you see in children. If they cannot have their lollies as they want, you see them throwing them away so nobody else can have them. You see them doing all sorts of childish things, out of control, when their initial desires are denied. We are told that these people—they are proud of the announcement—will speed up the utter desecration of our unique and precious forest. It is a crying shame and an international disgrace, and we should not allow such people to be in govern ment.

I think we have demonstrated already that the national forest policy statement is a worthless document. The government does not want to implement it. The states that signed it want to do something else in defiance of it. They are flagrantly disobeying its conservation intent.

The silly thing about it is that, properly enforced, the national forest policy statement would in fact be a sort of resource security on the sly. Here we have the government, which was so hell-bent on establishing that process, and some of the state governments that thought it was such a good idea disobeying that very policy which could bring about their much wanted direction of a few years ago.

The policy itself is industry oriented and the process is to create regional forestry agreements. It would effectively guarantee supply. We should guarantee supply to sustainable, viable and vital industry, but we do not really know whether that is what we have got. Parts of this industry could be viable, vital, lively and useful. Other parts are patently not. They cannot be continued. They are not sustainable and we do not really know where they fit. We have various contentions and assertions about the value of various sectors of the industry, but we do not have the information. We are told with various degrees of accuracy of the level of export income that we receive from woodchips, but we do not really know because the government has not taken the proper responsibility to properly define exactly how much of those exports are obtained from what is really waste material and what is obtained in other ways.

There are great problems in the definitional side of this whole national forest policy statement and its translation on the ground in the bush. We do not really know enough about this to be debating in a fully informed way. The debate has degenerated into sloganism and into mutual insult sessions. We need the government to show the leadership, to properly define the terms we use for debate.

What really is `sustainable'? Is `sustainable' using up the forests as fast as humanly possible while putting the country into debt and adding to environmental damage? Is it sustainable to wilfully ignore parts of the national forestry policy statement and emphasise others? Is it sustainable to propose to exploit these coupes while possible in flagrant disregard of what has already been signed by states?

I would like to make a contribution to this debate about sustainability. A recent report released by Dr Andrew Dragun, senior lecturer in law, economics and public policy at La Trobe University, found that the Victorian government directly spent $90 million on logging for a return of $40 million. In other words, the Victorian taxpayer subsidised the industry to the tune of $50 million a year. Dr Dragun goes further and suggests that when all of the costs are taken into account, a more reasonable estimate of the annual subsidy could be of the order of $385 million. That is a contribution to the debate. I would like to see the dispute to that or see other suggestions which challenge or confirm. I think we need to be debating exactly what is meant by these terms.

We know some of the facts. We have seen them displayed over the years. The combined debts of all the forestry commissions—I say commissions; it is not a mistake for the corporations that exist in some other states—which operated over a number of years is $5 billion or so. That amount consists of debts as follows: Queensland, $1.666 billion; New South Wales, $1.121 billion; Victoria, $1.178 billion; Tasmania, $565 million; and Western Australia $481 million. Only South Australia ever operated a profitable forestry service. It is not surprising that South Australia's debt is so low. Ninety per cent of its sawlogs are sourced from softwood plantations.

Consulting economist Mr Francis Grey has identified 23 types of effective subsidy to the industry, which could include things like low royalties, state government subsidies, possible exemptions, roading, various infrastructure, port facilities, forestry commissions, not paying monitoring fees, diesel subsidies and others. There are also accusations of rorts and efficiencies that I will not go into now. I have told parliament previously about these sorts of things.

It makes good economic sense to keep our native forests intact. Senator Margetts has explored that area quite considerably. Not only do they provide a habitat for endangered species—and I am reminded here of an instance that Senator Coulter reminded me of earlier today. He visited an area near the Tantawangalo forest in south-east New South Wales from which 22,000 koalas had been shot and removed in the 1920s. Obviously that was an area of koala habitat which was extensive and successful and had got to the stage where the population was quite intense.

Recently the New South Wales Forestry Commission did not define that area as a koala habitat because there were no koalas there. Obviously there was no examination of the degree of suitability of the habitat. It was a koala habitat; it had been a successful koala habitat. It would obviously suit koalas in the future. When we mention koalas we often do it in a offhand way, but I am talking about a national icon; I am talking about one of Australia's symbols. If we remove its habitat because we are incapable of recognising what its habitat is then eventually we do not have koalas. If we remove them, we remove part of Australia. Our native forests in an intact condition provide a habitat for endangered species. The other function of such places is that they store greenhouse gases, they hold soil together and provide organic matter for the forest itself in its own process of sustainability.

It is also a source of clean water. A hectare of old-growth mountain ash clear felled may produce $270 worth of woodchips once and a generation later it may produce half as much because regrowth is not so dense. Consulting economist Read Sturgess and Associates was commissioned by the Victorian government to examine this matter and found that if that same hectare was left unlogged it would produce more than $6,000 worth of water in Victoria and it would do that year after year. So with these things in mind it is really not surprising that the softwood market is steadily increasing because there are people who recognise the value of our native forests, that it is important to reserve those areas and to challenge the previously accepted wisdoms of there being an endless opportunity to exploit them.

We are reminded—and I know this has been quoted before, but I will quote it again because it suits me to do so now—that Mr de Bruin of the SEAS Sapfor, which is and we should recognise it as one of the largest softwood companies, said in the Sunday Age, `We're expecting a substantial increase in available plantation resources over the next three or four years. We'll get to stage where we virtually don't have to log native forests at all in the next two to five years.' That is the trend. That is where the industry is going and those who are intending to make a real profit out of it recognise it. We should also be encouraging it to go. Companies such as CSR are recognising that and are heavily investing in plantations as well.

I contend that native forest logging—and this is where I started this section, on the definition of sustainable—is not sustainable; it cannot be continued forever. The sooner we recognise it the better. It is costing us money and destroying the environment. If we are going to interpret the national forest policy statement properly, we really need proper debate about what is sustainable, what is profitable and what is waste. We need these terms properly defined by government if the government is sincere about its efforts to implement its own policy.

I question that sincerity because the national forest policy statement also contains a promise to have a representative, comprehensive—it would be comprehensible too, I would hope—and an adequate reserve system in place by the end of this year, and it has not even set one area aside yet. I pointed this out some time ago to the government. Even the area in Tasmania—and I am sure the parliamentary secretary at table is well aware of this, but some other honourable senators in the chamber may not be—that contains the world's longest living organism on the planet, a Huon pine 10,500 years old, has not even been set aside.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was only discovered last week.

—The senator contends that it was only discovered last week. I think if he reads the article again he will see that it has been known for some time but the information was only published last week for a jolly good reason, because there might be a few people who would want to do something with it which would not be in the best interests of the whole community.

PARA.TAB: Be proud of the fact that we have within our jurisdiction the oldest living organism on the planet. What are we doing to protect it? It has yet to be given the protection which surely we must all agree it warrants. But even though we have this national forest policy statement, we have not worked out how to sufficiently protect it. It is located on a mining lease owned by Pasminco. Thank goodness the company has shown the enlightened approach to properly guard it up until this moment. But what has the government done? What has it actually achieved? Even though it has this policy statement—

TALK.START.PARA: —We did not know about it till last week.

—You should have known. Even though it has this policy statement, we have not seen proper protection of such a wonderful organism offered by this government. It should be capable of responding to such a wonderful resource that we have here. It is a resource; it is something that we share; and it is something which is owned by the Australian community. Unless we can amend this motion, the Democrats will not be supporting it. I propose that we amend it to read, as I indicated before, that the chaos is a direct result of the government's failure to follow the policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —In making a contribution during this debate for the government, I want to touch on some of the issues that have been raised by Senator Bell, Senator Margetts and Senator Panizza. I think these points will highlight the controversy and the differing opinions and views we have of the current debate over forestry and more particularly woodchipping. Then in some detail I will go to the national forest policy statement because I believe this policy can at least significantly deal with some of the controversies that are currently raging and have raged certainly in my state for the last 20 or so years in the public arena.

PARA.TAB: One point that Senator Bell raised in respect of the national forest policy statement I will comment on now. I can assure Senator Bell and the Senate that the government is very determined to implement the national forest policy statement, and not just because of the current controversy we are faced with. I would reject any assertion that we do not want to implement it. Even Senator Bell would have to acknowledge that it is not just because of but certainly in part because of the current controversy that is occurring that it is very necessary to vigorously pursue all of the goals and objectives set out in the NFPS, and I will come to those in detail shortly.

There was a great deal of passion in the contribution of Senator Margetts. I would never call her a liar, I would say to Senator Panizza. I accept that what Senator Margetts does outline, she passionately believes in; she does passionately believe it. It is just that on a number of points she is wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —In other words, she is not quite correct.

—She is wrong on a number of points. I would hope that in our debates—and I am sure there will be many of them over the coming years, in this place, on this issue—we can persuade you, Senator Margetts, that you are wrong on some of the points you hold. I do want to respond to a couple of the issues she touched on.

PARA.TAB: Senator Margetts alleges that the only area of the woodchip licences this federal government and state governments care about is the dollar value. That is clearly an incorrect assertion. I know that at state government level—and I am referring to all state governments; currently there are conservative governments in most states—prior to a Liberal government in Tasmania and prior to a Liberal government in Victoria, the policies of both former Premier Field and former Premier Kirner are being continued by the current conservative governments. Those policies are not just dollar driven; they are driven by a combined set of values applying to their forest industries, based on assessing the conservation values of the forests in those two states. They have an appropriately balanced set of values that they are attempting to implement at their state levels. It is not simply dollar driven.

In this area the federal government has to rely, to a significant degree, on advice from the states. That is because within our department we do not have the significant number of people necessary to carry out the assessments in the detail in which the states can obviously carry them out. As has already been pointed out—I think, fairly frequently—the federal government's power in this area is in respect of woodchip export licences. But through a cooperative approach with the state governments, we have developed the national forest policy statement.

Senator Margetts refers to the problem with the balance of payments. She asserts that the woodchip export industry is a net drain on the balance of payments. As Senator Cook said in his response at question time, it is very hard to separate out the contribution of the woodchip export area from the other sectors of the industry because it is an integrated industry. When you log an area, a `coupe'—and I think that is a word that is entering into everyone's everyday usage, given the run it is getting at the moment—depending on the quality of timber in that area, there is a significant amount of waste. There are a number of options: you can chip it; you can use those chips domestically or for export purposes; and, other than putting them in pulp and paper, you can also put them in MDF plants and produce particle boards—and that is a very significant area of expansion of industry.

I return to the issue of the balance of payments. Frankly, it does shock me that in the last financial year we exported over $450 million worth of woodchips; I wish that did not occur. I would much rather see those woodchips processed and downstreamed into a greater value added product in this country, whether it is pulp and paper or whether it is to a particle board mill.

However, I would remind Senator Margetts—and this is another point she made—that you need a pulp and paper mill to do that. I do not know of any site in Australia that the Green movement accepts as an appropriate location for a pulp and paper mill. The Greens have not named one. All they will do is continue to talk about so-called backyard boutique pulp and paper mills. The problem is that, at least at the present time, they are not economically viable. No-one is proposing to build any in Australia. Surely we have to be economically rational, at least to some extent, about what is required. If you look at pulp and paper mills around the world, they are very capital intensive. If we are going to go down that track, then at the least we do need a pulp and paper mill that is viable on a world scale and will undoubtedly be technologically rich. Also with the various other forms of downstreaming, I certainly believe that, under the processes involved in the national forest policy statement, we can downstream much better than we are doing.

Looking at the quarterly forest product statistics for the September quarter of last year, I remind the Senate that we imported—and I am shocked by what we import into this country—$144 million of newsprint, $731 million of printing and writing paper, and $370 million of packaging and industrial paper. They are shocking statistics, showing that we export over $400 million of woodchips and import this other product. These figures do not include the statistics on furniture: I understand that some hundreds of millions of dollars of furniture made from wood products are imported into the country. If we were able to convert those woodchips into the value added products that we are importing—and at the moment, I think the deficit is $1.7 billion a year—we would become a net exporter, not a net importer. That is the sort of industry approach that we in government can encourage under the national forest policy statement.

It is unfortunate that the environment movement approaches this issue purely from the point of view of criticising woodchip exports. It is a fairly shrewd way—at least from their point of view—of attacking all logging in all native forests. I think one of the goals of the national forest policy statement is to ensure that we reach a balance between the competing uses of our forests. We must ensure that an appropriate range of our forests is set aside for conservation. In many areas an appropriate level of forests must be set aside for wood production and industry development that is sustainable. We should ensure that where such development occurs it is carried out in an environmentally responsible way.

I want to comment on pine plantations. Senator Margetts was just a touch cautious about pushing that as an issue, even though she did raise it as one of the solutions. I think pine plantations have a place in the development of a sustainable forest industry. But I notice that in New Zealand, the Greenpeace organisation is campaigning vigorously against them and demanding that they be ripped out of the ground. Why? A pine plantation, if any of you have been into one, is an ecological desert for native flora and fauna. For obvious reasons, you will not find too much Australian flora and fauna in a pine plantation. Pines are not native to Australia. The biology of pines precludes or minimises the growth of any other Australian species. Therefore, I do not want to see pine plantations from one end of Australia—or Tasmania—to the other. I think that would be an inappropriate way to head.

Senator Coulter and Senator Bell talked about the debts of the forestry commissions. Certainly Senator Coulter referred to the debt of the Tasmanian Forestry Commission—or what was known as the Forestry Commission—of $400 million. I think the important thing is that, since then, the processes have been changed in Tasmania, and the administration of forestry is carried out on a commercial basis.

However, I do want to point out one aspect of the debt in Tasmania—and Senator Bell should be aware of this. The Forestry Commission in Tasmania was used as one of those hollow logs by the Gray government to pay a dividend, from the Forestry Commission to the state government, of over $10 million a year—I think that figure is correct—in terms of a notional profit that did not exist. It did that in order to make sure that, when it was entering into its borrowing requirements, no-one saw the debt levels. It did not have a lot to do with a debt for forestry development; it had a lot to do with using a fairly imaginative financial hollow log in order that former Premier Gray could continue to incur the unsustainable levels of financial expenditure that he was incurring while he was Premier.
Senator Calvert interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That all occurred, Senator Calvert, prior to the Field government and, unfortunately, we were the government that was left with the mess to clean up.
—You can't blame Premier Gray.
—Yes, I will blame Premier Gray, and that is widely accepted by the business community. Senator Crane, you talk to the business community in Tasmania about former Premier Gray's regime in Tasmania.

PARA.TAB: I want to make one other point, about Senator Bell's referral to Mr de Bruin and his projections about where the industry should be going. Senator Bell conveniently skates over the fact that Mr de Bruin is a major importer of timber into this country. He obviously makes a profit out of it. I think Senator Bell used the words, `Mr de Bruin wants to make a real profit out of it.' He certainly does. He stands to be a major gainer from the importation of timber.

It would be interesting to see from which countries Mr de Bruin—the expert whom you are quoting—is taking the timber and what forestry methods are being used in those countries. I know that the forestry practices in Thailand, Brazil or wherever are absolutely outrageous. They are not sustainable in any sense. Before the Democrats and the Greens quote Mr de Bruin more widely, I think they should investigate where he is importing his timbers from. I think it would embarrass them.

I am very proud of the fact that we have a tree in Tasmania—the Huon pine—that has recently been publicly exposed as being more than 10,500 years old. I do not think anyone in this place or anywhere else would seriously suggest that that tree, now that it has been publicly announced, should not be protected to the maximum degree and in the appropriate way. I do not think you can seriously expect the federal government, having learnt one week about the tree, to rush in and have a national park or World Heritage area declared the following week. I do not think you can seriously suggest that, Senator Bell.

We have a considerable controversy raging at the present time about woodchipping and also about the broader forest industries in this country. The federal government—with its limited powers that I have referred to—entered in a realistic way into negotiations with all the state governments about the forest issue approximately 3 1/2 years ago, and the national forest policy statement emerged. The statement has not been signed yet by Premier Groom from Tasmania, but I understand that it is in the process of being signed. He has sent it up, but he has qualified it a little bit. That, hopefully, will be resolved shortly.

You do require the considerable cooperation not just of the state governments—because I think we have to be critical of the state governments in their approach to the NFPS—but also of industry. I frankly do not think industry has been forward looking enough in some areas—for example, looking at and developing downstreaming of our extensive woodchip resource. It is going to require the cooperation of not just the federal government—and I think it is unfair to blame the federal government in that way—but also of the state governments and industry in order to ensure the rigorous implementation of the national forest policy statement.

This statement is a balanced approach to forestry practices in Australia. The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Faulkner—a very vigorous and decisive minister who is very concerned for the environment in this country—quite rightly is concerned about the conservation goals of the NFPS. It is appropriate that his role is to advance those interests and concerns within the context of this statement.

As a balanced approach, the NFPS deals with issues of wood production and industry development, plantations, private native forests, water supply and catchment management, tourism, employment, work force education and training, public awareness education and involvement, research and development and international responsibilities. It touches on the responsibilities of at least half the ministers in the federal government.

When you do not have active cooperation from state governments—one state is still to sign the NFPS—it is a bit difficult to be implementing the policy as vigorously as you would hope. But make no mistake, the government is determined that a balanced range of objectives and goals will be implemented. Looking at the motion before the Senate, the first part is a statement of fact:

SPEECH.PARA: it is now 2 years since the Government drafted the National Forest Policy Statement . . .
It goes on:
this statement was, and continues to be, endorsed and supported by a wide cross-section of the forest industry . . .

That is not correct. It is not just the forest industry that endorses this; it is endorsed by various groups in the community, and the federal and state governments. It needs the active involvement and support of not just the forest industry but of all those parties.

PARA.TAB: I have been rebutting subparagraph (iii) of the motion on behalf of the government. I have referred to the very fine role of our minister for the environment, Senator Faulkner, and the very diligent and determined efforts of the Minister for Resources, Mr Beddall. He has approached his responsibilities in a very determined and balanced way.

We have had the involvement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—as we should—because the NFPS is a very major part of government policy. It is important that the Prime Minister, in recognising the major importance of this statement, should be involved with those two ministers and other ministers in the development of the implementation of the NFPS. There is not chaos. The government is about implementing this in the appropriate way.

On behalf of the government, I have touched on some of the controversies in this forestry debate. I have briefly dealt with some of the goals and objectives of the NFPS. I strongly refute the assertion in subparagraph (iii) of Senator Brownhill's motion and ask the Senate to accordingly reject it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment on the motion that Senator Brownhill has put forward. I am glad that Senator Bell is here. It has been rumoured in the press in Hobart—and I think it is more than rumour—that at the next half-Senate election the fight for one of the positions is going to be between Senator Bell for the Democrats and Bob Brown for the Greens.

PARA.TAB: Although I do not always agree with what Senator Bell says, at least I thought his argument today was rational, which is more than can be said for Senator Margetts, who raved on for 20 minutes about 400-year-old trees. What she did not say was that in my state of Tasmania—I do not know what happens in Western Australia—something like 70 per cent of the state is locked up. I think it is fair to say that, not just in Tasmania but in most parts of Australia, more trees are damaged by fire, wind, hurricanes and gales than will ever be damaged by a living and sustainable forest industry, which we have got down there.

What we are debating today is this fine motion brought forward by my colleague Senator Brownhill and the mess that this Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) has got us into. Is it any wonder that outside this parliament we have ordinary men, women and children staging one of the largest demonstrations and protests ever seen in Canberra? Is it any wonder that these thousands of decent Australians and hundreds and hundreds of thousands more like them have finally stood up and said, `Enough is enough'? Is it any wonder that they are upset because this government is threatening their jobs, their livelihood, their families and indeed their very survival?

This national forest statement is not a blueprint for the future management of our forestry resource. It is instead final proof that the Labor government has sold out to the radical green agenda regardless of the cost. The national forest statement was supposed to be based on rational, scientific evidence, but to date we have seen very little, if any, evidence of that. All we seem to have seen is evidence of Natalie.

If this was supposed to be an objective assessment, then why did the minister for the environment pay conservation groups to make their own wish list? What we ended up with were the darkest of green conservation groups roaming the bush, paid for by the minister, trying to identify every coupe they could find as being suitable for conservation. Those conservation groups must have thought it was Christmas.

But if that was not enough, then the minister placed the final outcome into the hands of the Environment Protection Agency, the Australian Heritage Commission, the Australian Nature Conservation Agency and the World Heritage and Biodiversity Branch and the Environmental Resources Information Network in his directorate. When all these groups had had their say, what was left? I will tell you what was left. What this government ended up with was a farce—a document which lacked any credibility. You do not have to take my word for it. The federal Labor member for Lyons, Mr Dick Adams, is on record as saying that the process which arrived at the decision `did not have a lot of integrity'. Is it any wonder when we have a Prime Minister who ably displayed his lack of knowledge of forestry issues by describing a coupe as an area of 150 metres square.

Our minister for the environment is not much better. We heard in this place only yesterday that he wrote to the Victorian Minister for Conservation and Natural Resources, Geoff Coleman, telling him that a shining gum was a nationally rare plant. We might well ask what criteria the minister uses when considering such a listing, especially when there are thousands of hectares of forest in Victoria containing this species.

This is what happens when a minister losses control of his portfolio. We have seen that this week. This is what happens when a minister allows himself to be dictated to by the bureaucrats in his department who are obviously running their own agenda. My own state of Tasmania is a classic example of how bungled this whole process has been. When the minister for the environment originally announced a national list of 1,800 coupes which were to be protected, 85 per cent of the 170 listed in Tasmania had either been harvested previously or had roads built through them or to them.

When the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) intervened we had a new list of 509 coupes—Senator Crane told me today it was actually 511. This new list has no more credibility than the first. At least two of the 72 coupes on the latest list have already been clear-felled. In addition, 50 others had either been logged previously or are being logged now. To make matters worse—if they could be any worse—two-thirds of the coupes on the list are not even in the National Estate and a further three are in private forests. This national forest policy statement must be rejected and it must be rejected outright. What this statement attempts to do is to lock away forever a valuable resource which it has been proven, time and time again, can be responsibly managed for forestry operations.

Why are these people who have come to Parliament House so angry? We have to ask ourselves that question. Why do they feel betrayed by the government and the entire farce of a process which has resulted in this statement? I will tell you why they are angry? They are angry because the government has broken every promise it ever made to the forestry workers in this country. They are angry because no-one in the government is prepared to stand up and be counted on their behalf.

Where are the voices of anger from the government members and senators? There are no voices of anger because the people in the government who should be standing tall, like Senator Murphy, have rolled over. They are nowhere to be seen. I look forward to hearing what Senator Murphy has to say because we know that he is a member of the CFMEU and the Australian Timber Workers Union. We know that Senator Sherry is a member of the Federated Liquor and Allied Trades Union. Why have you deserted your union mates? You have turned your backs on your old friends. I read in the paper today that Silvia Smith, Harry Quick and Dick Adams have supposedly threatened to resign. Do you believe that? I don't. I think it is just another excuse for a headline.

You have let down Tasmania's timber workers because, at the end of the day, you have shown that in the Labor Party it is more important to keep in sweet with the Prime Minister than it is to stand up for the people who need you. You ought to be ashamed of yourselves. I do not know how you will face your old mates. I can tell you that amongst the timber workers in Tasmania your names are mud.

What this statement will do, if it is allowed to remain, is change forever the balance in relation to forestry matters. It does that because this document not only moves the goalposts but also changes the whole game. The only areas which this statement and this minister are prepared to exclude from the definition of old-growth forest are those areas, by his own definition, which have been clear-felled over the last 20 years for integrated sawlog and woodchip operations.

We know that this new definition that is supported by the radical green movement and the minister has resulted in the farce we have today. What it quite clearly means is that, accordingly to the new rules, the areas which have been traditionally available for harvesting and regeneration are now off-limits. It creates a ridiculous position where plantations can now be considered under his definition as old-growth forests.

It is time the government took a long hard look at the position which it has allowed the radical green movement to put it in. Members of the government need to take a walk outside Parliament House and see the people and the families who are going to be the big losers. Let us try to explain to them why these areas, which have been traditionally available, are now to be locked away.

If you really want proof of how responsibly the forest industries have managed their operations, it is there in front of you. If the government and the radical green movement are now prepared to list previously logged areas as old-growth, then surely that is proof that the forests can recover. Personally, I believe that there is no better example than that that regeneration can and does work.

This national forest policy statement has sent a clear message overseas that this government does not want investment. This government is not about encouraging the valuable downstream processing that will be so important in stimulating jobs growth. How will Australia ever be able to participate in downstream processing when every forest which is over 20 years of age is going to be off limits? For the sake of future generations of Australians, this statement must be rejected outright. Timber workers and their families have a right to work and we must not stand by and watch this government take it away from them.
Amendment (by Senator Bell) proposed:
Subparagraph (a) (iii), omit "refusal to enact the National Forest Policy Statement", substitute "failure to follow the proper licensing process.".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my remarks in this debate by saying that, before I became a senator, I sometimes had a view that a lot of time was wasted in this place. I would have to say that this particular motion confirms in my mind that we waste so much time in this place with nonsense, it is unbelievable. I am quite sure that the public of Australia will not be amused by nonsensical motions like the one we have before us now.

PARA.TAB: It is clearly evident that those opposite have taken a severe dose of political opportunism over the last couple of days. You thought, `Here's a go. Here's our chance.' I do not blame you for doing that because you really have not had much going for you in the past. It has really gone to your heads. This motion makes no sense at all. I do not know what the point of it is. The first point says that it is now two years since the government drafted the national forest policy statement. That is true. It also says that this statement was and continues to be endorsed and supported by a wide cross-section of the forest industry. That is true too. It is also supported by a number of state governments because they signed it.

Point (iii) of Senator Brownhill's motion refers to the chaos caused by the `three-ringed circus', et cetera. It concludes by saying that this was a result of the government's failure to enact the national forest policy statement. Of course, on that side of the fence we have had all these calls about support for workers, mates and old growth. I know one thing for sure: despite your overdose of political opportunism, the one thing that will not grow old on that side is leaders. They will never grow old in their job because you keep changing them perennially. So don't come in here and preach to us about stability or anything else.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you stick up for the workers? What about the workers?

—Let us deal with this matter of sticking up for workers. It is the height of hypocrisy for you lot to come in here and lay claims about supporting workers. What did you do in the debate over the 45D and E legislation? Where did you vote then? What did you do about Jeff Kennett when he took all the legal rights of workers away from them in Victoria? What did you do about Ray Groom?

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order relating to relevance. What Jeff Kennett did or what we do with our leaders has nothing to do with this debate. I ask you to direct the senator to be relevant to the debate, which has been stuck to by all speakers up to date.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—I do not think there is any point of order, Senator Panizza. It has been a pretty robust debate. Senator Murphy was giving some examples. I presume that is all they were.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know it does not take too many logs to make an opposition frontbench. What did you do about Groom's dismissal of construction workers? You talk about costs. What Groom did was a greater cost to the state of Tasmania. That is what this debate is all about. You talk about costs, but what did you do about that situation? Not a thing. You have never sought to represent workers. As I said, you come in here in your political opportunistic way, and that is exactly what you will continue to do. That is fine because its adds no real solution. It does not contribute to seeking a proper outcome to the end of this debate.

PARA.TAB: I cannot leave the Greens or the Democrats out of this opportunistic approach either. They chose to come in here and talk about a bloke in South Australia who runs a pine sawmill, Mr de Bruin. Of course, the Liberals are not too happy with him either. He was also very opportunistic in this debate because he was seeking greater market share for the pine industry. Dishonest as it was, that is what he was about. I would like to read from a Hansard debate in the Victorian parliament with respect to Mr de Bruin and his company. It demonstrates just how much credibility he really has. This statement was made by Mr Weideman, the member for Frankston. Mr Weideman, who is a Liberal member, referred to Mr de Bruin and SEAS Sapfor. He referred to something that SEAS Sapfor did which was very dishonest. His comments draw some attention to the company and that person. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: My understanding is that SEAS Sapfor Limited had a company called Timber Sales distributing its wood and timber products. A year or so ago it was brought to my attention that in Dandenong the company was treating pine sawlogs with arsenic and creosote. My understanding is that the property was sold. Local residents and the Environment Protection Authority were concerned the property was contaminated. The property was sold as being chemical free, which caused concern to one or two of my constituents who are worried about conservation issues.

The fact is that it was not contamination free. It is also worth noting that Mr de Bruin, who is now the head of SEAS Sapfor in South Australia, was at some point in time involved in Poseidon Minerals. I hope that his management role at SEAS Sapfor does not bring about the same result as that which occurred at Poseidon.

PARA.TAB: Senator Brownhill's motion demonstrates a total lack of understanding of the national forest policy statement; otherwise we would not have this motion. We have been here for four days; we have been here since Monday. I would have thought that, given the circumstances that exist outside Parliament House and given the opportunity that some of you on the other side have had, you would have at least gone and got yourselves a copy of the national forest policy statement and did a little bit of reading. You would at least have some understanding of what this is all about and how you go about implementing it. I will read into Hansard—obviously you will not read it yourselves—the intergovernmental arrangements of the national forest policy statement. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Land use decision making

Under the Australian Constitution, State Governments have primary responsibility for land use decision making and management. As a consequence, State processes are well established, and they are periodically reviewed to take account of community priorities. Several States are introducing changes to increase opportunities for consultation, to reflect changes in societal values, and to promote more effective State-Commonwealth cooperation in land use decision making.
That is in part what it says about intergovernmental arrangements on land use decision making. It also refers to the intergovernmental agreement on the environment. It reads:
The Intergovernmental Agreement on the Environment provides for the identification of the interests of both the Commonwealth and State Governments in land use decision making.

The Commonwealth has a number of obligations. You people are confused about the issue of woodchip licences versus the implementation of the national forest policy statement. This government also has other obligations when it issues woodchip licences. Many of them are contained within the Commonwealth Environment Protection Act. It requires certain things of ministers in terms of recommendations and making final decisions on the issue of woodchip licences.

PARA.TAB: A Federal Court decision—there may be some different opinions about that—has clearly set down an obligation on the Commonwealth. But that does not alter the fact that you are being politically opportunistic to try to confuse one issue which you do not understand with another. There is a further requirement of the national forest policy statement. You have said that you want it implemented. Part of its implementation is to have—what are they called?—regional forest agreements.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't know it your self.

—No. There are a whole range of factors, and I do not claim to know them all off by heart. At least I have read it, Senator Crane. Part of the development of a regional forest agreement is a comprehensive regional assessment. Page 24 of the national forest policy statement—I suggest you read it—reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Governments have identified a single, comprehensive regional assessment process whereby the States—
I want you to listen to this—
can invite the Commonwealth to participate in undertaking all assessments necessary to meet Commonwealth and State obligations for forested areas of a region.

The point I want to make is this: yes, the Commonwealth has had a national forest policy statement for two years, but not once in that two-year period has it received anything from any state. You obviously do not listen to anything the Prime Minister says; he said this back on 22 December. In the two years that the national forest policy statement has been in place and signed by all of the states with the exception of Tasmania, not one of those states has written to the Commonwealth to invite it to participate in the process of getting in place a comprehensive regional assessment to then put in place a regional forest agreement. You may know this, but it will be the only process that will bring both security and stability for the industry and long-term protection for the environment. As I said before, I suggest that you people stop being politically opportunistic and that you read the documents that you keep referring to. We have been going on about this for four days.

PARA.TAB: Another very important aspect of this that is relevant to workers is the utilisation of the wood that currently grows in our forests. Page 20 of the national forest policy statement—I hope that Senator Crane takes note of this; he ought to read it—says that wood pricing and allocation—

TALK.START.PARA: —I have read it.
—He obviously did not take much notice of it. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The pricing and allocation system for wood from public native forests has a major bearing on the structure and efficiency of the wood products industry and on the return to the community from use of a publicly owned resource.

Yesterday I gave an example of a circumstance that existed in Tasmania with a company called Australian Newsprint Mills. I want to provide a further example today of just how the states are not managing this public resource in a way that will provide to this country and its workers a better social and economic return.

PARA.TAB: In terms of woodchip exports, there is photographic evidence whereby logs that should be processed in this country, which would give greater security to sawmill workers, are currently being woodchipped. That is

SPEECH.PARA: no way to run a forest industry. The direct responsibility for that lies with the states, not the Commonwealth or anyone else. We do not have a forestry department. We cannot direct the states as to when they can or cannot cut down the trees. That is a fact.

PARA.TAB: A company called North Broken Hill Peko, which has a subsidiary called North Forest Products in Tasmania, has a concessional legislative right. It exports out of Tasmania almost 200 million tonnes of wood via woodchips per annum. I participated in the Forests and Forest Industry Council, which was funded by the Commonwealth to the tune of $10 million. It developed a strategy for Tasmania's forests called the forests and forest industry strategy. That strategy is not being properly implemented. But it did say that we should move from having area based concessional rights to volume based wood supply agreements.

The state has a responsibility to ensure that the utilisation of its forests returns a proper and adequate social and economic benefit. It is not doing that because this company is seeking to negotiate a 15-year volume based agreement for the same amount of wood that it currently exports out of the state of Tasmania. One might say that that is okay. We have people who want to have further processing of that wood within the state. If it is contractually obligated to another company, one cannot then turn around and sell the wood to somebody else.

It has already happened. Interests have said, `We would like to build a pulp and paper mill or an MDF plant', and the state has had to say, `We don't have the wood to sell to you. Go and talk to North Broken Hill.' That is not the way that a state's forest industry should be run. I know many timber workers who do not support the exporting of timber in woodchip form when it can be processed further so that it provides more jobs for them and a better economic return. If that is what those opposite support, they should stand up and say it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The speaker opposite has consistently misled this chamber. I would like to read into the record just two things.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask this question: how can we stop people telling lies in this place?
