—On the point of order: there is no capacity for Senator Crane to ask questions, and he knows it. He is just playing around with the standing orders. I ask you to rule him out of order.

—Senator Crane, if you claim to have been misrepresented, there are other opportunities where you can do that. At present, I have no way of telling whether Senator Murphy is telling the truth or otherwise. I am afraid that you will have to wait until your opportunity or someone else's opportunity comes to rebut what he has to say. That is what debate is all about.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask that you ask Senator Crane to withdraw the inference that I am telling lies. As you say, he will have an opportunity to refute anything I have said. I certainly do not accept his comment as being parliamentary. I ask you to ask him to withdraw.
—On the point of order: Senator Crane did not directly accuse Senator Murphy.
—There is no point of order. Senator Murphy believes that Senator Crane is implying that he was not telling the truth. If that is the case, I ask Senator Crane to withdraw.
—If Senator Murphy cannot handle the truth, I will withdraw.

—The forest issue is complex. The Commonwealth has an obligation under several acts to deal with environmental matters. Those obligations are contained within the national forest policy statement. The circumstances that exist at the current time may have delivered some euphoria to the opposition; it has not had too much of that because it seems to be always spending its time spinning the leadership bottle. I do not know of the longevity of the regurgitated model that we now have; we will have to wait and see about that.

PARA.TAB: When the opposition considers Senator Brownhill's motion, it should really look at what it is saying. Paragraph (b) of the motion calls on the government to implement immediately a consistent and sustainable policy for the resource sector. In the first instance, the opposition talks about the national forest policy statement. If the national forest policy statement is implemented, there will be a consistent and sustainable policy in place for the resource sector and the forest industry. Even Senator Brownhill's motion recognises that. Subparagraph (ii) says that this statement was and continues to be endorsed and supported by a wide cross-section of the forest industry. We want to get it implemented. But I pointed out very clearly—it has been pointed out to the opposition many times—that we can only do that at the invitation of the states.

I do not know where Senator Bell's amendment fits into this motion. He probably prepared it on the run because it is handwritten. Following the proper process, he has only brought it to the fore as a result of the Sackville decision. But he did not do it last year. We have had this policy in place for two years. We did not see you in 1994 bringing in some motion of this nature for us to have implemented. I have not seen you produce any letters from—John Howard is the leader now—Alexander Downer to the leaders of the states.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. On several occasions during Senator Murphy's speech, he has not addressed people from the other house in the proper terms. I ask you to call that to his attention. You just do not address someone as `John Howard'.
—Senator Murphy, I believe that you would be aware of that.
—I apologise. I have not seen any letters from Mr Howard, who is the current leader.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I still do not think he has got it right. Could you draw it to his attention.
—Are you suggesting that he should be called the honourable Mr Howard?
—The Leader of the Opposition.
—I believe that the title `Mr Howard' is quite sufficient.

—As I said, I have not seen any letters from Mr Howard, the honourable Leader of the Opposition, or Mr Downer, the former honourable Leader of the Opposition, to the state premiers in Western Australia, South Australia, Victoria and New South Wales saying, `Let's get this national forest policy in place.' I have not seen one.
—Here they are from Mr Fahey, Mr Kennett. Here they all are. Do you want me to table them?

—As we have been in this process for four days it seems strange that you are waving bits of paper over there. You might get an opportunity to table them later. Nevertheless, it is farcical for us to get involved in debates on motions of no consequence that can make no contribution to either resolving the circumstances that currently exist over the issue of woodchip licences or to getting a quicker implementation of the national forest policy statement. This motion, along with the amendment, should be opposed for the very reasons I have just outlined.

PARA.TAB: I encourage the opposition, including Senator Boswell, to read the national forest policy statement and then encourage those Premiers to get to work and invite this Commonwealth to participate in the process of comprehensive regional assessments that will lead to regional forest agreements—which I totally support—to greater security and to the greatest ability for the forest industries around this country. They have a marvellous contribution to make to the economy, but they need to be better run. We need to get better social and economic returns out of them. That will be part of this process also. The state Premiers around the place have signed off on it so it is really a matter of getting on and getting it done and opposing this motion. As I said, it serves no purpose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating Senator Brownhill's motion on the mess that the present Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) has got us into. Senator Faulkner can be described as the minister for rigorous assessments because it is the rigorous assessment that he has gone through which has declared the 1,300 areas of high conservation value. Clearly from what we have heard this week and before, the assessments have been a complete charade. Worst of all, legitimate environmental questions which concern forest management have been completely demeaned.

PARA.TAB: There has been a fair bit of media speculation today that Senator Faulkner has been called off the job and the job has been given to Senator Collins. It is interesting that the main government speaker was the parliamentary secretary to the minister for agriculture, Senator Sherry, who filibustered and wasted a lot of time here this afternoon. Clearly, the job is just too big for Senator Faulkner. He has made a complete sham of the process of evaluating the high value conservation forests. He has destroyed the credibility of the procedure, which I might add is a procedure that the government itself has made. He has put at risk thousands of jobs of average Australian workers, the communities that they come from and the enormous amounts of infrastructure that the forest industry and timber industry support.

If anyone had any doubt about the feeling that people have about this issue, they should have been outside federal Parliament House at lunchtime today to see thoroughly decent average working Australian men and women, people who are not only involved in the timber industry directly but in others as well, protesting in Canberra about the things that they hold very dear.

There has been a fair bit of evidence of the demeaning process that has gone on by the minister. First and foremost—and there are a number of bits of evidence of this—at least five coupes or compartments in Victoria do not exist. Originally we were told there were 509 compartments. There are actually 511.

There are particular compartments on which the evidence shows that the government did not ever do its work. I give the example of compartment 2329 in the Glenbog state forest. The first half was logged in 1977, a part selectively logged in 1984 and there has been selective logging from the 1920s to the 1970s. It has been thinned twice, part-cleared for highway construction and it has been included as an area that has high conservation value. The only person who could think that would be Senator Faulkner.

We also have evidence that 50 coupes were secretly and randomly transferred last week from Tasmania to Victoria. I should put on record that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) apparently thinks that a coupe is approximately 150 square metres. He said that on A Current Affair the other day. That area is about the size of his Woollahra house. A coupe actually is about 40 hectares. Minister Faulkner signed a letter to the Victorian minister responsible for forests in which he described—although with the Latin name—the shiny gum as being potentially an endangered species. When I heard that, I concluded that the only endangered species are timber workers and their families because Senator Faulkner has been the recipient of incompetent advice from his department.

We have the evidence of Natalie and others who advised on the high conservation value. We had $120,000 of taxpayers' money paid to special interest groups that were favourable to the minister's agenda. We know about Mr Toyne and his agenda. He wishes the whole of the south-east to be declared wilderness and therefore to be closed down and not be available at all for logging. Pretty clearly, the whole evaluation process has been highly political, directed by political forces favourable to the left-wing minister. It really is another whiteboard affair—a complete pandering to special interest groups. Finally, the government's failure has resulted in the crude use of the export power to manipulate the industry and win the green vote.

When I had the opportunity to go outside today to speak with the families and citizens of Bega, Bombala, Eden and beyond, where schools have been closed and businesses have closed for the day, I met a tugboat operator from Eden, a supermarket manager, a minister of religion—a whole range of people who are concerned about their towns and communities. This really is a disgraceful, shameful and unAustralian government.

The government backbench knows what should be done. Five members, then six and, according to the Canberra Times today, now 14 members, have warned the Prime Minister that the government has to change its course. I guess if they all resigned, as John Devereux has done, we would all be in government this time next week. The caucus resolution was that the 509 coupes should be allowed to be logged until their conservation value is established. Pretty clearly, that is the right decision. But whilst the caucus might talk tough, it did not take a tough decision when given the opportunity in the other place today. The coalition moved a motion:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House, recognising the damage to regional economies and jobs, reaffirms its commitment to the national forest policy statement and requests the government to bring about its immediate implementation.

Those members of the government who were very worried about their electorates and knew what the right decision was, failed to support that motion. It was a motion to make the federal government set out the criteria for the evaluation of high conservation areas. We want that. We saw the government members who had the chance to support their electorates, workers and timber industry communities walk away from their timber workers. This uncertainty is causing a great number of concerns not only amongst timber workers and their communities but amongst the companies involved.

PARA.TAB: I know that Harris-Daishowa, a company that Senator Loosley knows a great deal about, has said publicly that its investment program is very much at risk. Hundreds of smaller independent mills have been affected. Whittakers, the second largest sawmiller in Western Australia, has voluntarily had its shares suspended.

We have become an international laughing stock on this issue, especially as yesterday the current account deficit came out at $2.4 billion. This was the December figure, but it is a record figure—worse than the September 1991 figure. The current account deficit is moving from the budgeted $18 billion to $26 billion this year. Since this government has been in power, the net foreign debt has gone from $21 billion to $180 billion, which is $10,000 for every man, woman and child in the country.

Mr Keating talks admirably about nationalism, our national identity and sovereignty. I put it to him, and to the government, that the two greatest threats to our national identity and sovereignty will be the IMF or his blatant and unacceptable use of the external affairs power, both of which will have much more effect on questions of our independence than his rewriting of history.

This debate is not about woodchips; it is about access to public native forests. Senator Faulkner and some Green groups would have us believe that timber workers are clear-felling thousands of hectares of forests, purportedly at high conservation value, for woodchips. Let us look at the facts on a per tonne basis. Woodchips are worth $85 to a sawmiller. This compares with $200 per cubic metre for inferior sawn timber, $800 per cubic metre for dried structural products and $2,500 for furniture quality timber.
There are some constraints of time. I would like to finish by advising the Senate that the opposition does not accept the amendment of the Democrats.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Bell's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 8 December 1994, on motion by Senator Loosley:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are many excellent recommendations in the report entitled Australia's participation in peacekeeping. The committee has embraced the fundamental importance of involving local non-government agencies to ensure the success of a peacekeeping mission. It has hence made some important recommendations to involve members of non-government organisations in training and post-employment briefings in recognising their function in the field and enhancing cooperation and liaison with them.

PARA.TAB: As many honourable senators would know, NGOs are usually in a troubled country for a long time working closely with the local people before and after a conflict. They are in it for the long haul, and they often have the local knowledge and experience of the conflict resolution methods of the indigenous people which can be utilised by peacekeeping forces. This cultural and human rights training that NGOs have should be passed on to peacekeeping troops before they set foot in a country.

This report has heralded some policy changes with regard to proper coordination between not only peacekeepers and NGOs but also other civilian participants, such as the Australian Federal Police and the Australian Electoral Commission. Recommendation 23 advocates the establishment of a permanent peacekeeping policy and operations body which would coordinate the Department of Defence, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the AEC, the AFP and the NGOs.

This recognition of civilian functions is also well exemplified in recommendation 3, which seeks to place representative civilians in the United Nations headquarters and in peacekeeping missions. This would be part of our longer term vision of seeing a permanent full-time command and control operations centre and strategic headquarters in the United Nations to coordinate peacekeeping missions between the many different international participants, and that is in recommendations 11 and 15.

Australia has the opportunity to work productively for this proposal during the current debates on restructuring the United Nations in the year of the United Nations' 50th anniversary. This is a critical debate we need to have if the world community is serious about providing quick and even-handed peacekeeping responses to violence, genocide and war in other nations.

The present situation is that the limitations on United Nations resources and its accrued debts from the United States have in the past crippled the organisation's effectiveness. This proposal for a strategic peacekeeping headquarters and command and control centre will only cost more. We may have to address some of the United Nations' fundamental funding problems first.

There are some problems in this report, however, which I would like to address. In my opinion this report has not amply demonstrated the inconsistencies between defence policies and practices and our new peacekeeping commitments, nor does it suggest measures to bring them into line. A further concern is how we will go about managing a budget for contributions to peacekeeping operations.

In terms of our broader defence strategies, peacekeeping has a role in both our third and fourth pillars of Australian defence, which are regional security and international security. Our work in these efforts contributes to preventing a transformation of conflict into war and aims to address the roots of conflict, which are important measures for Australia's immediate defence. It is therefore alarming that our peacekeeping efforts, which embody both the strategies employed by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Department of Defence, can be at odds with our current defence department policy.

Our current defence policy is centred around defence self-reliance, which is dependent on commercialisation and exporting services and equipment to be self-sustaining. However, the promotion of arms sales in our region has the effect of fuelling internal conflicts or bilateral tensions and actually works to destabilise our region. The idea that somehow our arms sales contribute to others' security and, hence, our own is contradictory in terms. We plan our own defence priorities with regard to immediate defence needs based on capability, not threat, and our arms sales and technology transfer to countries enhance their capabilities, even if they are not yet a defined external threat.

This policy has two ramifications for our peacekeeping efforts. It directly works against methods of bringing warring or potentially warring parties into peaceful negotiation. It also displays a large opportunity cost of resources and efforts that could otherwise go into peacekeeping efforts which would enhance regional and international security and, in turn, lessen demands on the defence budget.

Peacekeeping embodies a range of efforts from preventive deployment to peace enforcement, with the responsibility shared by the departments of foreign affairs and defence. Peacekeeping itself is not just a military activity and has civilian components such as the Australian Federal Police as law enforcers and the Australian Electoral Commission to oversee and help conduct elections, for example. However, the military component is the most expensive of the peacekeeping efforts and accrues many training and equipment testing benefits that defence could not experience, other than being in the field during peacekeeping activities.

This report has not adequately addressed how we will go about paying for peacekeeping activities in the future. This is a necessary part of any policy commitment. It is certain that peacekeeping demands are going to be more demanding in the future, and we have to start planning for them now. The current situation of an increasing gap between rich and poor nations, and between the rich and poor in nations, in our current globalisation trade policy means that it is inevitable that many conflicts which come out as ethnic conflicts will have originated as a result of economic conflicts and increasing gaps in opportunity within countries. Therefore, we need to set a realistic budget for peacekeeping and organise an accountable budget management plan for use in the future.

Defence is the main component of peacekeeping operations and makes the decision whether or not we support international peacekeeping operations, what resources and capabilities we devote to an exercise and how we use them. However, this report concurs with the Department of Defence, which should not have to commit its own resources to it. On the other hand, contributing organisations such as the Australian Federal Police and the Australian Electoral Commission are expected to be responsible for their own resources committed to overseas operations, subject to supplementation, yet they may not have the power to make the decision to commit in the first place.

Peacekeeping operations are difficult to plan for and when a budget is set for peacekeeping it must take into account the post-deployment assistance that goes with it. This includes a post-military commitment, civilian infrastructure, law and order and de-mining operations, for example. This is one of our recommendations, set out in recommendation 47. The majority report recommends that `the government examine the feasibility of allocating an annual amount for peacekeeping'. That is in recommendation 22.

How that funding is administered will be crucial and accountability must be paramount. It should not be seen as an open cheque providing funding to every activity that could be grouped under peacekeeping, as this would no doubt lead to inefficiency in expenditure, possibly overspending and a lack of government accountability. Department of Finance approval should be required for each request for additional finance. This would be the only way of keeping down expenditure and offering a satisfactory level of accountability.

I believe it is important for Defence to own peacekeeping and to take responsibility for it. It is important for it to plan for peacekeeping missions within its own force structure planning, policy making resources devoted to equipment and training. It is important for the maintenance of readiness for peacekeeping missions.

The separate budget account for peacekeeping can then be used to supplement for the extra costs of peacekeeping missions that are unplanned. In terms of policy making, it is important for Defence to accept responsibility for peacekeeping in order to maintain consistency in its policy making and policy operations, and to coordinate this with other aspects of its long-term defence strategy. Without this occurring, the Department of Defence and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade will continue to work against each other, and defence policies will continue to work against our international and regional interests. We need to work together if we are to instigate peace in other nations and keep the peace.

It would be a very frightening thing if a de facto world government becomes the World Trade Organisation and the United Nations becomes the enforcing de facto body for that in terms of regional insecurities that come from this economic destabilisation. I hope that Australia does not jump on that bandwagon and that we think very carefully about the implications for peacekeeping and whether or not we are using our resources in the best way as a preventative diplomacy in peacemaking rather than peacekeeping.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 8 December 1994, on motion by Senator Brownhill:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to speak to this report very briefly and to note that in one part of the report a paragraph was added which I requested, and that is paragraph 1.5. The first sentence of that paragraph states:

SPEECH.PARA: In this report the committee reflects the evidence given at public hearings and in some of the submissions.

I wanted to underline that because I believe that this report, as far as it goes, is useful but it does not go far enough. I want to underline the fact that the interim report reflects very much the evidence given by the Department of Social Security and the Department of Employment, Education and Training. In fact, I believe that this interim report is weighted far too heavily in the direction of the evidence which they gave. I want to underline the rest of this paragraph which says that most of the submissions lodged with the committee have been critical of the impact of the assets test on farming families. I would hope that the final report reflects far more closely the evidence given by many farming families and peak farming bodies, rather than simply accepting the argument of the Department of Social Security and DEET.

PARA.TAB: The National Farmers Federation was concerned yesterday that those farmers who qualify under the drought relief package to have exemptions from the assets test should in fact be taking up that option. There are some who have taken it up, but, along with the National Farmers Federation, I would certainly urge those farmers who do qualify for that limited availability under that drought package to apply. I hope that we will see at least those farmers having the ability to take advantage of what is offered in the drought package. While I welcome this report, I want to place on record the fact that the final report will need to emphasise far more closely the evidence given by many farming families and farming peak bodies. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The rural adjustment, rural debt and rural reconstruction report, which was published in December last year, has been widely circulated and widely acclaimed. That is a significant achievement, given the highly charged atmosphere in which many of the hearings were held and under which many submissions were written. The committee received some 300 submissions, which indicates the interest in the issue. It attracted a great deal of interest at the time, and the hardship and heartbreak was brought to our committee. Obviously, these issues continue to attract a lot of concern by people in the community.

PARA.TAB: One aspect in the report that has not received much attention but which needs to be aired is that of rural debt and how the committee approached this issue. It has been suggested that the committee did not address sufficient time to this aspect of RAS. On the contrary, the question of debt pervaded every aspect of the report. The extent and the impact of debt in rural Australia was probably best described in the submission from the Australian Conference of Leaders of Religious Institutes. Representatives from ACLRI also gave evidence in Sydney. They have had extensive experience in dealing with farm families, with banks, with financial counsellors and as mediators with all those groups.

Perhaps the submission that best put the question of debt into perspective was from ABARE, which suggested that debt was not of itself necessarily a limiting factor. ABARE stated that the wheat and other crop industries have the highest average debt and the lowest average equity, yet also have recorded the highest rate of return. The key factor to debt is the ability to service that debt. Within the economic framework of the last 10 years, the ability to service that debt has been eroded and that really is the key to the current dilemma facing so many farmers. I know that some farmers have bought additional country next door at too high a price and that sort of thing, but, across-the-board, it is because of those reasons I have just mentioned.

The Rural Adjustment and Finance Corporation of Western Australia suggested that farmers did not understand debt and that it was not economic conditions but seasonal fluctuations, spiralling costs, unpredictability in commodity prices and the downward spiral in farmers' terms of trade which were the problems. But, of course, everywhere it was the people who did not have the cash flow and fat on their bones who had all the troubles. The Western Australian Rural Adjustment and Finance Corporation suggested that if it were economic conditions—that is, high interest rates and high inflation—alone that caused difficulties for farmers, then all farmers would be in similar difficulties, and that, of course, is not the case.

Elsewhere debt was referred to as a symptom, not a cause. It was also suggested that farmers get into difficulties because they are not profitable enough to service their debt. When you examine the causes of financial difficulties, you find that many of them are beyond the scope of individual farmers to control. So the best they can do is to be aware of them. Such things as fluctuating commodity prices and the escalation in farm costs can be accommodated and managed if the farmer's skills in financial management are enhanced. Costs and low prices are regrettable aspects of any business, but they are inevitable and must be managed if the business is to remain viable.

Like Senator Woodley, I too have enormous sympathy with the people who are the victims of the excessive and incompetent economic policies of the Hawke and Keating governments and the consequent high interest rates of the 1980s. I would suggest that, with the news this week of another round of burgeoning foreign debt, we may well see the interest rate roulette wheel brought into play again and more people will be caught by the Labor government's mismanagement.

While farmers cannot directly control the interest rates and indirect taxation that have crippled the rural sector, they can remove the government that brought them those policies. We have to get the monkey off the back of the workers of this country. Small business, whether it be farm related or non-farm, cannot continue to carry the economic imposts of indirect taxation.

I will name a few of the imposts of indirect taxation that are affecting people in the farming sector. Wholesale taxes put a big impost on the freight onto and off a farm. All these people who have lorries that cart product onto and off farms have to pay wholesale taxes on their tyres, their motor vehicles, and the spare parts for repairs and maintenance.

Wholesale taxes have gone from a tax take of about $3 billion 10 years ago to a tax take of something like $13 billion now. That is a heck of a lot of extra money going into the wholesale tax coffers. Fuel taxes are a big impost for people in the farming communities. We all know how fuel excise has burgeoned in the last little while.

People say, `Capital gains tax is not a worry in one generation.' But the capital gains tax is basically a de facto death duty for people who want to exit the farm by giving it to a son who wants to sell it. The fringe benefits tax is another horrific cost for people in the farming sector. So the farming sector has all those costs which are things that really have to be taken off if that sector is to become very relevant in reducing their debt.

The rural adjustment scheme report has suggested that, ultimately, education is the key to survival. I reiterate that and urge farmers to strengthen their management skills, streamline their business practices, enhance their skills and utilise the increasing range of business services available.

The government has come to the realisation that, when people do make a dollar or two, they should have the opportunity to put money away. Although the farm management bonds do not come into practice until 1 July next year, they are a step in the right direction for when people make money so they can put it away and look after themselves in bad times.

Debt is a problem not only in the rural sector but in all sectors. We heard evidence that when some people get down to, say, 40 per cent equity and they have a good cash flow, they can still make a go of it and do reasonably well. However, if other people with a 70 per cent equity in a farm do not have a good cash flow, they will gradually sink down. Notwithstanding all that, I sympathise with all those people in the rural sectors that have had drought. The drought has been so widespread and hard that it has really knocked the stuffing out of many farmers.

People may think of some way of setting aside or writing off debt, but that is not something for the committee to do. Our committee was examining the rural adjustment scheme. We could not be all things to all people and tell banks what they should do—unless we were thinking of nationalising the banks and I do not think anyone in this chamber now would think of doing that. We cannot actually tell banks to write off debt, set debt aside and set interest payments aside for a certain period of time. Although that was suggested at our inquiry, it was found that it would not be fair to everyone.

Today I had a phone call from a person who was very cranky that the people on the property next door were getting a debt write-off. Because this particular person who rang me was not in quite as necessitous circumstances, that family did not get a debt write-off from the bank. That is for the banks to decide. However, again it is not for us as a committee to decide whether it should or should not be done.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to this report, following Senator Brownhill. Perhaps I will reflect on some of the things he said and maybe go beyond those comments. Although the terms of reference for this inquiry were reasonably wide and the evidence we received pointed to some of the fundamental problems with rural industry and communities, the report is basically limited to operating within the existing government framework. That is particularly true in relation to the part of the report which concerns RAS, which is the major part of the report and the bulk of the text. In other words, the report is concentrated on making amendments to the current rural adjustment scheme.

PARA.TAB: I believe we must consider the overall question of government policy in deciding what can be done about the decline in rural communities and industry and the exodus from the bush, which is so evident to us. I say this because, with the wide scope of the terms of reference for this inquiry, the hopes of many people were raised that we would address those kinds of issues. I suppose it depends on interpretation of the terms of reference. But it was very clear that many of the submissions were about these larger questions. I believe we would be remiss if we did not address those concerns in commenting on the report.

Most of the recommendations contained within the report, while they would improve the rural adjustment scheme if implemented, do not get to some of these deeper problems facing Australia's farmers and rural communities. I certainly support the committee's recommendations, but to fully comprehend and to begin to rectify the enormous problems in rural Australia today, we really need to go beyond the scope of the inquiry and perhaps begin to address some of the concerns which were at least projected in the terms of reference, if not explicitly spelt out.

We need to ask ourselves how family farms—farms that have been viable for generation after generation—are suddenly so non-viable that the current generation is being forced to sell up and leave the land. I think the answer to that question would expose some far greater problems than the ones we have covered in the report of this inquiry. In many ways, I believe the drought has masked these deeper problems. The drought has certainly pushed a great number of farms to crisis point and beyond and the media has played a useful role in showing to the broader community the desperation that there is in country Australia. Of course, the response of the public has been encouraging. Perhaps I ought to say that it has been magnificent. I believe this response drove the response by the government in delivering its two drought packages to date.

However, the problems facing Australia's farmers go far deeper than just the drought. I will outline for the Senate what I see to be some of the deeper problems. The first of those problems is the one referred to by Senator Brownhill—namely, the epidemic of rural debt. This epidemic has been brought on by high interest rates, by various banking practices, by the advice and encouragement given to farmers to get big or get out and, regrettably, by insufficient scrutiny and monitoring by the farmers of the financial advice given to them.

The issue of rural debt was touched on very briefly by the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Committee. I am afraid I do support some of the criticisms of the report that Senator Brownhill was defending a moment ago. The issue of rural debt needs far greater attention by the Senate. The second problem is land degradation—degradation that has occurred over a long time—and its contribution to the loss of income for farmers in Australia.

A third problem is the effect on farmers of the global economic system and the market fundamentalist concepts of the level playing field, user pays, free trade and so on. That is partly illustrated by what GATT has done to our tobacco industry—and what it may do to our citrus juice industry and perhaps the pork and dairy industries. The fourth problem facing farmers in rural communities is the removal of government resources from rural areas. This is particularly true of state governments. This has been further exacerbated by the competition rhetoric such as that contained in the Hilmer report.

The fifth problem relates to the entry into the industry of the large international agribusinesses, which are increasing foreign ownership of Australian resources and subsequently bringing about a reduction in the number of Australia's family farming operations. A sixth problem is the total lack of any government commitment to the maintenance of rural communities and infrastructure. More specifically, there is no policy direction from either government or coalition which is committed to the maintenance of population and industry in inland Australia. The final problem I see is the deliberate walking away from policies of cross-subsidisation on which Australia was built and on which many in our rural and remote regions rely.

I see these as some of the deeper problems facing rural Australia today. These are the issues that we will have to address if we are serious about rectifying the growing gulf between rural and urban Australia. The government's current rural adjustment scheme has two major foci. One is designed to make viable farms more viable—that is a worthy objective. The other seeks to remove farmers who are not viable, by definition, from rural industry altogether.

This is a policy for continuing down the same disastrous track—disastrous, that is, from my point of view. While some would see that it may produce a viable rural industry, I see it continuing the dramatic exodus from the bush. We need to really ask ourselves whether we want to see the family farm survive in this country or whether we would be happy to stand by and see those farms taken over by investors and foreign owned agribusiness. The Australian Democrats are committed to fighting to protect the family farm as we believe it is an essential part of the fabric that is rural Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 November last year, Senator Faulkner invoked the provisions of the World Heritage Conservation Act to stop work on the Port Hinchinbrook project near Cardwell in North Queensland. His reason for this decision was:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . last week my department received further information about the probable impacts on the seagrass communities of mangrove clearing on the site.
The project had been fully approved by the Queensland government and had been subjected to rigorous environmental study.

PARA.TAB: Senator Faulkner's own department had advised him that a deed of agreement signed by the Queensland government, the Cardwell Shire Council and the developer was a comprehensive document and represented an approach not unlike what might have been expected from a full environmental impact assessment process. The decision came after 95 per cent of the mangroves had been cleared. Senator Faulkner refused to table his new evidence. It was not until I moved a motion forcing him to table this information that he then did so at the Senate's demand.

The so-called new evidence was mostly outdated letters from unknown academics and scientists from around the place calling for a stop to the project. However, I did find some recent advice which was credible from reputable managers of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, the experts on reef and tropical waters. This advice was dated 14 November 1994, the day before Senator Faulkner's decision was made, and it stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The removal of regrowth mangroves presents very little threat to the seagrass beds.

As well, the evidence included an internal memo from Senator Faulkner's own department which stated that the recommendation from the portfolio is not to take immediate action under the World Heritage Conservation Act.

PARA.TAB: Senator Faulkner had known about the effect of the clearing of the mangroves four months before he made his decision. Concerns were reported in the Valentine report on the project, a report which he commissioned. He also knew that the developer had permission to clear mangroves from the tripartite agreement which he had in his hands for many months. Mr Goss delayed signing for three weeks to ensure Senator Faulkner's approval. Following his decision, under pressure from the coalition, an embarrassed Senator Faulkner then commissioned a workshop of experts to sit down and resolve whether world heritage values were infringed by the mangrove clearing. The workshop found:

SPEECH.PARA: If significant sediment were to erode from the 4 ha mangrove removal area it could have a significant impact on adjacent seagrasses. However, there would be a high probability of recovery (within about 12 months).

We had a situation where Senator Faulkner had stopped a project which was fully approved by the Queensland government and which had been subject to rigorous environmental studies which were equivalent to an environmental impact assessment.

PARA.TAB: The project had been stopped without any credible evidence and in the face of all advice from the Great Barrier Marine Park Authority and the environment department. This was done after the mangroves, which were central to Senator Faulkner's world heritage concerns, had been cleared. It was also done at a time which ensured that work could not begin until after the wet season, leaving a scarred site to drain into the surrounding channel area, causing environmental degradation.

In the process, 40 jobs and over $1 million in revenue were lost. Senator Faulkner was embarrassed by his own workshop experts who argued that the project should go ahead. One would think that Senator Faulkner would have then approved the project—but he did not and he still has not. All work on the project has stalled. Senator Faulkner will not give an ironclad approval for the project through to completion. He has created a labyrinth of environmental bureaucracy impossible for the developer to travel through.

In a letter to the Queensland Minister for Environment and Heritage, Mrs Molly Robson, on 23 December 1994, Senator Faulkner attached a list of 11 processes involved in various stages of the development which may—and I emphasise may—threaten world heritage values in his opinion. These 11 processes include beach and foreshore management, remaining fringe mangroves, site stabilisation, breakwater construction, channel dredging, de-watering of the marina and dredge spoil pool, acid sulphate soils, monitoring and site management, baseline studies and long-term planning for Hinchinbrook Channel. Advice was given on how these processes should be addressed, and this was plagued with management plans and scientific studies.

The department has advised the developer that, to commence activity which could damage world heritage values, he must make a request to the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories so that the minister can assess whether the activity is likely to damage world heritage values, and that these assessments could take some time. The minister stated in his letter:

SPEECH.PARA: The outcomes contained in this document set out a range of issues and processes that are considered relevant to ensuring that World Heritage values are protected. As far as I am concerned the construction can now proceed on this basis, that is subject to these processes being put in place and those outcomes relevant to Port Hinchinbrook development being satisfactory in terms of meeting my concerns about World Heritage values.
Senator Faulkner also warned that `should the above processes produce evidence of a threat to world heritage values then clearly action would be needed to protect them'.

PARA.TAB: Whilst giving this half-hearted approval to the project, the minister has made it impossible for the developer to start the project with any certainty that he will be able to finish it. The project could be stopped by the minister at any time. Any time the developer requests an activity it will take days, weeks or even months to be processed, and it then faces possible rejection by the minister. As such, the developer has stated that he will not start on the project until Senator Faulkner gives clear approval for it through to completion.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you would understand: this is what is wrong with this government; it is a government made up of ex-union bosses, ex-Labor Party officials—of which Senator Faulkner, I think, is both—and perhaps a couple of teachers. They have no idea how business works. They have absolutely no appreciation of what you need to do if you are investing millions of dollars in a project that will create a lot of jobs and bring a lot of export income into Australia.

Giving this sort of approval subject to these sorts of conditions is just ridiculous. It is no wonder that the developer has said, `This is not an approval.' This sort of conditional approval, subject to all these things, is really subject to the minister at any time coming along and saying, `I want it stopped' or every time the developer proceeds on a stage he has to refer it to the minister and refer it to his department and they could take days, weeks or months to look at it. You just cannot run an investment or a development like that. It is obvious that the developer just simply will not go ahead on those bases.

Last year the Courier-Mail exposed seven other projects in North Queensland which had had approval or part-approval from the Queensland government but which were in areas bordering on world heritage areas. There is some concern that many of these also will be stopped by Senator Faulkner. In Townsville, North Queensland, less than an hour south of the Port Hinchinbrook development, we have the same fiasco going again on the Magnetic Keys project on Magnetic Island. That project has been approved by the Queensland government and subjected to environmental assessments. It has been given approval, subject to sensitive environmental conditions.

But again Senator Faulkner has come in over the top and stopped that project which would do so much for Townsville and so much for the economy of North Queensland; it would create jobs and much needed export income. But, yet again, here is this minister—the minister for stopping things in Australia; the Forrest Gump, we now call him; the minister who has cost all the jobs of all these people with all these trucks around Parliament House, the small businessmen in real problems—doing it again in Port Hinchinbrook in Far North Queensland and at Magnetic Keys in Townsville. It is just the same sort of thing. This minister, who does not understand business, is doing his best to cost Australia jobs and chase away investment

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —All this week my colleagues and I in the coalition have been fighting for the workers, families and communities who have been so shamefully treated by this Labor government's inept and damaging handling of the forest issue. We have had this interfactional dispute between a right wing minister and a left wing minister. Then the left wing of the party organised majority caucus support for Senator Faulkner. Now the same left wing is split and members of caucus are threatening to resign. Senator Devereux has already resigned for the obvious reason.

PARA.TAB: The simple fact is: Labor is in a shambles. It is destroying people's livelihoods, and it has lost direction as a government. Labor is going everywhere at once yet at the same time is going nowhere. We therefore need to ask the question: how did Labor get itself into such a mess? There are the answers: the government is incompetent; it is arrogant; and it engages in sleazy opportunistic deals. They might all be reasons. But this evening I suggest that the major reason is the involvement of one Simon Balderstone, the only survivor from what was the staff of former Prime Minister Hawke who is still with the current Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Mr Balderstone is the senior environmental adviser to the Prime Minister.

In volume 2, No. 12, of the glossy environmentalist magazine Simply Living, Simon Balderstone wrote an article entitled `Eco Defence' to bring Australia's attention to the radical organisation known as Earth First. Earth First members pride themselves on being `conservation commandos'. In the editorial part of the article, Balderstone says:

SPEECH.PARA: Direct action, whether it be lying in front of a bulldozer, or sabotaging environmentally-destructive items such as billboards or logging-plants, has its supporters and opponents, but hardly anyone in the Australian conservation movement denies it has played an important role in the past decade.

In fact, while the `Earth First!' movement, led by Dave Foreman (see our interview p.24) in America is acknowledged as the front line for what it calls `ecotage' by `ecoteurs', even that movement cites blockades on the Franklin River . . .
and elsewhere in Australia—
as admirable examples of necessary direct action by the conservation movement.

PARA.TAB: In my home state of Tasmania, Earth First held up a train. You may well recall that incident, Mr Acting Deputy President. The person used the false name of David Rainbow. Earth First spiked trees with metal rods. As a result, a lot of the timber industry now uses metal detectors to determine whether trees are spiked. To overcome that problem, Earth First is now using or threatening to use ceramic rods which will not be detected by these metal detecting devices.

That is nothing short of terrorism because the workers outside this place would have to consider every single day whether they are going to come home alive. The wives and the children at home would have to ask themselves whether their husbands or fathers will be trying to saw a log that has a metal or ceramic spike in it. This is nothing short of terrorism that Earth First promotes.

And the second most powerful man in this government, Simon Balderstone, immediately under the Prime Minister, writes in glowing terms about such an organisation. It is therefore time for Mr Balderstone to come out and say to the Australian people who it is that he serves. Does he serve the Australian government and the Australian people or the extreme green cause. He is paid by Australians—I would imagine, in excess of $75,000 per annum—and for that sum he ought to be working in the best interests of the people of Australia and not just for the extreme green movement.

My suggestion this evening is that he is working for the extreme green movement, and that is what his agenda is. No longer is he concerned about sabotage in the bush when he can do sabotage in the Prime Minister's office and wreak havoc on the industry by getting the Prime Minister and ministers to sign documents.

The evidence was there today because today in the parliament, in the other place, the Prime Minister said that no state of Australia has invited the Commonwealth to partake in a regional forest agreement. That is untrue. Therefore, the Prime Minister has either misled the House or perchance—I would suggest this is the more likely—he was misadvised by Simon Balderstone. Because the truth is that Tasmania did invite the Commonwealth to engage in a regional forest agreement before Christmas.

The national forest policy statement refers to states having the possibility of inviting the Commonwealth. This was to be organised through a document which was being drafted to determine the rules and regulations and the way in which these regional forest agreements would be undertaken. The Commonwealth had that task. In February 1994 it had a draft. In August 1994 it promised the final version in September of 1994. That document has never been provided. One asks why, if it was only a week away in August of 1994, it has taken so long to be provided. In fact, it still has not been provided.

Is it as a result of environmental sabotage in the Prime Minister's office? Is it a deliberate ploy to ensure that regional forest agreements will not take place? And might I add, despite the Commonwealth's tardiness or deliberate sabotage by Mr Balderstone, the Tasmanian government said, `We will enter into one of these arrangements on certain terms.'

We have to ask a lot of questions of Mr Balderstone and the way that this whole issue has been treated. So I ask: prior to yesterday's meeting with the Premier of Tasmania, had the Prime Minister been informed by his adviser Simon Balderstone of all the details of the offer that had been received from Tasmania to become a signatory to the national forest policy statement and to undertake detailed studies leading to a regional forest agreement for Tasmania? Was the Prime Minister advised that Tasmania was not seeking any special deals and was prepared to sign?

If he was advised of that by Simon Balderstone, as he should have been, the Prime Minister misled the other place today. Or the Prime Minister was misled by Simon Balderstone, and the Prime Minister and Simon Balderstone can sort that out between themselves. Clearly, one of them has been engaged in a game of misleading the public of Australia.

I also ask: did Simon Balderstone make a commitment to representatives of the Wilderness Society in September of last year that 500 coupes would be set aside from logging? Did Mr Balderstone release to Bob Burton and Alec Marr a detailed list of 509 coupes to be withdrawn from forestry operations prior to those lists being made available to the relevant action ministers, namely, Beddall and Faulkner?

In his media release of 27 January 1995, the Minister for Resources, Mr Beddall, was not aware. Yet it is now quite transparent that the Greens knew the list. So the following question has to be asked: if that list was determined in the Prime Minister's office, how did the Greens get it before the Minister for Resources and the states? I suggest that there is a clear link. Somebody in the Prime Minister's office leaked it, and one can ask who that might be.

The simple fact is that it is quite apparent that a deal was struck with the Greens by Mr Balderstone, and he is now being held to it by the extreme Greens. That is why the government is in such a mess; it realises that, if Mr Balderstone seeks to renege, they will do what Paul Keating did to Bob Hawke on the Kirribilli House agreement.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 5 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware of the depth of concern felt by Tasmanians about the issue of inadequate television reception as they are forced to change from VHF to UHF.

(2) Is the Minister aware that, contrary to explicit Government promises, struggling households in Tasmania are being forced to change from VHF to UHF, to outlay hundreds of dollars in new equipment and are still suffering reception difficulties.

(3) Is the Minister aware of the promises made by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) in the Senate chamber on 23 and 24 May 1989 regarding television reception in Tasmania, including: `The truth of the matter is . . . that all VHF services will remain on VHF. It is only new services which . . . will be on UHF, `No-one will be forced to buy new TV set', and `The Government program is to provide additional services without disrupting reception of existing services, and that's exactly what will happen'.

(4) Given that these explicit promises have been broken, what action will the Minister and the Government take to see that VHF transmitters are not turned off until such time as all Tasmanians are receiving first-class television reception as promised.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) The use of UHF television frequencies to increase the number of broadcasting services available to Tasmanians, or to improve reception of existing services, is not contrary to Government promises.

(3) Senator Evans's promise referred to the ongoing use of VHF channels for existing commercial television translators serving various regional centres. Senator Evans made his remarks in the context of the Government's Television Equalisation program, which is designed to provide more than 4 million viewers in areas outside mainland capital cities with access to a greater choice in commercial television services.

Since July 1992, the Government has invested about $20.0 million in transmission facilities to improve and extend the signal coverage of national radio and television services in Tasmania. It is estimated that a further $17.0 million will be provided for this purpose from now until June 1996.

(4) Changes in the channels used to transmit the ABC Television service have been made in some areas, either to improve reception of this service or to release frequencies for additional FM radio services.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 18 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the following recommendation of the Australian delegation to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) November 1993 lead meeting been totally ignored by the Government `It is recommended that Australia continue to take a close and active interest (in the OECD Lead Control Act) issue including through thorough preparation for the Canadian Workshop in collaboration with environment interests'.

(2) Can the Minister explain the apparent reluctance by the Environment Protection Agency, and therefore the Australian delegation, to support OECD co-operation on a lead risk reduction strategy and reluctance to support an OECD Council Act on lead.

(3) Can the Minister explain the alleged lack of consultation with environmental non-government organisations (NGOs) concerning Australia's lead policy at OECD meetings since taking on the portfolio of Environment, Sport and Territories.
(4) Will the Minister table a list of meetings and other communication held between industry, NGOs and the Government concerning Australia's lead policy at OECD level.

(5) How many Australian representatives have been sent overseas at Government expense to participate in OECD meetings to devise co-operative lead risk reduction activities by OECD countries, and at what cost to the taxpayer.
(6) Will the Minister table the Australian input into the OECD lead workshop held in Canada in September 1994.
(7) Can the Minister guarantee that the Environment Protection Agency will collaborate with environment NGOs during preparation for the OECD lead meeting to be held in Paris in November 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows :

PARA.TAB: (1) No. The recommendation referred to was made in the report of the Australian Delegation to the OECD Chemicals Group and Management Committee Working Group on the Development of a Council Act on Risk Reduction of Lead held in November 1993. The Environment Protection Agency is the lead agency of the Australian delegation. The exact wording was ` . . . including through thorough preparation for the Canadian Workshop in collaboration with environment interests, industry and technical experts.'

The recommendation was not a formal undertaking by or to government, but one of a number of suggested courses of action leading up to the Canadian Workshop. It was made before the scope and nature of the Workshop were fully known. When the OECD Secretariat circulated the Terms of Reference for the Workshop in February 1994 it was clear that it was to be a fact-finding rather than an overall policy-making forum. The Workshop was convened:

to examine transboundary problems associated with some ten categories of products/uses of lead, including lead shot and fishing sinkers, faucets, crystal and ceramic ware, plastics, paint, and gasoline;
to consider practical options to control lead exposure, including the use of lead substitutes; and
to evaluate the potential implications of such solutions.

In gathering the required technical information, the EPA and other Commonwealth agencies responsible for briefing the Australian delegation to the Workshop consulted extensively with industry, particularly with lead end-users. NGOs were not consulted at this stage because the overall Australian position on a possible Council Act on lead had not altered since the February 1994 meeting of the OECD Chemicals Group and Management Committee. The EPA did consult with NGOs in reaching consensus on an Australian position before the February meeting.

(2) The EPA fully supports OECD activities which engender international co-operation in reducing health and environmental risks due to exposure to lead, particularly co-operative activities leading to information exchange and technology transfer. One such undertaking has been the publication of the `OECD Risk Reduction Monograph No. 1: Lead'. The EPA co-ordinated the substantial contribution made by Australian governments, industry and environment interests. With respect to an OECD Council Act on lead, Australia does not support prescriptive international pollution control or abatement measures unless there is clear evidence that the pollution being addressed has significant transboundary effects. Australia's view is that lead risk reduction is primarily a national issue due to the differing nature of problems faced by Member countries and differing social, economic and environmental conditions and priorities.

The only transboundary issues of concern to emerge from the Canadian Workshop were bird shot and fishing sinkers, lead in petrol, and trade in consumer products that pose a direct risk of exposure (ceramic foodware). The latter problem arises largely from articles traded by non OECD countries. The issue of lead shot and fishing sinkers is a regional one, largely between Canada and the USA. Transboundary pollution from lead in petrol is primarily a problem within Europe and, in Australia's view, best dealt with through such forums as the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.

(3) As outlined above, between February and September 1994 the EPA has been engaged in assembling the technical information required as background to the Canadian Workshop. The findings of the Workshop were considered at the November 1994 meeting of the OECD Chemicals Group and Management Committee. As a result, the EPA and relevant Commonwealth agencies will need to consider a range of policy options with respect to an OECD Council Act in the New Year, and will consult with NGOs and industry in recommending to Government Australia's preferred policy approach.

(4) Consultations between industry, NGOs and the government with respect to lead-related OECD activities fall into three distinct periods. The first, from late 1991 to mid 1992, covered preparation of Australia's input to the OECD Monograph on Lead. The EPA consulted extensively with industry, environment NGOs, and Commonwealth and state government agencies. The Australian Conservation Foundation and the LEAD and NO LEAD groups participated fully in this process. In the second period, from late 1992 to November 1993, the EPA again consulted with governments, industry and NGOs in reaching an Australian position on a possible OECD Council Act on lead. The third and most recent phase is explained above. Immediately following the Canadian Workshop the EPA did attempt to arrange a debriefing meeting with representatives of environment NGOs. This meeting was subsequently cancelled due to invitees' non-availability and/or lack of interest.

I consider that tabling a full list of the numerous meetings and other communications which have taken place between industry, NGOs and the Government over a three and a half year period is an unwarranted drain on agency resources.

(5) Since November 1991 approximately thirty Australian representatives have attended OECD meetings at which lead risk reduction activities have been discussed. Only two of these meetings were dedicated to lead risk reduction, and both involved consideration of an OECD Council Act on lead. Delegates included officers from the EPA, the National Registration Authority, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, the Department of Human Services and Health, and Worksafe. The cost to the Australian government would be in the order of $240,000, of which only a portion was directly related to lead risk reduction. At no stage has the Australian government funded the attendance of representatives of either industry or non-government environment groups at these meetings.

(6) I have made available to Senator Coulter a copy of Australia's input to the Canadian Workshop, a paper entitled `The Rationale for OECD Risk Reduction on Lead: Some Issues for Consideration'. Further copies are available from the Senate Table Office.

(7) As explained above, the EPA attempted to arrange a debriefing on the Canadian Workshop in October as part of the lead-up to the November 1993 Joint Meeting of OECD's Chemicals Group and Management Committee.

The issue of whether or not to have an OECD Lead Council Act was not resolved at the November meeting. Instead, it was decided to form two Working Groups; one to develop a draft Council Act and the other to develop an alternative strategy. Outcomes of each are to be considered by the OECD at its Joint Meeting in June/July 1995. Appropriate consultation with NGOs will occur prior to the meeting.

(1) Are any statistics available in Australia on the number of accidents caused by prescription drugs and drink driving; if so, what are these figures, on a state-by-state basis, over the past 10 years.
(2) What drugs, over the same period, have been found to be involved in Australia's road death toll.
(3) Are sufficient warnings issued to people taking these drugs of the potentially dangerous effect these drugs could have on their driving capability.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Human Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) and (2) Figures are not available, either nationally or on a State by State basis, on the number of road crashes caused by prescription drugs.

However, Associate Professor Olaf Drummer, Victorian Institute of Forensic Pathology, prepared a report on `Drugs in drivers killed in Australian road traffic accidents'. The report is based on 1045 driver fatalities in New South Wales, Victoria and Western Australia covering the period 1990 to 1993. This represented 57% of all driver deaths which occurred during this period. The remaining drivers were excluded from the study largely due to insufficient information. The data revealed that:

alcohol was present in 36% of cases; and
drugs other than alcohol were detected in 22% of the cases with cannabis the most common drug found (11%).

A further analysis of these statistics showed that drugs (both legal and illicit) did not result in a significantly higher culpability ratio than the drug-free group, whereas the presence of alcohol significantly increased the relative risk.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 22 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What steps are taken to ensure that the State concessions listed in the notes accompanying the pensioner concession card are concessions which are actually available.

(2) What should a pension recipient do when the listed concessions, that is, rebates on council and water rates, rebates on electricity bills, reductions on fares on public transport, reductions on motor vehicle registration charges, third party insurance costs and driver's licence fees, are not honoured by the State departments or business enterprises.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The letter accompanying the Pensioner Concession card is prepared in consultation with the States/Territories, to ensure that it accurately reflects the concessions available to pensioners in each of the States/Territories.

The State concessions on council and water rates, electricity charges, public transport fares and motor vehicle charges are what are known as "core concessions". Under an agreement reached between the Commonwealth and the States/Territories on 5 July 1993, the Commonwealth pays compensation to the States/Territories for the continuing provision of these "core concessions" to all pensioners. Responsibility for the actual provision of the "core concessions" rests with various State and local government agencies, including State transport authorities, local councils, etc. However, the agreement is between the Commonwealth and the State/Territory Governments.

State/Territory Governments were required to certify in writing to the Department of Social Security that they were providing and would continue to provide these "core concessions", before payments were made under the agreement.

(2) In the first instance, a pensioner who believes a "core concession" is not being provided in their State should raise the matter with the concession provider concerned. If it is clear that pensioners are being denied a "core concession", the person should then inform the Department of Social Security, preferably in writing.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 30 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 1713 (Senate Hansard, 7 November 1994, page 2534) regarding consideration being given by the Australasian Police Ministers' Council to a ban on the sale of replica and imitation firearms:
(1) Are statistics available on the use of replica and imitation weapons in crime; if so, what are these figures, on a State basis, for the past 5 years.
(2) How do these figures compare with available statistics from overseas.
(3) Has there been any progress by the Australasian Police Ministers' Council in discussions on proposed restrictions on replica and imitation weapons.
(4) Is any consideration being given by the council to exemption status being given to museums and war memorials for purchase and display of replica and imitation firearms.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Justice has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: There are no national statistics available on the use of replica and imitation weapons in crime. I am informed that while State and Territory police services maintain statistics on the use of firearms in crimes, not all jurisdictions specifically record circumstances where those firearms turn out to be replica or imitation weapons. Nonetheless, a number of jurisdictions have noted that imitation or replica pistols have become an easily obtainable weapon, preferred by perpetrators in the commission of armed hold-ups. As a result, there is clearly a need for more stringent controls in this area.

At the 27th Meeting of the Australasian Police Ministers' Council on 16 December 1994, Ministers agreed to prohibit the importation, sale and possession of unauthorised replica and imitation weapons, other than approved toys. This is an important step in reducing the availability of dangerous goods in the community.

Regulations controlling the importation, sale and possession of these weapons will allow the relevant Minister or delegate to provide exemptions to the prohibitions. Bodies seeking such exemptions would be required to gain an exemption certificate from the relevant authority.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 1 December 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What federal authorities were advised of criminal investigations being conducted by Queensland law enforcement agencies relating to Operation Wallah and Operation Hacker 6.

(3) Has there been any subsequent advice given to federal authorities by the Queensland law enforcement agencies since these original briefings.

(4) Have the Queensland law enforcement agencies sought assistance from any federal authorities concerning the Operation Wallah or Operation Hacker 6 investigations or any subsequent investigations currently being carried out by Queensland authorities, particularly matters relating to international inquiries; if so, have the federal authorities agreed to assist with these inquiries.
(5) What assistance has been required of federal authorities by Queensland law enforcement agencies.
(6) Have Australian federal authorities commenced their own inquiries following advice from Queensland law enforcement agencies into matters relating to Operation Wallah and Operation Hacker 6.

(7) On what dates were the Minister and the Attorney-General informally and formally briefed on the investigations being conducted by Queensland law enforcement agencies concerning matters relating to former Senator Richardson.
(8) Has either the Minister or the Attorney-General received any further advice concerning the matters currently under investigation by Queensland law enforcement agencies.
(9) Have any other Federal Cabinet ministers been briefed about federal/State investigations into former Senator Richardson.
(10) Which Ministers have been advised and on what dates were they given this advice.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Justice has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: Senator Chapman has asked a series of questions concerning investigations being conducted by the Queensland Police under the code name Operation `Hacker 6' and the Queensland Criminal Justice Commission (CJC) Operation `Wallah' into alleged criminal activity on the Gold Coast.

I am not in a position to comment on investigations conducted by State authorities. Furthermore, it is not my practice to comment on activities of agencies outside my portfolio and for obvious reasons I will not provide details of current AFP operational activities.

As indicated in my letter of 2 June 1994 to the Leader of the Opposition, any information held within the Opposition ranks relating to the Queensland Criminal Justice Commission investigation, should be provided to the appropriate authorities.
Accordingly, in reply to the honourable senator's question I respond as follows:

(1-3) I draw the honourable senator's attention to the answer I gave to a Question without Notice on 9 June 1994 (House of Representatives Hansard pages 1849-1851). I indicated that the Australian Federal Police (AFP) and the National Crime Authority (NCA) had received briefings from the Queensland Criminal Justice Commission (CJC) under the terms of Memoranda of Understanding (MOU). I was advised at the time that the information provided to the Commonwealth agencies did not disclose the commission by any person of any Commonwealth offence. Operational matters, including the exchange of information, between the AFP, the NCA and the Queensland CJC or Queensland Police Service are left entirely in the hands of the two Commonwealth agencies.
Since my response in the House of Representatives on 9 June 1994, I have been advised that further briefings have been provided to both the AFP and the NCA in accordance with the MOUs.

(4-5) The MOUs recognise that an effective attack on organised crime activity requires mutual cooperation between law enforcement agencies and also recognise the need for agencies to advise, inform and consult in respect of investigations which may result from time to time in mutual assistance being provided. Requests for assistance and the nature of any such assistance requested or provided are operational matters and it is therefore inappropriate that any such details be made available.

(6-10) I have been advised by the AFP that a subsequent briefing was received from the Queensland authorities which contained further allegations. I am further advised that these allegations relate to possible Commonwealth offences and are currently being assessed by the AFP before any commitment is made to undertake a criminal investigation, and until the AFP concludes its examination of these matters, it would be inappropriate for the Government to make further comment.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 7 December 1994 (Hansard page 4081) Senator Watson asked me a question without notice concerning the inflation implications for Australia of growth in the money supply, comparing the growth of money supply in Australia with that of comparable countries.

PARA.TAB: The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

Monetary policy is primarily set with the medium term objective of maintaining low inflation and low inflation expectations. Maintaining low inflation is vital if Australia is to achieve the investment needed to ensure sustained economic and employment growth.

Since 1990, both headline and underlying inflation have slowed significantly. Headline inflation has been below 2 per cent in each of the last three financial years. This is the longest period of sustained low inflation since the early 1960s. Underlying inflation has been around 2 per cent in each of the last two financial years.
Australia's inflation rate has been at a level comparable to that of our major trading partners for around 3 1/2 years.
The Government will not allow these gains on inflation to be lost.

In determining the appropriate stance of monetary policy the authorities carefully monitor a range of economic and financial indicators in gauging inflationary pressures. These include trends in capacity utilisation and labour market conditions,

ANSWER.PARA: wage agreements, price increases and price setting behaviour by firms, changes in inflation expectations, monetary and credit aggregates, movements in the $A and the current and prospective state of the world economy.

PARA.TAB: For the purposes of considering adjustments to monetary policy, the emphasis is on how the indicators may be foreshadowing future developments in relation to inflation and activity. No one indicator is paramount in this process and no prescriptive relative weightings are placed on the various indicators. Since deregulation of the financial sector in the early 1980s growth in the monetary aggregates has proved to be less reliable as an indicator of economic developments due to continued institutional change and financial innovation. Other countries have had a similar experience. International comparisons of money supply growth are also not necessarily meaningful because of different measures and institutional structures operating in different countries.

As is to be expected, growth in the monetary aggregates has increased since the recession. However, as illustrated in the chart below, growth in the money base, M3 and broad money are still moderate. M1 has been growing strongly for some time, but this appears to be due, to a considerable extent, to a long-term trend towards cheque-linked accounts.

ANSWER.PARA: [CHART OMITTED FROM DATABASE - SEE HARD COPY PAGE 479]

PARA.TAB: The Reserve Bank and the Government are committed to maintaining underlying inflation at around 2 to 3 per cent over the course of the economic cycle. In the light of evidence that the economy is growing very strongly, the Reserve Bank has raised official interest rates in three discrete moves since August 1994. While current underlying inflation remains low, because of the lags involved, official interest rates have been adjusted in a timely manner to moderate economic activity and hence potential future inflationary pressures.
